title: Almost half of bird species at risk of extinction as worrying state of nature in UK revealed
lead: The first State of Nature report in four years has found that nearly one in six UK species is at risk of disappearing due to intensified farming and climate change
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: Britain’s  are not “up to scratch”, environmentalists have said, after a landmark report .
Without action, they warned, the situation would only get worse, with the countryside reduced to monoculture farming and non-native species.

The State of Nature report, compiled by more than 60 environmental NGOs and charities, tracks the abundance and distribution of more than 10,000 species in the UK and the British Overseas Territories with data going back to 1970.

The latest edition, the first  found that nearly one in six species were at risk of being lost from Great Britain. On average, species had declined 19 per cent since monitoring began, with skylarks, for example, dropping 59 per cent in abundance.
The major causes behind the decline were the  from the 1950s onwards and , the report found.

Craig Bennett, chief executive of the , said it was up to politicians to turn the situation around. “This next parliament will be the most important in my lifetime for nature and climate action,” he said, adding, “Nature recovery is fundamental to tackling climate change and improving people’s lives – history will not be kind to politicians who ignore this truth.”
Groups involved in the study said that conservationists already knew what policies worked but that it was not yet being done on a big enough scale.
Beccy Speight, the RSPB’s chief executive, said of the findings: “The UK’s is better studied than in any other country in the world and what the data tell us should make us sit up and listen”.

She added: “We know that conservation works and how to restore ecosystems and save species. We need to move far faster as a society towards nature-friendly land and sea use, otherwise the UK’s nature and wider environment will continue to decline and degrade, with huge implications for our own way of life.”
Richard Gregory, head of monitoring at the RSPB, said that more needed to be done both in supposedly protected areas and on farmland across the country.
“We have huge swathes of land given over to national parks and Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty (AONBs) and so on. And we have all these protected areas, but they’re not being really protected. .”
National Parks England was approached for comment.

Twenty-six per cent of the UK’s land area is covered either by a national park or an AONB, but according to a report by the House of Lords this summer just 6.5 per cent meets the international criteria for being protected for nature.
The UK has pledged to protect 30 per cent of its land for nature by 2030.

Mr Gregory said that the sheer volume of farmland, meanwhile, meant that small tweaks to agriculture could have big impacts. “That would be relatively easy to do with the will because we have the knowledge,” he said.

Across the country, Westminster and the devolved governments have launched various subsidy schemes aimed at making farming more nature friendly. However, the report found that only a fraction of farmland was covered, ranging from 28.5 per cent in Wales, to just 4.8 per cent in Northern Ireland.

Despite the bleak overall picture, the authors of the report were keen to highlight projects that had brought species back from the brink. For example, rock lobster or crawfish was on the brink of extinction in the 70s and 80s but had increased in distribution by 576 per cent.
The report found that , with 43 per cent of species at risk of localised extinction in Britain, while 31 per cent of amphibians and reptiles were also at risk.
For terrestrial mammals, more than a quarter of species were in danger of extinction, including hedgehogs and red squirrels.
The picture was also grim for plantlife, with 54 per cent of species having decreased in distribution.

As well as plants and animals being in decline, the report found that the UK’s landscapes were in a poor condition. Just 7 per cent of broadleaved woodlands and 25 per cent of peatland were classified as in good ecological condition.
, said the Government had put into law the requirement to halt the decline in nature and pointed to the target to protect 30 per cent of land for nature.

“At the start of this year, I published our comprehensive Environmental Improvement Plan, setting out how we will create and restore at least 500,000 hectares of new wildlife habitats, starting with 70 new wildlife projects including 25 new or expanded National Nature Reserves,” she said.
“We also continue to , plant more trees and through our world-leading environmental farming schemes support farmers to produce food sustainably and profitably.”
The report is not without success stories.

Among the creatures to have done well since 1970 was the red kite, which was once extinct in England and Scotland. It now numbers more than 4,400 breeding pairs, a seven fold increase over the last five decades.
Meanwhile, the wood bristle moss has boomed thanks to a decrease in sulphur dioxide emissions, which causes acid rain. The bryophyte has increased its range by 170 square kilometres.

Other species, however, are not doing well at all. Hedgehog numbers appear to have more than halved since 1970s, while red squirrel abundance has dropped 37 per cent. Puffin populations crashed by 30 per cent in the mid-2000s and have not recovered.

title: ‘Truly frightening’ that water companies can’t meet investment targets, say river campaigners
lead: Ofwat found the industry had spent just 73% of the funds available, raising fears that it doesn’t have the capacity the build the much bigger projects needed in future
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: A failure by water companies to hit investment limits is a “truly frightening” sign that they may have lost the capacity to properly invest in infrastructure and reduce pollution, campaigners have warned.

Ofwat, the water regulator, sets a level at which water companies can charge customers so as to fund so-called enhancements, including improving the security of water supply and reducing environmental impacts.

On Tuesday, showing that they spent just 73 per cent of the approximately £7bn in funding allocated for the 2020-23 period. Overall, enhancement spending should account for around one-fifth of company spending.
Across 17 companies that provide water and/or sewage services, 13 failed to spend the full amount. Only United Utilities overspent by any considerable figure.

The largest underspends were by Yorkshire Water, which had permission to invest more than £800m and spent around £300m, and Thames Water, which spent approximately £700m of its nearly £1.2bn allowance.
The industry has blamed a number of factors for the shortfall, including the lingering effects of Covid, rampant inflation and planning delays.
There have  that water companies may be unable to raise the capital needed to fund improvements, but Ofwat’s report suggests that even with money available the industry struggles to get things built.
Nick Measham, chief executive of WildFish, which  and improve drought resilience, told i that it was a worrying sign for the future.
“This is really scary that this industry doesn’t have the capacity to complete capital projects,” he told i, “it’s truly terrifying.”
He said years of underinvestment appeared to have left the industry ill-suited to the changes needed.

Under the Government’s existing infrastructure plan, the industry is expected to spend £60bn over the next 27 years to dramatically reduce storm overflows in which sewage is discharged into rivers and seas.
It also has plans to , with seven regions in England forecast to be water stressed by the end of the decade.
Industry insiders  that would push the sector’s capacity for infrastructure development to its limits.
Mr Neasham and other campaigners have been pushing for the industry and ministers to move even faster.

Ofwat itself said in the report that it was concerned by the shortfall, saying: “Customers have provided water companies with funding to deliver service improvements. We are concerned that there are companies that are underspending their enhancement allowance while not achieving their performance targets”.
The report adds: “Given the step up in investment that is likely to be required for the 2025-30 period we expect companies to improve their delivery capabilities over the next two years”.
Water UK, the industry body, said that it expected companies to catch up in the remaining two years of the current investment cycle.

A spokesperson told i: “Construction projects were severely restricted by Covid lockdowns in 2020. Today’s figures show that the industry has been catching up since then, but there is clearly more to do before the 2025 deadline. Ensuring the security of our water supply in the future while protecting the environment will take significant investment. That’s why water companies in England and Wales are proposing record levels of spend over the rest of this decade, with detailed plans set to be published next week.”

Following the publication of the performance report, which showed 12 companies failing to hit their targets, Ofwat announced that £114m would be returned to customers through lower bills. Five companies have been permitted to charge more as a reward for exceeding targets, with the rest paying penalties.
Ofwat said in its performance assessment that not a single company reached its highest grade of performance, “leading”.
Thames, Anglian, Bristol, South East, Welsh Water, Southern and Yorkshire Water all fell into the lowest category,  “lagging”, while the remaining 10 were rated “average”.

Environment Secretary Thérèse Coffey said: “While I acknowledge there is good work ongoing in some companies – cleaning up waterways and investing in vital infrastructure – there is simply not enough of it. The fact that not a single water company is classified as ‘leading’ is unacceptable. Our water and sewerage systems are highly complex and under increasing pressure – but that is no excuse”.
Ofwat was approached for comment.

title: Temperatures of 75°C will one day wipe out humanity – but not for another 250 million years
lead: The problems we are already facing as a result of climate change show just how monumental they will be millions of years from now at much higher levels of warming, researchers argue
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Scientists are predicting a bout of  so great it will wipe out the human race even if greenhouse gas emissions were cut to zero tomorrow.
But this won’t happen for another 250 million years.
Researchers have forecast the first mass extinction since the dinosaurs died out 66 million years ago – with temperatures set to reach as high as 75°C and humidity becoming so great it will be
The hottest day ever recorded was 56.7°C in California’s Death Valley in July 1913, according to the World Meteorological Organization, the body recognised as keeper of world records.

Based on the first-ever supercomputer climate models of the distant future, scientists say their research demonstrates how climate extremes will dramatically intensify as the world’s continents very slowly merge to form one hot, dry and largely uninhabitable supercontinent.
When this happens, the study predicts temperatures that are routinely hitting 40°C to 50°C, quite often climbing up to around 65°C and even 75°C – combined with extreme humidity.
Alexander Farnsworth, one of the researchers at Bristol University, told i: “In some places we have some daily weather extremes that can reach upwards of 65°C to 75°C in our simulations.

“The hotter it gets the more humid it can also get. And humidity really matters. It can mean the difference between being able to sweat to cool down in hot temperatures and not being able to – leading to death.
“This would ultimately seal our fate. Humans – along with many other species – would expire.”
The temperature rise will result from three factors, the scientists claim, two of which relate to the formation of the supercontinent known as Pangea Ultima.

First, the Tectonic processes in the Earth’s crust that are slowly bringing the continents together to create a single supercontinent will lead to more frequent volcanic eruptions, which release huge amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, warming the planet.

Second, much of the cooling effect of the sea of the sea will be lost. The oceans absorb far more heat than the land, curbing temperature rises in hotter weather in coastal areas and inland.  As most of the Earth’s surface moves much further from the ocean in the supercontinent that cooling benefit will be reduced  – in a process known as the “continental effect”.

Finally, the sun will become about 2.5 per cent brighter in the next 250 million years, adding more energy to the Earth and further warming the world. This is part of a trend, common among all stars, in which hydrogen is converted into helium at an ever-faster rate, in a process called fusion.
These resulting temperature rises also increase humidity because as atmosphere warms, it can hold more moisture.

“The newly emerged supercontinent would effectively create a triple whammy, comprising the continentality effect, hotter sun and more CO2 in the atmosphere, of increasing heat for much of the planet,” Dr Farnsworth said.

Although human-induced climate change and global warming is likely to be a growing cause of heat stress and mortality in some regions, research suggests the planet should largely remain habitable until this seismic landmass change in the deep future.
But when the supercontinent forms, findings indicate only somewhere between 8 per cent and 16 per cent of land would be habitable for mammals, scientists have said.

“If we look at humans’ natural ability to survive extreme heat then there are several heat-stress thresholds that can’t be crossed in general. Firstly, exposure to Wet Bulb temperatures, which consider heat and moisture, above 35°C for over six hours would be fatal. This even considers total inactivity, full shade, absence of clothing and unlimited drinking water.
“Likewise, Dry Bulb temperatures (what you measure on a thermometer) above 40°C and low humidity for a sustained period of time is also lethal,” Dr Farnsworth said.
Many other species are unlikely to fare much better than humans and other mammals.

“We only looked at mammals, but it would certainly not be a fun place for other species. The fact that much of the continents become aridified – removing a lot of the vegetation on which mammals and other species survive would make life difficult for most species.

“And plants, in general, do not like temperatures above 40°C. Plants underpin the food pyramid, so if you start to remove them over vast areas you stress the rest of the species, such as insects, which rely on them and subsequently the higher ‘trophic level’ species that in turn rely on them as a food source.”
He argued that there may be a way round total human extinction with the right technology but says that would be a mammoth and highly complex task with no guarantee of success.
In the most shorter term, Eunice Lo, also of Bristol University, said “it is vitally important not to lose sight of our current climate crisis”.

“While we are predicting an uninhabitable planet in 250 million years, today we are already experiencing extreme heat that is detrimental to human health. This is why it is crucial to reach net-zero emissions as soon as possible,” she said.
found that more than 4,500 deaths were linked to extreme temperatures on the hottest days of 2022’s record-breaking heatwave.
It found there were an estimated 4,507 heat-related deaths over the hottest days in England, the most deaths in a 35-year period between 1988 and 2022.
In the warming study, the scientists applied climate models, simulating temperature, wind, rain and humidity trends for the next supercontinent expected to form in the next 250 million years.
To estimate the future level of CO2 the team used models of tectonic plate movement, ocean chemistry and biology to map out inputs and outputs of CO2.

The future CO2 calculations were led by Professor Benjamin Mills, at the University of Leeds, who said: “We think CO2 could rise from around 400 parts per million (ppm) today to more than 600 ppm many millions of years in the future. Of course, this assumes that humans will stop burning fossil fuels, otherwise we will see those numbers much, much sooner.”
The study is published in the journal Nature.

title: Jobs and investment at risk over year of uncertainty following Net Zero U-turn, business leaders warn
lead: Labour has already pledged to restore the 2030 petrol and diesel car ban and energy efficiency requirements on landlords, leaving firms guessing on the UK’s climate policy until the next election.
author: Arj Singh

body.text: A year of pre-election uncertainty has been sparked by   which will cost the UK jobs and damage the economy, business leaders and climate experts have warned.
The Prime Minister controversially U-turned on a string of climate pledges on Wednesday, including delaying the 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel cars to 2035.
Labour has said will reverse the decision if it wins power, while also rejecting Mr Sunak’s scrapping of requirements on landlords to meet new energy efficiency regulations.

A Shadow Cabinet Minister told i that Labour has heard from car manufacturers that they will carry on” work towards the 2030 date, but said it was “outrageous” that manufacturers who have spent “hundreds of millions on production lines because they were told to by the Government” were now “at a competitive disadvantage”.

The “ambiguity” triggered by the announcement has undone “years of work” in “depoliticising the debate and building investor confidence”, the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) director-general Shevaun Haviland said in an article for i.
“A year out from the likely date of the next General Election, all parties should be engaging in a long-term, stable approach to Net Zero.”
She warned that companies were likely to make investments in competitors like the United States, the EU and China which are “surging ahead” in the race for clean power and technology.

“Conflicting messaging mystifies net zero and diverts much-needed investment to more stable policy environments elsewhere, with the UK losing out on high quality jobs for the future which damages our economic prospects,” she said.
The concern was echoed by green policy experts.

Peter Chalkey, director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU): “The chaos of the past two days leaves investor confidence shaken, particularly as it comes off the back of the Government’s recent failure to secure new offshore wind farms in its own auction, an error that’s cost bill payers a billion pounds.
“Investors will be asking themselves could a possible Labour government after the next election restore that confidence with a more stable policy environment.

“In the meantime though, with the US incentivising and attracting huge sums of net zero investments, the PM’s U-turns will likely put off or delay projects that would have created jobs. The PM has prioritised politics over the economy.
“The UK’s net zero economy is worth £70bn but can’t be taken for granted.”
Ed Matthews, head of campaigns at E3G climate think tank: “Absolutely unquestionably, we’re going to be in a period of investor instability over the next year.

“Because [companies] will now have less confidence in the Government’s plan to deliver on the net zero target, but they will also know that if Labour win the next election, they will be far more ambitious.
“I think for the car industry, they know that it’s highly likely that this target could be reinstated in a year’s time.
“So on one hand they’ll be planning on that basis, but the bigger problem, is about the economic opportunity for the UK as a whole.
“These companies have a choice about where to invest, and we’re locked in a race to Zero with the US, China and Europe.
“And they are steaming ahead in that race at the moment, while we’re already behind.
“So the decision to delay the 2030 ban will just undermine the confidence of investors further that the UK is a serious place to invest in green technology.
“It will be damaging to investment in green industry and green technology.”

:  “We’ve been through all the numbers, we’ve looked at the range of policies that we’ve got in place… we have consistently over-delivered in all our previous carbon budgets, we’ve consistently over-delivered despite everyone saying we were behind,” he said.

Mr Sunak continued: “We are absolutely not slowing down efforts to combat climate change. I am very proud of our country’s leadership. We have decarbonised faster than any other major economy in the G7, not a fact you hear reported that often.”
Delaying the ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars to 2035: Labour would reverse this decision and bring the ban back to 2030

Scrapping measures to force landlords or homeowners to upgrade homes to an energy performance certificate (EPC) of grade C or higher by 2035: Shadow Net Zero Secretary Ed Miliband said Labour does not support watering down obligations on landlords to improve the energy efficiency of rental homes, in a signal it would reverse this

Scrapping the 2035 ban on gas boilers: Labour has not yet outlined a policy response this decision from Mr Sunak, although Mr Miliband insisted the party would “set out a plan in government with a date”

Meat tax, frequent flyer tax, “compulsory car sharing” and seven recycling bins: Mr Sunak has been accused of announcing that he was scrapping a series of non-existent policies. Mr Miliband said “we’re not in favor of seven bins” and “I’m certainly not in favour of a meat tax, it’s ridiculous”.

title: King Charles warns of ‘existential threat’ of climate change, one day after Sunak’s green policy U-turn
lead: He urged both nations to ‘strive together to protect the world from our most existential challenge of all – that of global warming’
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: used a speech to the French senate to warn of the “existential threat” of as he urged the UK and France to work together on the issue.
His comments came a day after Rishi Sunak announced that  including pushing the ban on petrol and diesel car sales to 2035.
Opening his speech in English before , the King, who has often , called for a “partnership for sustainability” between Britain and France.

“Just as we stand together against military aggression, so must we strive together to protect the world from our most existential challenge of all – that of , climate change and the catastrophic destruction of nature,” he said.

He went on the warn that the “challenge facing our planet is both great and grave”, but that it had been “been increasingly heartening to see the action that is being taken by our governments, our people and, more and more, by the private sector”.

“I have long felt that our businesses can play a most vital role, working in partnership and harmony with our governments and our people, to channel trillions of dollars to the solutions that will enable a successful transition to a sustainable world,” King Charles continued.

He added that he would be meeting with business leaders from France and Britain later in the day, who had been crucial in “preserving our precious biodiversity and offering essential global leadership”.

King Charles proposed that France and Britain should team up to jointly tackle the climate and biodiversity emergencies with a new version of the 1904 Entente Cordiale pact that sealed the friendship between Paris and London.
“I would like to propose it also becomes an ‘Entente pour la Durabilité’ [Partnership for Sustainability] in order to tackle the global climate and biodiversity emergency more effectively,” he said.
His speech was the first time a member of the Royal Family has address the French upper house since his late mother  did so in 2004.
He went on to thank France for the “great kindness” it had shown the Royal Family and the UK following her death in September 2022.
King Charles began his state visit with a lavish banquet at the Palace of Versailles on Wednesday night hosted by  alongside 200 guests, including celebrities such as Mick Jagger and Hugh Grant.
Following his speech to the senate, the King will visit the  suburb of Saint-Denis, which is home to the French national stadium used for the Rugby World Cup, and the Olympics next year.
He will later tour a flower market and see the ongoing renovations at the Notre Dame Cathedral, which was partially destroyed by a fire in 2019.
The visit is being seen as a chance for the UK to reset its relationship with France after the damaging years following the Brexit referendum.
The EU’s former Brexit negotiator, Michel Barnier,] wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, that “this visit is the symbol of a new chapter in the special relationship between our two nations”.

between the two countries, with French Info correspondent Richard Place saying: “Charles III’s visit may seem insignificant. However, it has a political significance. The arrival of the British royal couple sends an important message.”
French daily Le Monde described the visit as “three days to showcase Franco-British friendship”, while Le Figaro focused on Charles’s transformation since he became King last year.
The publication said: “Charles III largely succeeded in his first steps. The day after his mother’s death, he was up to the task. Finding the right tone, the right place.”

title: What will replace gas boilers in 2035? When the UK ban will be, alternatives explained and how heat pumps work
lead: The cut-off for the sale of new gas boilers remains at 2035, with exemptions for struggling households
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: Rishi Sunak has announced  delaying the ban on new petrol and diesel cars and new fossil fuel heating for off-gas-grid homes, but the sale of new gas boilers will still be outlawed from 2035.
In a , the block on the sale of petrol and diesel cars moves from 2030 to 2035.
The ban on installing oil, LPG boilers and new coal heating for off-gas-grid homes is delayed until 2035, instead of phasing them out from 2026.
However, the cut-off for the sale of new gas boilers remains at 2035, with exemptions for households who will struggle financially to make the switch.
The Government is also raising the Boiler Upgrade Grant by 50 per cent to £7,500, to help households who want to replace their gas boilers with a low-carbon alternative such as a heat pump.
The Prime Minister said this was a .
We take a look what the options are to heat homes if gas boilers are no longer the answer.
The legislation does not mean homeowners must scrap existing gas boilers.
But it will affect the installation of any new boilers in a home from 2035, and what property developers can use in new build homes from the same date.
are likely to become one of the most common ways to heat homes as fossil-fuel boilers are phased out.
The Government had been investigating the possibility of  over the coming years to help reach net-zero carbon emissions.

But in July, Grant Shapps, the former energy security secretary, said it was now “unlikely” hydrogen would be used to replace gas-powered boilers because of the need to replace pipework in a switchover.

He told an event at Westminster that he was “a big believer in hydrogen as part of our energy mix in the future” but added: “Hydrogen molecules are very small, you have to replace potentially quite a lot of piping, and of course you’ve got to produce the ‘green’ hydrogen to make the whole thing stack up, the kind of volumes which mean that the transition would be pretty slow.
“So I’m not sure that home heating will be all through hydrogen, it will have a role to play.”
uses technology similar to that found in a refrigerator or an air conditioner.

It extracts heat from a source, such as the surrounding air or geothermal energy stored in the ground, increases it to a higher temperature using electricity, and then transfers the heat to where it is needed around a home.
Air-source heat pumps use the heat energy from the air and ground-source heat pumps use geothermal energy from the ground.

Heat batteries are an emerging technology that uses dense natural materials to store heat at high temperatures that can be released slowly over a 24-hour period. They are designed to charge up during off-peak times when electricity tariffs are lower.
The heat battery concept can be used for a heat battery boiler, which would be a direct replacement for a gas boiler.

Electric boilers are also available, but they can cost up to four times more per year to run if using peak-rate electricity and are unable to meet high demands for heating and hot water, so are best suited to smaller homes and flats.
Biomass boilers operate in the same way as conventional boilers but burn biomass (biological material from plant-based organisms such as wood logs, chips or pellets) rather than fossil fuels.
Solar thermal panels absorb heat from the sun during daylight hours and use that energy to heat a water-based central heating system.
Within the panels are tubes of fluid that take in heat from the sun. This energy is then transferred through a heat exchanger before warming the central heating system or water in a cylinder.

title: Cost of living sees homeowners rethink green upgrades despite widespread support for net zero
lead: Homeowners were slightly less inclined to install all kinds of net zero-related measure in their homes, from heat pumps to energy efficient lightbulbs, a new study has found
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The has led some homeowners to reconsider making green upgrades such as heat pumps and solar panels to their homes despite widespread support for , a survey has found.

The second Net Zero Homes Index survey, which tracks the willingness of UK families to make home and lifestyle changes to tackle climate change, found households appetite for green measures has declined in the past year – although many still plan to carry out upgrades.

Over the next two years, 28 per cent of homeowners said they were willing to install a heat pump, down from 31 per cent a year ago, according to the nationally-representative survey of 4,007 carried out for British Gas by the Public First consultancy.
Over the same period, their willingness to install better insulation fell from 47 to 46 per cent and to add solar panels, from 42 to 41 per cent.
Plans to install electric vehicle “fast charging points” took the biggest hit, with just 28 per cent saying they were will to install them in the next two years, compared to 34 per cent a year ago.
Energy-efficient lightbulbs and electrical appliances, as well as triple glazing, also saw slight decreases over the period.

The slight decline in enthusiasm for net zero measures is mirrored by a dip in confidence about whether the UK can meet its target to become carbon neutral by 2050 – with the confidence index dropping from 57.5 to 56.5 in the past year.

“In a year that has been particularly difficult for households with the rising cost of living and inflation at a high, we’ve seen these issues reflected in our second Net Zero Homes Index,” said Gail Parker, director of low-carbon homes at British Gas Zero.

“But we are also seeing that people want to make changes to de-carbonise their homes and its key that we work with Government and the rest of the industry to ensure households can make these changes easily and affordably,” she said.

The research also found that respondents were overwhelmingly receptive to the development with 79 per cent supporting building more on-shore wind, compared to just 7 per cent saying they were opposed.
Meanwhile, nearly nine in 10 respondents supported building more solar power, 83 per cent supported more off-shore wind.
New nuclear remained the most controversial low-carbon energy option, with only 48 per cent supporting it.

The report comes as Rishi Sunak prepares to water down several policies to help the UK reach net zero, such as pushing back bans on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars and the installation of new gas boilers.

Philip Evans, climate campaigner for Greenpeace UK, said: “Much has been said about Rishi Sunak breaking the cross-party consensus on the urgent need to cut carbon emissions, but it’s important to remember this consensus extends far beyond Westminster.

“These survey results show Britain still overwhelmingly wants cheap solar and wind power, clean technologies and energy efficient homes to cut our heating bills. This is what is needed to bring down the cost of living, and is exactly where economic growth is going to happen.”

Imogen Dow, warm homes campaigner at Friends of the Earth, said: “On a day where the Prime Minister has all but steamrolled over the UK’s climate commitments, it’s heartening to see that public appetite for meaningful climate action is completely at odds with the government’s ill-conceived agenda. “Not only are people incredibly supportive of our climate goals, they overwhelmingly want more cheap, green energy, and many have said they’d be willing to make climate-friendly changes to their homes, such as installing home insulation. “This goes against divisive narratives being pushed by those who wish to make climate action a wedge issue – that people are unwilling to accept the scale of change required. It goes without saying that those who’ve done least to cause climate breakdown, including those on low incomes, should not carry the cost burden of going green, but it’s up to government to design policies so that they are fair and equitable. If this was a real priority, the government would be rolling out a street-by-street insulation programme for those who need it most, helping to slash both energy bills and emissions.”
Kathryn Brown, Director of Climate Change and Evidence at The Wildlife Trusts, says:

“In a world reeling from the costs of inaction over net zero, taking control of our carbon emissions is both empowering and essential. The battle against climate change isn’t about a single choice, but a conscious collective shift.

“British Gas’ new report shows that people are passionate about nature and climate issues, and determined to do what they can to help. It’s about accountability, resilience, and embracing a three-step approach: calculation of carbon footprint, reduction of emissions, and investment in nature recovery. We each have a unique path to net zero, but together, we forge the road to a sustainability.”

title: Why scrapping net zero low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets could win Sunak votes and save Tory MPs
lead: The PM’s net zero rethink began in July, as he ordered a review of low-traffic neighbourhoods. Last night Tower Hamlets mayor Lutfur Rahman got there first and scrapped most of his. Pollsters tell i how they think it will play electorally.
author: Hannah Fearn

body.text: In Levenshulme, south Manchester, residents are at war. Half of the neighbours in this once-poor but now steadily gentrifying suburb want controversial traffic-calming measures.

They are keen on the closures of “school streets” and the creation of – areas into which only the residents and staff of local businesses can drive. The other half are infuriated by them, worried about rising council tax and angry about incursions on their liberty.

“Two of my neighbours had an argument on the street about it,” one resident, too anxious to be named, says. “It’s a subject I wouldn’t go near, having to live here. I see all sides of the issue: it’s benefiting some streets, but it’s definitely displacing traffic to boundary roads – because sometimes I am that traffic.”

Angry rows like this are taking place in towns and cities across the country. And the conflict is leading some in national politics to sense an opportunity. In the aftermath of the Conservatives’ unexpected victory in the credited to motorists’ opposition to the expansion of the London wide  – Rishi Sunak is seeking to expand his party’s appeal to fed-up drivers.

In a precursor to this week’s , July saw the Prime Minister announce a . And it could go beyond the proliferation of LTNs set up during lockdown. Whitehall insiders have not ruled out the possibility of a review taking in school streets – the partial closures of roads outside schools that keep them free of cars while children are dropped off and collected.

These traffic calming measures have been sold as  by “helping to drive down congestion” – the .But the politics of low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets are more complicated than simply relieving voters of a looming financial burden in the way that a . While many fiercely oppose the inconvenience that closing off streets to traffic brings,  the safe, quieter and less polluted roads, particularly where school children are concerned.
So would scrapping these really be canny politics that will bring electoral rewards. Or could it backfire for Mr Sunak?

Lutfur Rahman, the controversial directly-elected mayor of Tower Hamlets, has provided something of a test case. Last night he announced , despite the council’s consultation showing that 57.3 per cent of residents wanted to keep them.  Mr Rahman said there had been attempts to skew the consultation. But his decision to scrap the LTNs, or “Liveable Streets” as they are branded in the borough, was only backed by 41.7 per cent of consultees and has been met with angry protests.

So is this just bad politics from the mayor and the Aspire political party that he founded in Tower Hamlets?  The election last year, in which Mr Rahman won the mayoralty, suggests not.  The former local Labour leader had made opposition to LTNs a central issue in his campaign.

At the top of the list of pledges in Mr Rahman’s manifesto was a promise to: “Reopen our roads and abolish the failed Liveable Streets scheme, which has seen emergency services and vulnerable residents’ access blocked.” He said he would “only introduce traffic reduction measures through consultation with, and by the consent of the people of this borough”.

Mr Rahman went on to not only win the mayoralty but his party, Aspire, gained enough councillors to take control of the council. Within months, Tower Hamlets had removed school streets schemes from outside schools in Bow, to a mixed reaction from parents. And this week he has gone much further by scrapping nearly all LTNs.

As ever with elections, the cause and effect of individual policies is hard to definitively untangle. The politics of Tower Hamlets are particularly complex and, on the other side of the debate, the Green Party, which campaigned in favour of LTNs, won its first seat on the council. But it was Aspire that was propelled into power, having campaigned hard on scrapping them and Mr Rahman has said his victory was a “resounding democratic mandate” for the removal of the road closures.

In Levenshulme, where the debate still rages, it is hard to discern which way the issue is playing from election results. Labour, which has run Manchester Council for years, and is responsible for introducing LTNs and school streets – has held onto to all three council seats in the suburb in recent elections. And this year the Green Party, which has been campaigning strongly in favour of street closures, boosted its position in a Levenshulme seat to second place behind the Labour candidate for the first time and took 31 per cent of the vote.
But independent candidate Jeremy Hoad, who has criticised the council’s LTNs policy, has also seen a rise in his popularity in both the 2022 and 2023 council elections.

A study published by the University of Westminster this year that investigated the relationship between political messages on social media regarding LTNs and councillors’ share of the vote might give Mr Sunak some pause for thought.

Professor Rachel Aldred told i her research found that Labour councillors were more likely to receive a slight uplift in their vote share after posting positive messages about LTNs. But for Conservative candidates, there was no immediate impact in taking a negative stance.

However, national pollsters have much more positive news for the PM, with evidence suggesting that he could benefit electorally from scrapping low-traffic neighbourhoods and school streets. Ipsos Mori carried out countrywide research in 2022 to look at the level of support for creating LTNs.

“Last year we found that half of people support creating low-traffic neighbourhoods in principle, but this has a small fall to 45 per cent if you point out that it would mean you personally could not drive in certain areas unless you lived or worked there, and a bigger fall to 22 per cent if it means a financial trade-off in terms of higher levels of council tax,” Gideon Skinner, Ipsos Mori head of political research, told i.

In 2021, a similar Ipsos study found that the most successful arguments in favour were not linked to but to local benefits such as making areas safer and reducing street accidents. Voters found the most convincing arguments against were the inconvenience of making longer journeys and the disadvantages for those with mobility issues.

According to Mr Skinner, the data gathered by Ipsos suggests that Mr Sunak’s gamble might be worthwhile. “Clearly it can have an impact in a local setting if you can turn it into an issue, as we saw in Uxbridge, and it is an issue that may have some potential to help shore up the Conservatives’ political base – especially if it’s framed more about impact on drivers and perceptions of unfairness rather than climate change or health benefits, or if there is big media campaign about it,” he says.
“It’s not unusual in human nature to see people pay more attention to the negative impacts and those who lose out from any policy than those who benefit.”

And election analyst Sir John Curtice, professor of politics at the University of Strathclyde, says that given it is now a national conversation, a backlash against LTNs may be felt by Tory candidates in Conservative areas that had trialled them buoyed by Boris Johnson’s early championing of the scheme.

However, data gathered by Ipsos Mori also suggests that in the wider political context – with the pressure of rising cost of living and concern about the health of the NHS – the issue isn’t an election-winning one. All these issues, and broader existential matters such as the sense that it’s “time for a change”, poll more highly on voters’ lists of concerns.

Ipsos Mori Global chief executive Ben Page told i that, in his estimation, the campaign on scrapping LTNs could secure “the core vote in a few places, but is not something that is going to reverse a 20-point Labour lead”.

title: Rishi Sunak condemning public to cold homes and polluted air, says heat pump industry
lead: Sources at major installers and manufacturers told i that the 2035 ban on gas boilers, which has now been scrapped, was not actually a major issue for the industry but that removing it sent completely the wrong message
author: Daniel Capurro

body.text: British heat pump companies have reacted with dismay to , even as he announced more generous grants for installing the technology.
Industry insiders also , saying that obvious ways to boost the industry and reduce costs for consumers remained stalled.

Chris Norbury, chief executive of E.on UK, accused Mr Sunak of “condemning people to  that are expensive to heat, in cities clogged with dirty air from fossil fuels, missing out on the economic regeneration this ambition brings.”

Sources at major installers and manufacturers told i that the 2035 ban on gas boilers, which has now been scrapped, was not actually a major issue for the industry but that removing it sent completely the wrong message.

One senior industry figure told i that while it would not change the economics of getting a , it could undermine people’s confidence. The public still grumbles about the last Labour government promoting diesel cars, only for them to turn out to be more polluting, the source said.
“This won’t affect people’s spreadsheet calculations, but it might make them worry that the Government will backtrack on support,” they said.

As well as putting off consumers, the industry insiders said the uncertainty created by the Prime Minister’s rhetoric was likely to drive investors elsewhere, leaving the UK importing green technology rather than creating skilled, well-paid jobs.
Heat pump and  prices are falling rapidly, but the UK is competing with the United States, the EU and China for manufacturers and expertise.

“The UK risks minimising the creation of the jobs and the economic upside that would come from the green transition, and it would just become a problem for our balance of payments,” James Murray, cofounder of the Net Zero Festival and editor of BusinessGreen, told i.
One industry source said Mr Sunak’s rhetoric would “turn investors cold” and called trying to compete with heavily subsidised EU and US companies while the UK Government equivocates “quite scary”.

Mr Norbury said of the policy shift: “This is a mis-step on many levels. From a business perspective, companies wanting to invest in the UK need long term certainty to create the jobs and economic prosperity the country needs.”
While Mr Sunak scrapped the 2035 ban, he did announce a 50 per cent increase in the amount of money available under the Boiler Upgrade Scheme for households wishing to buy a heat pump.

The grant will now be worth £7,500, meaning the cost of installing a heat pump could be as little as £500. Octopus Energy announced last week that its latest generation of heat pumps could be installed in a three-bed semi-detached home for £8,000.

However, industry insiders said that the original grant was already generous and other policy changes would have been more effective. For example, green levies fall exclusively on electricity, a legacy from Britain’s era of coal-dominated generation.

The Government previously promised to switch them to gas, but subsequently put the decision out to consultation. Enacting the policy would make heat pumps substantially cheaper to run than a gas boiler in most circumstances.

title: From electric cars to gas boilers – the four green policies Rishi Sunak is considering weakening
lead: In a speech this week the Prime Minister is set to outline a major rowback on several green policies
author: Alannah Francis

body.text: Rishi Sunak is  to ensure they are “proportionate”, in a move that has drawn sharp criticism from across the political spectrum and campaigners.
On Wednesday morning, Home Secretary Suella Braverman denied the Government was .
But in a speech this week  is set to outline a major rowing back on several green policies.

Ms Braverman told Sky News that ministers remain “absolutely committed” to delivering on . She added: “Fundamentally, we’re not going to save the planet by bankrupting the British people.”Here are seven green policies the Government is considering watering down.
A delay on the  is expected to be announced.
It is currently set to be implemented by 2030, in line with what has been Government policy since 2020. However new plans would push this back to 2035.
Ian Plummer, commercial director at online vehicle marketplace Auto Trader, described such a delay as “hugely retrograde”.
He said: “Pushing back the 2030 ban on new petrol and diesel sales by five years is a hugely retrograde step which puts politics ahead of net-zero goals.

“This U-turn will cause a huge headache for manufacturers, who are crying out for clarity and consistency, and it is hardly going to encourage the vast majority of drivers who are yet to buy an electric car to make the switch.”

Mike Hawes, chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), said a delay in the ban on the sale of new conventionally fuelled cars could cause drivers to delay switching to electric vehicles.

He told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme: “We’re trying to understand what is going to happen next between this sort of statement [on the 2030 ban] and that policy, and the message it sends consumers which must be incredibly confusing.”
Another key green policy that the Prime Minister is considering weakening, according to documents seen by , is the plan to phase out the installation of gas boilers.
Under existing plans, gas boiler installations are due to be wound down by 2035, but it is expected the Government will now only want 80 per cent to be phased out by that year.
David Cowdrey, director of external affairs at the MCS Foundation, which calls for the widespread adoption of renewable energy, said a relaxation of current plans would send the wrong message.

Mr Cowdrey said: “The potential move to relax the ban on gas boilers by 2035 could severely undermine the confidence of heat pump manufacturers, heating engineers, and homeowners, as well as the Government’s own target on heat pumps.

“A failure to follow through on the promise to phase out gas heating by 2035 could mean higher bills for consumers, continued dependence on polluting fossil fuels, and sends the wrong message to the economy.”

Homeowners and landlords are set to be told there will now not be any new energy efficiency regulations for homes. The Government had been considering issuing fines to landlords who fail to upgrade their properties to a particular standard of energy efficiency.

The Government had targeted off-grid boilers which use fuel such as oil, petroleum or solid fuels – as these produce high greenhouse gas emissions. However there has been criticism that such a fast ban could make fuel poverty worse, especially in rural areas, where such system are more likely to be used and would have to be replaced.The ban is now set to be delayed until 2035, with a target of only 80 per cent of off-grid boilers to be phased out by this time.
Meanwhile, Britons are reportedly set to be told there will be no new taxes to discourage flying and no government policies to alter people’s diets.

The Government had also reportedly been looking at a household recycling scheme that would have featured seven bins – six for recycling and one for general waste – but Mr Sunak is likely to rule out what he considers burdensome recycling policies, the BBC reported.
Shadow climate and net zero secretary Ed Miliband, said: “This is a complete farce from a Tory Government that literally does not know what they are doing day to day.
“Thirteen years of failed energy policy has led to an energy bills crisis, weakened our energy security, lost jobs, and failed on the climate crisis.”

Green Party MP Caroline Lucas, said: “This is pure political game-playing from Sunak, but all of us will pay the price. Delaying energy efficiency measures will mean higher bills and more emissions. Delaying green investment will mean fewer jobs and less prosperity. Delaying petrol ban will mean dirtier air. What a farce.”

Liberal Democrat climate and energy spokesperson Wera Hobhouse said: “What Rishi Sunak should see in front of him is the opportunity to embrace the industries of the future and protect the coming generations from the catastrophic impacts of climate change.
“Instead, he has cowered to the delayers and deniers like the disgraced Liz Truss and adopted wholesale their policies.”

Conservative MP Chris Skidmore, the former chairman of the UK government’s net-zero review, said: “Rishi Sunak still has time to think again and not make the greatest mistake of his premiership, condemning the UK to missing out on what can be the opportunity of the decade to deliver growth, jobs and future prosperity.”
There has been some support for Mr Sunak’s reported plans to dilute his net zero commitments. Tory MP for Lincoln Karl McCartney welcomed the expected policy changes.

“For a long time I have been calling on the Government to take the common sense decision to delay its planned 2030 ban on the sale of new petrol and diesel cars. Just as countries like France and Germany have done. I am pleased the Government has seen the light,” he said in a statement.

title: HS2: Rishi Sunak suggests northern rail links will be boosted in fresh hint line will be scrapped
lead: Prime Minister faced a barrage of questions over the future of the high speed rail line
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: has given his strongest hint to date that the Government’s rail improvements could be refocused on boosting links across the North rather than .
In a round of often tense interviews with regional radio stations, the Prime Minister repeatedly refused to commit to delivering the future phases of the high-speed rail link beyond .

When pressed on the future of the trainline, he chose to raise the importance of improving speeds and capacity on train journeys from Liverpool to Hull, under the proposed , which he claimed would “drive growth most”.

“East-west, west-east connectivity across northern towns and cities is important,” he said. “I’ve said it for years. Now I’m over on the east side of the North. I know that that connectivity across the Pennines is not good enough. And it’s not just Liverpool to Manchester, it’s all the way across the North.”

“And that is probably the thing that will drive the most growth, create the most jobs if we can get that right. And that’s why we are investing in doing that. But we obviously need to do more, go further, but having greater frequency, greater capacity and shorter journey times all the way from Liverpool, all the way over to the east coast is actually I think the thing that will make the biggest difference to unlocking the massive potential across the North.”
Mr Sunak repeatedly refused to commit to delivering the future phases of HS2 beyond Birmingham and cast doubts on whether it will .
A decision on the rail link was expected this week, but the backlash to suggestions portions of it could be scrapped has meant an announcement is now more likely in November.

While Mr Sunak did not deny that the later phases of the new rail link were under review, he declined on several occasions to say they would go ahead, opting instead to talk of the need to connect all northern towns and cities, fix potholes and improve roads.
When asked about the future of HS2, he has said the Government is always making sure “we get value for money”.
Speaking to BBC Radio Manchester, the Prime Minister said: “I’m not speculating on future things. We’ve got spades in the ground right now, we’re getting on…”

“I think what people also should know because I know there’s a lot of focus on this one thing but actually, one of the journeys that people use most in Greater Manchester or across the North, it’s in their cars right now…”
Asked by BBC Three Counties Radio what the point was of a HS2 service stopping at Old Oak Common railway station, which is “closer to Brentford than Trafalgar Square”.
The Prime Minister said: “Old Oak Common is on the new Elizabeth line and actually the connections to most London destinations are very strong.
“Obviously it’s a new station that people will not be familiar with but its connectivity to all those areas is very strong.”

title: Labour U-turns on plans to end private schools’ charitable status but will still impose 20% VAT charge
lead: U-turn comes after i revealed earlier this week that Labour will roll out VAT on private schools immediately and in full if it wins the general election
author: Poppy Wood

body.text: has U-turned on its pledge, but said it will still apply 20 per cent to school fees if the party wins , i can reveal.
Ending the tax breaks enjoyed by private schools is one of Labour’s flagship policies, and the party has stated for several years that it would do so partly by ripping up their charitable status.

The move was put forward by  in a House of Commons debate as recently as January this year. She said that Labour MPs “agree” that “charitable status for most private schools is something that should come to an end”.
However, senior party sources told i that Labour has now scrapped the policy and that the party will only look to apply VAT to private schools if it enters No 10.

On Wednesday, Labour formally confirmed the U-turn after questioning from i. In a statement, a spokesperson for the party said: “Our policy remains. We will remove the unfair tax breaks that private schools benefit from, to fund desperately needed teachers and mental health counselling in every secondary school.

“This doesn’t require removing charitable status, however, driving high and rising standards for every child against the backdrop of a broken economy requires political choices. Labour isn’t afraid to make them.”
The U-turn comes after i revealed earlier this week that Labour will  if it wins the general election, rather than “phasing it in” over several years.

Under current law, independent schools can be recognised as charities if they demonstrate that they make provision for those of “modest means” to attend – usually through scholarships and bursaries. Charitable status means private schools do not have to pay tax on their annual profits, and grants them other tax breaks including business rates relief on buildings.

New legislation would have to be passed for independent schools to lose their charitable status. Doing so would require a statutory change to the legal definition of “charity”, which would possibly pose wider implications for the charity sector.

However, the party could still impose VAT on private schools without stripping them of their charitable status, and this could be achieved much more quickly. The House of Commons enjoys “financial privilege” which allows MPs to decide public taxes and public spending.

i understands that Labour will make further changes to ensure private schools are forced to pay business rates on buildings even if they keep their charitable status if the party enters No 10. It is unclear whether they would still benefit other tax breaks such as Gift Aid and income tax relief.

Liz Brownsell, the head of charities at law firm Birketts, told i private schools would likely still benefit from “relief from corporation tax [and] capital gains tax”, but that the “impact of a change in VAT status would vary enormously depending on the specific circumstances of each school”.
“It’s difficult to assess the potential impact for independent schools if they were to retain their charitable status but become required to charge VAT on school fees,” she said.

“It’s also quite possible that a Labour government might seek to strip independent schools of other tax reliefs that are generally available to charities, even if they do not seek to remove charitable status itself.”

In July last year, Baroness Chapman of Darlington, Labour’s then-shadow education spokesperson, said “charitable status gives private schools around 80 per cent relief on their business rates and saves a school like Eton more than £500,000 a year”.
Sources within the sector told i there were questions over the legality of stripping schools of their charitable status that may have led Labour into changing its plans.
“One could take months, the other could take years,” one source said, adding that ending the charitable status of private schools could also be subject to legal challenge.
The Independent Schools Council also told i that it would “set a worrying precedent that any charity seen as not reflecting the political ideology of the day could be subject to additional taxes”.
Labour MPs have repeatedly said the party would axe the charitable status enjoyed by around half of all private schools, which would require a law change.

In an Opposition Day Debate on the fair taxation of schools earlier this year, Alex Cunningham, the Labour MP for Stockton North, said: “The Tories crashed the economy, so I support those on my front bench in their commitment to create funds by removing charitable status from private schools and from other pots where they can find that money.”
has also stated on several occasions that the party would strip private schools of their charitable status if he becomes prime minister.

In a speech setting out Labour’s vision for government in Gateshead last summer, he said: “When I say we are going to pay for kids to catch up at school, I also say it’ll be funded by removing private schools’ charitable status.”

And in an interview with the Sunday Mirror in 2021, he said: “Labour wants every parent to be able to send their child to a great state school. But improving them to benefit everyone costs money. That’s why we can’t justify continued charitable status for private schools.”
Private schools have argued  which help widen access.

One leading private school headteacher, speaking to i anonymously, said Labour’s plans to end tax breaks for independent schools would force them to make cost cuts elsewhere to avoid passing on higher fees to parents.

Julie Robinson, the chief executive of the Independent Schools Council, told i: “If Labour takes away the tax relief associated with charitable status for independent schools, the policy would create a two-tier system within the charity sector, setting a worrying precedent that any charity seen as not reflecting the political ideology of the day could be subject to additional taxes.
“We would love to work with Labour to build more effective ways to achieve our shared goal of improving education for all young people.”

title: Labour tax plan for VAT on private schools is popular but not a voter priority, polls say
lead: According to recent polling data, 49% of adults agreed private schools should lose tax exemptions, compared with 11% who disagree
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: ’s plan to  is popular across the political spectrum, but unlikely to sway voters, pollsters have said.
party intends to remove the 20 per cent tax exemption for private schools within the first year of being elected into government.
According to recent polling data from YouGov, 49 per cent of adults agreed private schools should lose tax exemptions, compared with 11 per cent who disagree.
This figure – published on 4 September – was higher among voters in the North of England, rising to 52 per cent.
Polling by Redfield & Wilton last year revealed 62 per cent of all voters support Labour’s plan – including 51 per cent of those who voted Conservative in 2019.
Research director at Redfield & Wilton, Philip van Scheltinga, said the policy has been popular since it was announced.
But he warned that this support would not be enough to win over voters in Labour target seats in so-called areas, where the priorities are “cost of living and the economy, followed by the NHS”.
The policy would not necessarily bring voters to Labour – or turn them away – he said, but instead could indicate more broadly that Labour is prepared to raise certain taxes.

“When Labour first announced the plans last November, Redfield & Wilton Strategies polling showed the policy was considerably popular. Even 51 per cent of 2019 Conservative voters supported the policy,” he told i.
“In a country in which the vast majority send their children to state schools, it is not hard to see why this policy has been well received.
“Ordinary families that Labour are trying to reach struggle to understand why private schools should have charitable status during a cost of living crisis.”
Polling expert and political professor Dr Will Jennings agreed the issue would not necessarily sway undecided voters.
But he said it could indicate how “bold” Labour is prepared to be if elected.
“I don’t think it’s likely to be a big issue for Labour. The number of voters affected is small and most are unlikely to be swing Labour voters,” he said.
“As ever the potential for it to matter is more to do with the wider message it sends about how radical Labour might be in power, and whether it conflicts with aspiration.
“But given the current economic context I am not sure that there is a lot of potential for it to resonate.”
Former Labour leader and prime minister Gordon Brown said he backed the plan to add VAT to private schools and said he had considered doing the same as PM.

Speaking on Times Radio, he said: “You’ve got to have a very good argument about why private schools should be exempt from the VAT. We don’t exempt most other things from value added tax, and it’s what we might have done when we were in government and certainly looked at it at the time.
“I think probably this is the right time to do this. It raises some money which allows us to invest in education for the rest of the community.
“And of course, it is regularising a situation where you’ve got a particular item of expenditure that is exempt from VAT without any proper justification for that happening.”

title: Conservatives close the gap on Labour in ‘Red Wall’ seats but still on course to lose, poll says
lead: A survey by Redfield & Wilton Strategies showed the Tories were likely to lose nearly every single Red Wall constituency
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: ‘s lead in the has shrunk to its lowest level in more than a year in a  – although the Opposition remains far out in front in the key seats.
Redfield & Wilton Strategies carried out a survey of the 40 seats which the Conservatives  for the first time in at least a decade.

The Tories currently hold the support of 31 per cent of voters in the constituencies, with Labour on 45 per cent. Reform UK is third on 10 per cent, followed by the Liberal Democrats and Greens on 6 per cent each.
The 14-point lead for Labour would allow the party to win back almost all of the seats if replicated at – wiping out the Tory majority in Parliament.

But it is two points less than the last Redfield & Wilton poll of the Red Wall, and the smallest lead since August 2022 – shortly before Liz Truss became prime minister and the Conservatives’ polling position began to collapse.
It comes after Mr Sunak announced a  in a move designed to show that he has a plan for long-term change which can relieve pressure on the cost of living.
The polling found a narrowing of the gap between the Prime Minister and on which is best placed to lead the party, but the Labour leader is still ahead by 42 per cent to 36.
And support for the Government’s cost of living policies has hit a new high at 32 per cent, with the proportion of people criticising its actions falling to 57 per cent.
Labour nonetheless leads on every single policy area except the UK’s response to the war in Ukraine, with double-digit leads on key areas such as the NHS and education.
Redfield & Wilton said: “Despite a slight improvement, the overall polling outlook is still dire for the . All the numbers still broadly point towards Labour.

“If our voting intention result were repeated at the next election, it would still represent a dramatic turnaround from December 2019, when Labour finished almost nine points behind the Conservatives in the Red Wall, and it would be enough for Labour to win back most, if not all, of these seats.”

Mr Sunak and his colleagues are widely seen as prioritising the Red Wall with the Tories braced for losses to the Lib Dems in their traditional heartlands and Labour wins in classic swing areas such as Milton Keynes, Plymouth and Reading.

title: Labour could be forced to accept Rishi Sunak’s plans to scrap northern leg of HS2, sources say
lead: Party would not be willing to commit to such massive spending in an election year, and could focus on delivering Northern Powerhouse Rail instead
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: A Labour government could be forced to accept any decision to  and instead focus on delivering an  should Rishi Sunak press ahead with plans to scrap the high-speed line, i understands.
The , business leaders and regional politicians after he refused to guarantee that  or terminate in central London.

But senior Labour sources have said that their hands would be tied if Mr Sunak pushes on with any proposals to ditch the high speed line beyond Birmingham, and the party would be forced to focus on delivering in full. This would be links from Liverpool to Hull and then to Newcastle and York.

“I suspect our thinking will be if we don’t commit fully to it [HS2], then we will commit to the east and west line, which does mean building part of HS2 around Manchester Airport to the city centre,” a senior Labour source told i.
“If they [the Conservatives] say they are going to cut it, then they’ll just say where will we find the £140bn – or whatever it will cost – to build it.

“We can’t afford that six months before an election. As much as I want this project, I also want a Labour government. There’s lots of things we can say that are positive about east-west connectivity – jobs, investment and apprenticeships,” the source added.
Such a move would be likely to be supported by the increasingly powerful Manchester Metro Mayor, , the insider said, as it would deliver on his central demand of improved transport for the North.
It would be highly controversial, however, and rail industry insiders have raised significant doubts over the viability of building NPR without delivering the phase 2 leg of HS2.

According to the rail industry, 40 per cent of the track laid as part of phase 2b, which runs from Crewe to Manchester, will be used by NPR, which sources said would include some of the most costly and technical aspects of delivering the east to west line via south Manchester.

The Department for Transport’s own business case for the later stages of HS2 said all alternatives to the Crewe to Manchester spur have been examined and were deemed “incompatible” with NPR. The document added that ditching HS2 phase 2b “would require a complete redesign of the NPR scheme”.
It is understood any reworking of the scheme would likely delay the NPR for several years.
Labour has yet to say what its official position is on HS2, stating that it wants to see the train line delivered but that it has to see the finances.

Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh has written to the Prime Minister raising concerns that Mr Sunak has become “alarmed” by the rising cost of HS2 given his previous roles as chancellor and chief secretary to the Treasury.

“It is under your direct watch that the cost of HS2 has reportedly almost trebled,” Ms Haigh writes. “The National Audit Office has found that HS2 “cost increases may not have been necessary” if risks had been “recognised and managed earlier” by the Government.

“And, as chancellor, you agreed revised funding for Phase One of: ‘£44.6 billion, including £5.6 billion of contingency to be held by HS2 Ltd and £4.3 billion of other contingency to be held by government’.”
She adds: “Please can you confirm that you personally, as chancellor, approved the revised funding on the basis of an uncosted programme?”

title: Speaker’s fury at Sunak over HS2 and net zero announcements could lead to parliamentary reform
lead: Ministers could be prevented from making major policy announcements when the House of Commons is not sitting
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Ministers could be prevented from making major policy announcements when the House of Commons is not sitting after Rishi Sunak’s U-turn on  and possible scrapping of the .
The Prime Minister sparked fury from the Commons Speaker  last week when he revealed during recess that he was pushing back the date of the ban on new petrol and diesel cars from 2030 to 2035.
Sir Lindsay is also expected to issue a similar rebuke if, as expected, Mr Sunak scraps or delays the HS2 Birmingham to Manchester leg after .
The Speaker has no powers to recall Parliament under these circumstances, and can only do so on instruction from the Government.
But a spokeswoman for Sir Lindsay said any change in the rules on recall could be made by Parliament, following consideration by the Commons Procedure Committee.
If Mr Sunak makes a second major policy announcement while the House is in recess, it is likely to fuel calls for the Procedure Committee to look at changing the rules on recall.

The  Party has said it would always put Parliament first when significant decisions were being announced if they were in government, but a source said a possible rule change to protect future parliaments could be looked at.
Sir Lindsay wrote to Mr Sunak expressing dismay that MPs had not had the opportunity to debate the net zero U-turn.

A spokeswoman for the Speaker’s Office said: “If the Government doesn’t proactively explain its policy on HS2, Mr Speaker will do what he can to ensure the House gets to consider it at the earliest opportunity.”
This could involve the granting of an Urgent Question when the Commons returns after the current conference break on 16 October.
Asked about the issue of recall, the spokeswoman added: “It is a matter for the House to determine any change in the recall rules, probably after consideration by the Procedure Committee.”

Shadow Leader of the House of Commons Lucy Powell said: “There is no clearer illustration of Rishi Sunak’s weakness than the fact that the Prime Minister is flailing around making policy shifts after putting Parliament into recess. He’s running scared of his divided Party with piecemeal plans that don’t stand up to scrutiny.
“Whilst the Conservatives trash our democracy and damage the standing of Parliament, Labour respects the role of MPs in holding the Government to account on behalf of the public.”

title: The middle class can’t afford a hike in private school taxes – state schools already risk being overrun
lead: There’s a good chance state schools up and down the country need to prepare for an influx – but not necessarily because of Labour’s policy
author: Ed Dorrell

body.text: Critics will tell you that if , thousands upon thousands of students will be forced out of independent schools and into the state sector. They say that, as a result, the £1.6bn that Keir Starmer’s people think such a policy will raise in tax receipts simply won’t happen.
Private schools themselves insist that their mums and dads  (promised almost overnight if Labour win) and that many will immediately pull the emergency cord and hoick their offspring off to.

There is a lot of debate about this, with projections varying wildly – and in truth we really don’t know what would happen. There are too many variables. They include how much of the 20 per cent the independent schools would actually pass onto parents and the willingness and ability of parents to pay it. We simply don’t have the foggiest.
Even if we did, though, I strongly suspect we’re actually looking in the wrong place.

I do think there’s a very significant chance that primaries and secondaries up and down the country need to prepare for an influx from the independent sector but it’s not for the reasons we might imagine. It is actually, as with much in our public life today, about the cost of living.

For many of those that pay for education, school fees come out of the same place as mortgage repayments: their post-tax income. And, in case you’ve been living in the moon, mortgage repayments for , in some cases doubling or more.

There will surely be private-school parents in their tens of thousands staring down the barrel of a remortgage in the next few months and thinking that they simply won’t be able afford the school fees anymore. Why pay when there’s a free one around the corner?

I run a lot of focus groups on all manner of subjects across lots and lots of social grades, and recently those that feature middle-class participants have got bleaker and bleaker. The middle classes in this country – including both those who send their kids to private schools, and those who aspire to – are feeling very nervous about their financial circumstances.

The threat of interest rates rising is making them worried about their futures. First the weekly shop moves from , then the two weeks in the south of France are binned. Next up? My bet is that independent schools will become the latest victim of Britain’s middle class austerity epidemic.

The independent sector is fond of pointing out their schools and their parents are much more normal than the stereotypes suggest – and who make sacrifices to pay the school bill. These are the very people for whom an interest-rate increase will leave floundering.

And it’s also worth noting that state schools are, on average, better than they’ve ever been. Both Ofsted data and exam results show – concrete roofs and funding cuts notwithstanding – a system that is competing with most “normal” independents. For many, the marginal benefits of private schooling has been shrinking for some time, a fact that will come into sharp focus as disposable income goes up in smoke.

Of course, if VAT is slapped on school fees by an incoming Starmer administation, there is a significant risk that some private school parents will make the decision to switch sectors, but my bet is that even before a Labour election victory makes that possibility a reality, the threat of repossession will have forced may fee-paying homeowners to squeeze their educational belts already.
In middle-class England the financial pips are squeaking, even before Labour’s tax man comes calling.
Ed Dorrell is a director at Public First and a former deputy editor of the Times Educational Supplement
