title: Sandro Tonali needs to stamp his authority on Newcastle after unconvincing start
lead: Tonali has struggled to prove his worth early on after a big-money summer move from AC Milan, but Newcastle need that to change ahead of a tough run of fixtures
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: MILAN – After , a realisation for. They need more from Sandro Tonali if their season is to truly get lift off.

After the qualified success of the San Siro the next fortnight has the potential to make or break Newcastle’s campaign. They have steadied the ship after three successive defeats, getting back to basics with a couple of clean sheets, but will be expected to win at relegation favourites  on Sunday.

Then it’s  in the, a competition they have aspirations of winning. is threatening to play his “second team” to cope with an injury crisis so it’s far from a write off, even if unbeaten City have swaggered through the season so far.  at home follows before  and Paris Saint German visit St James’ Park, all in the space of a few days. They will either be chasing their tails or chasing their dreams by the end of that run.

It is the sort of pressure Newcastle craved and exactly why they stretched their budget to sign Tonali, who was the most popular man in Milan for 24 hours. There aren’t many supporters who leave the bosom of their boyhood club and actually enhance their reputation .
“One of our own” was what the Curva Sud sang at him and afterwards he reciprocated the praise, telling Sky Sports part of his heart would always belong to Milan.

Perhaps the most uncomfortable chunk of the day for him came in the 72 minutes between his name being sung and the standing ovation from all four corners of the ground. Whisper it quietly, but here was another game in black and white that seemed to largely pass him by.

When the visiting North East press corps discussed it, a local reporter’s eyes widened in disbelief at the criticism. But the rolling debate on Tyneside is whether Tonali as part of a midfield three works in the club’s current engine room set up, especially as it seems to have also dimmed the influence of Bruno Guimaraes, asked to mop up in a sort of hybrid holding midfielder role.

A stat flashed up midway through the first half that told its own story. Tonali had the second fewest touches of any player in the game (20). Milan’s underemployed goalkeeper Mike Maignan was the only one behind him with 18.

Howe loved his defensive discipline and game IQ, pointing out that he managed the emotion of his return well. But Newcastle did not spend £55m to make him the most expensive Italian footballer in history simply to operate on the margins. When the big games arrive this autumn, they need him to affect matches more.

Tonali was honest enough at the start of the week to say he has struggled in the early stages of his Newcastle career, and not just because he ended up supping in Wetherspoons after a tongue-in-cheek recommendation from his new teammates. He is said by dressing room insiders to be a quiet character, displaying his authority on the field rather than be raging behind-closed-doors.

There was some surprise on Tyneside that he went straight into the team when other big money signings have been integrated gradually. But having taken a big punt on Tonali – and it was Howe who drove the deal – he clearly thought he couldn’t afford to keep him wrapped in cotton wool.
While Tonali is still clearly settling in at St James’ Park – the club have laid on an interpreter to help him acclimatise – it is the system that probably needs tweaking.

A 4-2-3-1, utilised last season with some success, might draw more from Tonali and Guimaraes. Perhaps the return of the underrated Joe Willock might also help, for he is that special kind of player who combines the unfussy, underappreciated mopping up midfield work with the art of darting into the opposition penalty area from deep.

Howe praised Tonali’s performance and mentality in Milan, saying he “represented himself well”. But then he perhaps betrayed his true feelings with the admission that: “I know there’s more to come from him.”
With such big games on the horizon for Newcastle, it needs to arrive sooner rather than later.

title: French transport puts the UK to shame – I travelled 1,809 miles on 8 trains, 3 trams and 2 buses to prove it
lead: Watching three rugby matches in four days across three different cities would have been so much harder in Britain
author: James Gray

body.text: The is a two-month long festival of the game that will criss-cross France before converging on Paris for the final on Saturday 28 October.

Many fans, especially those who have travelled from the southern hemisphere, will take the opportunity to take in a couple of matches and enjoy the culture of France. So to get the full experience, I set myself a challenge: visit four different French cities in four days and watch as many rugby matches as I could, without ever getting behind the wheel of a car.
I have prepared for today’s trip by  and rewarding myself by making sure Paris still does a good bottle of red wine (it does).

As such, I am a little bleary-eyed as I get on the metro, and fail to notice that the 2 line is “disrupté”. I get as far as Pigalle before having to speed-walk past the Moulin Rouge and down Boulevard de Clichy, a place I have never seen in daylight hours. It’s a bit more pleasant this side of 6pm.

Anyway, I make it to Gare du Nord in time for a Red Bull and a croissant before boarding a 17-car, double-decker train. Now, not to bore you about trains, but they use a wider gauge in Europe that means the trains themselves are wider, and a thousand times more comfortable too. They are quick too; a neat tracker on the (free and reliable) WiFi hub tells me we are doing almost 200 miles an hour at our fastest, which helps us complete a journey the equivalent of London to Cardiff in just 67 minutes.

The train is not exclusively France fans, but there are plenty already showing their colours and there are still 10 hours until kick-off. In England, I would fear for their ability to drink all the way through. What’s the French for “stamina”? (I believe it is “moderation”.)

By 7pm, I realise I have underestimated the French propensity to binge drink. The concourse outside the Stade Pierre Mauroy is rammed with fans in cockerel hats or berets and Le Tricolore painted on their faces, signing La Pena Baiona, an anthem sung by fans of Top 14 side Bayonne but that has been adopted by rugby fans all over France. Few seem to know all the words, or if they did at midday, have long forgotten them.

The atmosphere inside the stadium is similarly riotous, and the revised accompaniment for Le Marseillaise goes down a storm. (Tournament organisers were hammered in the first week for the butchered versions of the anthems that were being used in stadiums.)
The rugby is thrilling too, albeit scrappy. A French second XV give  far too many chances and there was only a point in it with 25 minutes to go, but the home side do bag two more tries to win 27-12.

In the press conference, Uruguay captain Andres Vilaseca tells the world his nation have shown they can hold their own with the best, and they deserve to do so more often. He is right; they have played just one tier-one nation in four years.

On the metro back into town, slurring French fans tell me it was unpleasant to watch. I point it was a “very French” effort to follow up beating the All Blacks with a shock defeat, and they laugh. “We play rugby the English way now,” they retort, a reference to their weighting forward pack and ability to grind out wins.

A generous 12pm check-out time allows me a casual morning after getting back at 2am, and I . He tells me from Saracens RFC, where he is working with the National Lottery, to “dry my eyes” when I complain about a late finish, clearly still a big rugby fan jealous of my gig. We talk about and the talented Alex Mitchell wearing his old No 9 shirt. I promise to buy him a beer in Nice.

Having hot-footed to the station, I get a call from Paul Gustard, formerly one of the England coaches and now running the defence at Stade Francais. I wanted to talk to him about coaching the tackle height – head shots are the key theme of the Rugby World Cup so far – but we had not been able to connect earlier in the week. So now I find myself doing an interview in, bizarrely, a Westfield shopping centre next to Lille station. We also talk about the game last night and what Lille is like: he is going to bring his son here for , and I tell him to make sure he gets up there early because it’s only a little metro and there were a lot of people on it.

The train back to Paris is a little older than the double-decker from yesterday but still spacious enough: the main frustration is forgetting that the transfer from Gare du Nord to the No 2 line in Paris is a really long walk and it is still baking hot.

I return to my apart-hotel and send my Dawson interview back to England before taking the evening off. A pizza, some vin rouge and a pair of ageing rockers playing 70s hits in a tiny bar called La Grange, named after a ZZ Top song, are my entertainment.

I am still humming an excellent version of Stand By Me from the night before as I fold myself onto the metro and head to Paris Montparnasse. Gare du Nord is technically Europe’s busiest train station, with nearly 300 million passengers in the last year before the pandemic, while Montparnasse handles barely a fifth of that.

Yet Paris’s fourth busiest train station must be the most confusing, with four different departure halls each located in different corners of a labyrinthine shopping centre. They also operate that infuriating system where the platform of departure is a state secret until four minutes before the train leaves, causing a mass rush to the train that feels entirely avoidable.

Anyway we make it to Nantes, France’s sixth largest city with nearly a million people living in the area. Few of them though are rugby fans. Stade Nantais, known as The Elephants, compete in Federale 1, France’s fifth tier, and the World Cup stadium is the football ground, Stade de la Beaujolaire home to FC Nantes, who play in green and yellow. There is a lot less yellow than green in town, because Nantes has been taken over by the emerald wave.

Officially, . Sure enough, players after the 59-16, eight-try win over Tonga describe it as like a home game for the men in green. The anthem is spine-tingling, the performance expectedly brilliant and Tonga are well beaten. Nantes resounds well into the night with “The Fields of Athenry” and the ever-present Pena Baiona.

I spend the morning at the Marche de Talensac, the exact kind of market you expect to find in every French town, complete with overly familiar butchers, rushed-off-their-feet bakers and incomprehensible greengrocers. I grab a pastry and find a local cafe in which to write my follow-up, where there is a couple eating oysters, from the market, with a bottle of Chardonnay. At 11am. What a life.

Typically, my first travel hitch on this voyage comes when I am forced to take a flight. There is no other way to make it from Nantes to Nice on Sunday and while my bus to the airport is fine, I find myself watching the minutes tick by past our scheduled time in a small departure lounge jam-packed with hungover Ireland fans waiting on an Easyjet cure.

I busy myself by examining downloaded footage of Ireland’s tries from last night and pretending I am Rassie Erasmus, plotting how to shut down Sexton and co. The sight of deputy No 8 Caelan Doris charging into contact and regular starter Jack Conan stalking the touchline, itching to get back to full fitness, would fill me with dread were I planning to take the Irish on next Saturday.

A surprising number are joining me on the south coast for England’s clash with Japan, and once we do finally board it makes for a very quiet flight as row after row succumbs to “the nods” – but once everyone has woken up again the rose starts flowing and the pre-match excitement is nascent once again. The six blokes behind me shame my endeavours by revealing they were in Toulouse on Friday as well and are heading to their fourth game of the weekend. Fair play, chaps. I hope you gave sleepy Dave his other shoe back.

My flight lands about 40 minutes late and I have a tight turnaround to make the match. An eight-minute taxi from Nice airport costs me an eye-watering 40 Euros – “it’s because it’s Sunday,” is the line the opportunistic driver spins me when I puff my cheeks out – and I check into the hotel as quickly as possible to forget the rip-off.

I am a guest of Asahi this evening, the official beer of the Rugby World Cup, and my hosts lay on dinner by the beach, transport, tickets to the big game and of course some of their product. There’s nothing they can do about the swelteringly humid conditions though and we leave the stadium about as sweaty as England’s players after .
I finish my trip with a lengthy TGV from Nice back to Paris, which feels like it might be miserable judging by the scrum at the station.

However, on the other side of the three electronic gates is another enormous double-decker which can hold far more people than Nice could ever allow through, it seems. Once boarded, it is spacious, air-conditioned and relaxed. The only frustration is there appears to be no cafe and all I have is a bag of peanuts, which I resolve to ration for the six-hour journey.

Six hours sounds like a long time, but it is a long way: Nice to Paris is just under 600 miles. There basically isn’t a UK train journey I can compare it to because our country isn’t big enough, but London to Edinburgh is a 400-mile journey and takes five hours on a good day.

I arrive at Gare de Lyon and am back at my suburban aparthotel with a vin rouge within 35 minutes, thanks to Paris’s slightly disconcerting (the doors often open before the train has stopped) but extensive metro system.

So, what have I learned from my sojourn around western Europe’s largest country? Firstly, that France’s wide-gauge, double-decker air-conditioned trains are a world apart from the converted coaches and 1990s hand-me-downs that crawl around the British network. If I tried to do this in the UK, I might barely have seen one match, never mind three.

And secondly, the Olympics are here next year. Paris will host most of the events but the Olympiad will also reach Lille, Nantes, Bordeaux, Marseille and Lyon. There will be plenty of things to complain about – there always is at an event so mammoth – but the transport will not be one of them.

title: Rugby World Cup 2023: Eddie Jones has created his own version of ‘Warrenball’ to defeat Gatland’s Wales
lead: A heavyweight Australia will take on a heavyweight Wales in a clash that is likely to be an uncomplicated type of match
author: James Gray

body.text: STADE DE FRANCE — There are a lot of similarities between  and : both rugby obsessives, both divisive characters and both play a brand of rugby that has not always proved popular with fans. They are the ’s two most experienced coaches, this being Gatland’s 26th fixture and Jones’s 20th.
They were also both hired less than a year out from the World Cup by a previous employer to try and fix a team that had fallen apart.
And now they find the other on the opposite touchline with their tournament future on the line.
Jones and Gatland share many similarities in the detail-orientated approach to rugby, which may be why they have both been so successful over the years.
“I will not apologise for pushing the players to the limit to get the best out of them,” Gatland said over the summer when quizzed about Wales’s brutal training camps in Switzerland and Turkey.

Jones meanwhile goes through assistant coaches at a rate of knots, and his Wallabies scrum coach Neal Hatley, one of the precious few to stick around having also worked with him in England, revealed that messages from his boss this week started as early as 4.30am.
This is not a knockout game but it might as well be. A defeat for Australia effectively sends them home, defeat for Wales damages their bid to avoid England in the quarter-finals.
Somewhat surprisingly given the war of words they used to spark when they met during Gatland’s previous spell with Wales and Jones’s with England, the pair seem to be friends.
“I always got on well with Warren,” Jones said on Friday.
“We used to have a curry together when we were coaching in the Six Nations but it’s a little bit different out here. We’re in the middle of nowhere so it’s hard to find where you can get a curry.”
Maybe the Stade de France caterers will sort them out with a midnight feast on Sunday night, but whose meal will taste sweeter?

Much of that may come down to Jones’s decision to bench his young fly-half Carter Gordon in favour of the squad’s “senior” No 10 Ben Donaldson, who is 24 and has five caps. Gordon is 22 and has seven.

“He’s a calm individual which is definitely needed at 10,” said captain David Porecki. A shock defeat to Fiji led to some “honest admissions” within the Australian side and Gordon was one of those to suffer the crook after he was badly at fault for Fiji’s only try, advancing to collect a high ball and then pulling out in confusion to allow the ball to bounce, directly leading to the score.
“With young players you’ve got to have a feel of where they are,” added Jones.
“Sometimes you need to back them, sometimes you need to pull them away a little bit. At the moment we feel like it’s best to pull him away a little bit.”

There is also a tactical shift. Donaldson started the tournament playing at full-back and excelled there in the kicking game. His ability under the high ball must also be a consideration against a Wales team that will kick more than almost any other team in this World Cup – except Australia.

Donaldson of course is a fly-half by trade and made his debut there against Wales last year. On that occasion, Australia went 34-13 down only to score three tries in the last 25 minutes and take a famous 39-34 victory. It proved to be the end of Wayne Pivac and heralded .

In fact, little in rugby is not familiar to Gatland, but taking on Australia under Jones will be a new experience. Their six previous meetings all came in the context of Wales vs England, a match-up the English won four times during the overlap of the two coaches.

How much there is to be learned tactically from those match-ups remains to be seen, but it is true that this Australia team is starting to look like the England team Jones was trying to build. They have one of the biggest forward packs in the tournament, even without 22-stone captain Will Skelton who misses out through injury. Against Wales last autumn they scored two mauling tries and dominated Georgia, usually beasts up front, in their opener three weeks ago.

Behind them, they have reliable boots in Donaldson at 10 and Tate McDermott at scrum-half, whose running game was never in question but whose improvement on his kicking was heavily praised by previous head coach Dave Rennie.
There is more weight outside them too in the shape of centres Samu Kerevi and Jordan Petaia and winger Marika Koroibete, all of whom tip the scale past 15 stone.
It looks like an uncomplicated game plan – and also one that is not dissimilar to “Warrenball”, the term coined by former England attack coach Brian Smith some years ago.

In Gatland’s own words, “Warrenball” is about “getting across the gainline, trying to get front-foot ball and playing to space if that is possible”. To do that, you need players across the pitch who can make strong carries through defenders, as well as a scrum-half who can set a high tempo to use the space that creates.

That approach, combined with a kicking game that keeps the ball in play for longer, draws on the fitness levels built up in those brutal training camps. Combine that with a referee in Wayne Barnes whom both coaches accepted would allow the game to flow from the breakdown more than others – “I’m delighted that Wayne Barnes is reffing it,” said Gatland – and Australia’s heavy pack are expected to tire, which should play into Wales’s hands.
“I don’t think we’ll change our approach,” Gatland said.

“We’ve talked about where we want to attack Australia, in terms of the opportunities that we can potentially exploit. It’s going to be one hell of a game, with not just them being desperate but us being desperate to progress from this pool.”

He added: “[I’ve] come to realise what to expect from an Eddie team. With regards to the way they’re going to play on Sunday, we’ve prepared for a couple of scenarios. They tend to attack the short-side, there’ll be a lot of kicking and they’ll be fairly direct.”

Even if the plan were a secret, there would be little chance of keeping it with George North at 13 and Nick Tomkins inside him, but Wales’s X-factor comes from Louis Rees-Zammit, the 22-year-old firecracker on the wing who is one of only two Welshmen to play every minute of the World Cup so far, and has 182 metres gained and 10 defenders beaten to show for it.

This game will be won and lost by the defences. Wales set a World Cup record in their narrow win over Fiji by making 252 tackles, led by Will Rowlands making a staggering 27 of them from the second row. For context, flanker and co-captain Jac Morgan has played twice as many minutes and made the same number.

Everything points to the experience of Wales, with more than 400 caps, overcoming the Australian youngsters. And Jones is already preparing the ground for it, telling reporters it takes six years to build a World Cup-winning team and that there are “little green shoots” and “good, young players that are really going to be great players”.
Edging out Wales on Sunday would be the first step to greatness for a group of Australians that no one at home is giving much chance.

title: Mack Hansen try helps Ireland outmuscle South Africa in thrilling Rugby World Cup clash
lead: The 2019 champions miss four kicks out of five to go down 13-8 to a resilient Ireland side in an almighty struggle at the Stade de France
author: James Gray

body.text: STADE DE FRANCE — Mack Hansen left  ruing their struggles from the kicking tee as  secured a hard-fought 13-8 victory over the reigning world champions.

Hansen’s try, his side’s only one of the match, virtually secured Ireland’s place in the quarter-finals but more importantly gave them a psychologically huge victory over a side many predict they will face here again in a month’s time with the  on the line.

Ireland weathered the second-half storm created by the arrival of the Springbok “Bomb Squad” of , which did help create Cheslin Kolbe’s 51st-minute try, but two more penalties, both won by the Irish scrum, were enough to earn them a seismic victory.
But South Africa will believe they had enough in the tank to beat the world No 1 side, only for Manie Libbok and Faf de Klerk to leave 11 points on the pitch in missed kicks.
“It was one hell of a game. Ireland brought it to us but I am proud of the boys for sticking in there and giving it our all,” fly-half Libbok said.
“We were unlucky.
“Obviously in a game like this you have to take your points and you have to convert pressure into points. Unfortunately we didn’t get it right.”

Before the Rugby World Cup, Eddie Jones explained that he thought this tournament would be defined by rugby played in short, sharp bursts. If this game was anything to go by  can take up picking the lottery numbers full-time if he gets the sack.

The opening minutes at the Stade de France were exactly that: intense, controlled aggression punctuated by regular stoppages. Rather than frustrate fans though, it gave them the chance to draw breath.

Both teams were keen to make an early statement, with Ronan Kelleher taking the honour of the first bone-crunching hit. In some ways though, that was style over substance as his line-out misfired five times out of 12 in the first half.

The Ireland tacticians were keen to make a statement too, refusing the chance to knock a third-minute penalty between the posts and instead kicking to the corner, only for Kelleher’s struggles to give the ball straight back to South Africa.

Instead it was Manie Libbok who opened the scoring with a sixth-minute penalty, landing the first blow of any meaning, but it was Ireland who finally scored the first knockdown. Mack Hansen crossed over on the right-hand side after Bundee Aki broke out of his own 22 and into the oppositions, following up his Player of the Match performance against Tonga with another barnstormer.

Ireland might have been concerned with surviving the onslaught that they knew was coming the second half from the seven forwards waiting on the bench. Garry Ringrose had gone off for a Head Injury Assessment and also seemed to injure his shoulder after trying to make a tackle on Jesse Kriel, while Johnny Sexton also looked like he might be in trouble after bringing down Damian de Allende.
Exactly how much damage was done to each man’s right shoulder may be a matter for the physios next week but both were able to resume and play key roles in the next 40 minutes of rugby.

And they were needed too because South Africa are not world champions by accident and did come back after half-time renewed. Rassie Erasmus pressed the big red button and sent on “Bomb Squad”  at a prescient moment with a Springbok put-in to the scrum on the Irish line in the offing. They won a strong scrum and Libbok threw a fine long pass wide to Kolbe who finished and had the presence of mind to run it towards the posts and make the kick easier.

But Libbok could not extend the lead, and combined with two long penalty misses from De Klerk, South Africa now have a sub-50 per cent success rate from the tee in this World Cup. They have slotted just 11 of 23 kicks, the worst percentage of any team to have taken at least five kicks in the tournament.

That scrum might have sounded warning bells in the Ireland coaching box, but they did not panic. Andrew Porter stayed on and delivered with a penalty against Frans Malherbe on the hour mark that allowed Sexton an easy kick to regain the lead.

You could sense South Africa’s frustration. Everything they threw at Ireland, Andy Farrell’s men took. Ringrose was winning jackal penalties, Sexton was getting up every time Pieter-Steph du Toit hit him just a bit too late and pushed off him to get up, and James Lowe was making sure the Springboks knew about out every time referee Ben O’Keeffe’s arm went up in his team’s direction.
🗣️"It seemed like there was 800,000"Mack Hansen on the Irish support in Paris! 🇮🇪 |

That said, it did not feel like anyone overstepped the mark. In a game of unquantifiable physicality, where nearly every tackle felt like it might have broken a bone, there were no yellow or red cards, no high tackles and no late tackle penalties. Perhaps the citing commissioner will change that – especially having seen what looks like a stamp on Josh van der Flier’s finger – but in the contact areas, this looked to be a game of the highest quality.
Fittingly, Ireland sealed victory with a kick from another scrum penalty right in front of the posts, Jack Crowley converting easily.

There was one final challenge for Ireland, a line-out on their own five-metre line, but once again they rose to the challenge.  who watched his unit flail on their own ball in the first half, would have smiled with satisfaction as they held up a maul with the weight of 13 South Africans behind it and forced the game-ending scrum.
The World Cup is not won. But this Ireland team must surely begin to believe they have it in them now.

title: I went to Scunthorpe to visit a town whose football club is dying. The situation is beyond grim
lead: The most miserable truth is this: the civil war between the club’s owner and its supporters might be the only thing keeping it alive
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Along one end of Glanford Park’s East Stand, before a section where the stand’s former name is outlined in corrugated iron made conspicuous by the grubbiness that surrounds it, begins a series of banners that detail ’s glory years: Wembley appearances, promotions, landmark cup results. The images are now a little tired, vibrant colour slowly fading into grayscale due to weather and time and experience. Halfway down the stand, one of the doorways by which supporters usually enter has been set up as a temporary resting place by a member of the homeless community.

Walk around to the West Stand, via the back of an away end with boarded-up, club-coloured portable cabins that are bedded in overgrown grass, and you arrive at Scunthorpe United’s entrance. There are shutters over the doors and a notice telling visitors to walk to the club shop instead. The club shop is also closed. On a non-home matchday week, it is open for 24 hours across seven days and never on a Wednesday.

A sign has been affixed to the Britcon Stand, where Scunthorpe United’s most committed supporters have their regular seats. “Proud members of ,” it reads. There is no disclaimer, but maybe there should be: “may not be the opinion of those who pass through these doors”. Above it, clouds are quickly gathering. A yellow weather warning has been issued; a storm is coming. Around here, they can barely remember when the storm last subsided.

A month or so ago, the excellent , a Scunthorpe United fan website, published a season preview that was, finally, gloriously upbeat. “There are lots of signs that this upcoming campaign could be one that signals the rebirth of Scunthorpe United Football Club,” it read. “It certainly makes a change compared to the previous years when we’d be sat here on the eve of a new campaign, hoping for the best but fearing the worst.”

Even by recent standards, it has been a bad eight weeks since. In September, an investigation by The Athletic revealed that Scunthorpe’s owner David Hilton had operated under several different aliases and, in 2015, was sentenced to two years in prison for 15 counts of fraud. That also led to him being disqualified from being a company director for five years.

Several days later, a statement from Hilton was published on the club’s official website in which, among other things, he said that the club was now for sale but that “without me at this time, your club will almost certainly die”. Hilton also invited several supporters groups, including Iron Bru, to a meeting at the club to forge better relationships.

Unfortunately, by this week a number of supporters posted screenshots on social media of an email from the club informing them that they had been issued with banning orders from home games (a club cannot actually issue a banning order, but they can ban supporters from matches). The next morning, the club’s X (formerly known as Twitter) account was deactivated before being restored later the same day.

Hilton was supposed to be the saviour, once. Under previous owner Peter Swann, Scunthorpe had fallen into debt, ignominy and non-league. All the hallmarks of steady decline were present: transfer embargoes, a high turnover of managers, a young team by necessity rather than design, dwindling attendances, local journalists banned from matches. The overarching mood was achingly familiar, the grim sense of inevitability once the good times fade from view and the money runs out.

Swann became deeply unpopular with supporters, who protested against the decline of a fine community club. A dream lived here that has already died. Scunthorpe United spent three seasons in the  around the turn of the last decade. In 2009, they played in Wembley finals twice in the space of two months having scored a last-minute equaliser in their  play-off semi-final. That is the crowning glory of the poster montage on the East Stand.

Those glory years lasted for at least a decade, albeit with slightly diminished returns. But on the first day of 2018, Scunthorpe were fourth in League One having won nine – and lost only one – of their previous 12 league matches. They were drawing away at  and doing the double over  six years ago. Now those two clubs are five and four divisions above them respectively. Supporters never expected to stay in the Championship. All they asked for was a football club to always be there.

Under Swann’s watch – and despite his £20m investment – Scunthorpe tumbled down. He stressed that the club was not living within its means and that, whatever happened, surviving on money they didn’t have would have risked the club’s existence – Scunthorpe were losing approximately £100,000 a month. Then Swann transferred ownership of Glanford Park to Cool Silk, a separate company he owned. The positive spin is that it allowed the club to write off its £11m debt, but supporters feared that their only security blanket, the literal roof over their heads, had been lost.

Inevitably, there were protests. Football supporters are not fools. They can see calamity approaching from the horizon. By October 2021, fans had locked the front gates of Glanford Park before a game against  to display their displeasure. There were pitch invasions. Despite an apology from Swann, supporters were angered by a lack of communication that addressed the slide down the leagues of their beloved club.

So when Hilton bought the club for £3 in January, taking on the debt obligations, they wanted to believe. Relegation to  North – by a margin of 16 points – could not be avoided, but Hilton appointed Jimmy Dean as manager and invested heavily in the playing staff over the summer. Fifteen signings arrived, including recruits from Aberdeen, Bradford, Mansfield, Hearts and Chesterfield. Without the off-field upheaval, Scunthorpe would be comfortable favourites for promotion. If disaster is averted, they still will be.

Since then Scunthorpe have, like far too often over the last half-decade, been plunged into civil war. There are two significant issues at play. Firstly, Glanford Park itself. The ground is owned by Swann but, at the time of selling the club, an agreement had been made for Hilton to pay £3m for the ground and surrounding land. A four-month period of exclusivity was agreed.

During this period, Hilton’s legal team raised concerns about the land’s valuation, its status as a community asset and issues of planning permission and access. He announced grand plans to build a new stadium and then found a loophole solution, a lease agreement that effectively let the club stay at Glanford Park. Swann is receiving 7p a week rent for Scunthorpe’s use of the ground, according to his barrister, and has pursued legal recourse to address what he considers to be trespass and squatting. A trial will take place early in 2024, at which point Scunthorpe United will discover whether they are homeless or not.

“Mr Hilton’s failure to buy the ground and effectively get rid of Mr Swann started to raise questions among supporters over the state of his finances and ability to buy the stadium, car park and training ground thus completing the deal,” says Tony Gosling, a Scunthorpe supporter for over 50 years.

“The team started brightly in National League North playing some great football, scoring goals and winning games. Fans were very much on board with Mr Hilton and what he was trying to accomplish. But rumours over unpaid bills, unpaid wages and pension payments to current staff, former staff and players began to emerge. Some staff left the club altogether and the academy set-up was lost.”

To that, we can now add the hostility between Hilton and the club’s supporters. He is right that this is a perilous financial situation, a sixth-tier football club with significant debt that loses money and has ongoing legal cases costing him thousands of pounds a month. But then none of this could have come as a surprise to Hilton, who committed considerable money on new players in the summer. Supporters i spoke to, who wished to remain anonymous given the recent spate of bans, are suspicious that Hilton is manufacturing the war with fans as a means of self-reassurance as he pursues an exit strategy.

The most miserable truth is this: the civil wars that are killing Scunthorpe United might be the only thing keeping it alive. A former owner that supporters dislike has the stadium; a current owner that supporters mistrust has the club. They dislike and mistrust each other and both seem stubborn enough to see their legal case through to the end.

If Swann wins, Scunthorpe are without a home and Hilton may well walk away. He was the only buyer to step forward in January – is that likely to have changed now, with only more uncertainty? If Hilton wins, the lease situation may continue or Hilton may negotiate a price to buy, but then the events of the last month throw into doubt his suitability as an owner. While both remain financially and emotionally invested, Scunthorpe will at least play on. Glanford Park has become their purgatory.

There is much blame to be apportioned here. To Swann, who oversaw the decline despite his own investment. To Hilton, who had seen how a split between an owner and supporters drags a club down, has failed to avoid the same issues and who should have been transparent about his past before a media outlet uncovered and reported it. And to the game itself, both in the micro and macro landscape. A convicted fraudster has been allowed to own a football club. The funnelling of money towards the financial elite makes life desperately hard for provincial clubs in provincial towns that are suffering far beyond football. The things we consider to be non-negotiable truths, that our clubs and their grounds should be protected as assets of our community, carry no weight in reality.

Make no mistake: this is a cultural tragedy. Scunthorpe is a town of 82,000 people, ranking outside the top 100 in the UK by population. It has the largest steel processing centre in the country, but job losses were announced in February and the town lives under constant fear of more following. In the town ward, 46.4 per cent of children are growing up in poverty. This is an area of the country where locals feel routinely ignored by politicians in Westminster. London may as well be in a different land.

On Scunthorpe United’s Community Sport and Education Trust website, one document details its raison d’etre: “Scunthorpe United Football Club has the ability to engage people, raise hopes, aspirations and improve the lives of the people of North Lincolnshire.” It’s true. A football club’s role in providing Saturday afternoon escapism is obvious, but it is on every other day of the week that the bigger difference is made. It matters more in places like this than anywhere else. If Scunthorpe United dies, a part of the town dies with it and it cannot afford lose much more.

“The town of Scunthorpe needs its football club,” says Gosling. “A football club both sells and promotes an area, it brings weekly national media attention and recognition worldwide from fellow football supporters. A football club bonds people together, puts a place on the map creating interest and if that club is doing well it brings a real feel-good factor and uplift for the whole community.”

It’s hard not to lose faith, whether you’re a supporter of 50 years or an outsider visiting for a day, that a feel-good factor will ever put down roots here again. Go back to those season previews, for therein lies the secret: this is what happens at Scunthorpe United. Hope is made to look foolish. Despair is reinforced as the natural state. Calm is prelude to storm and optimism only makes the eventual fall harder to bear.

To come to Scunthorpe is to visit a town that is in grave danger of suffering a tragic fate: the death of its football club. A new owner is at least supposed to bring with them a fresh start that follows crisis, a parting of the clouds. Scunthorpe United didn’t even get that. There is no magic wand, no obvious benevolent force waiting in the wings for the right moment to strike. Just a ground that is fading away and a club that is fading away slightly faster.

Update: On the morning of Thursday 28 September, Scunthorpe United issued a statement in which they announced that David Hilton had recently notified the Board of Directors of his decision to withdraw his funding from the club moving forward.

The club stressed that, despite contact with numerous parties over potential takeovers, no potential purchasers were looking to move forward. In addition, “an outside company will be bought in to work closely with the club’s creditors to try and ensure all are paid in a timely and professional manner.”Finally, the club will leave Glanford Park after their fixture on October 7 and play their matches at Gainsborough Trinity. Temporarily at least, Scunthorpe will not have its football team.

title: Inside Bruno Guimaraes’ new contract: Newcastle’s ‘happy camp’ policy and a £100m release clause
lead: Newcastle’s owners want to marry smart recruitment with savvy retention of key players to help compete on four fronts
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: There was a theory doing the rounds in some corners of  social media on Wednesday night that the  was fixed.
“Anyone else notice [Don] Goodman looking at the numbers before picking the away balls?” one prominent account asked as Sky’s footage of the draw was picked apart with a forensic eye.

A quick review of the evidence against him seemed to focus mostly on his previous as a Sunderland player. Given that the pot he was picking the balls from was covered by a giant green lid, it is safe to say the case can be closed and Goodman’s integrity remains unblemished.

Newcastle fans should relax – Manchester United at Old Trafford might not be the kindest reward for taking out Manchester City but it is not the daunting draw it once was. Playing as they did against , their aspirations to go one better than last season’s Wembley final failure do not feel all that unrealistic.
After an early season wobble, it feels as if the Magpies are flying again and Wednesday’s victory, a first over City since 2019 and Eddie Howe’s first over Guardiola, felt significant.

True, they may have eyes on global domination this season but the League Cup has carried heft for City in recent years. This was their earliest exit from the competition since 2011 and it was not a team of greenhorns that Guardiola picked, despite his pre-match protestations.

Newcastle’s greatest achievement was that their own understudies looked more than comfortable on the main stage.  certainly looked the part, shackling Jack Grealish superbly on his full debut. For Paul Dummett, playing his first football since a solitary 90 minutes at Tranmere 13 months ago, it was an especially memorable night.

The battle for Newcastle was always going to maintaining the unity and fire that carried them into fourth last season and Eddie Howe’s rotation policy should ensure competitive edge remains, even among those used sparingly. Squad members like Dummett and Jamaal Lascelles have been kept on precisely because their training standards remain high even without the guaranteed reward of first team football.
They will hope that dovetails with a “happy camp” policy that will see the club enter contract negotiations with almost all of their most prominent players over the next 12 months.

The first visible signs of progress on that front centre around Bruno Guimaraes, whose new deal is to be announced imminently. He played the first few weeks as if the ongoing negotiations were weighing heavily on his shoulders.

He is a player who needs to feel the love, which is why Newcastle’s decision to acquiesce to his team’s desire for a release clause in excess of £100m and agree a new long-term contract makes sense. The pay bump is reward for a player who has been a game changer at St James’ Park and as his mood has improved so too have his performances.

Against City his half-time introduction was a statement of intent that ended with an exclamation point as Newcastle followed the lead of their midfield talisman and became more aggressive and more assertive.

For all the debate about how long it will be until someone triggers that clause and takes him from Newcastle, it shouldn’t be forgotten that his current club have ambitions to win things. The sneaking suspicion of the hierarchy is that he feels such a connection he will stay as long as those goals remain attainable.

The “happy camp” approach of Newcastle’s owners is to marry smart recruitment with savvy retention of key players. Guimaraes had plenty of time left on his contract before entering contract talks but a pay rise is a reward for his contribution.

Next up for fresh terms is Joelinton, superb against City. Talks are said by insiders to be “progressing well”. And then in the next 12 months Newcastle are likely to start discussing extending Sven Botman’s contract as Paris Saint Germain and other heavyweights lurk.

title: Everton takeover: 777 Partners ‘confident’ of passing Premier League ownership test despite fans’ concerns
lead: 777 Partners will have to prove to the Premier League they have the funds to provide ‘financial security’ in the long run, an expert tells i
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: ‘s prospective new owners 777 Partners have opened up dialogue with prominent fans and supporters’ groups as they look to assuage concerns .

Since a deal with majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri , the US investors have faced questions about their sources of funding, legal wrangles surrounding some of the companies in their sprawling business empire and also their record in football after the mixed experience of some of the clubs under the 777 umbrella.
i understands 777 remain “confident” of passing , a process they estimate will take around 12 weeks and began with the submission of documents last week.

But they are walking into some scepticism , with Everton’s Fan Advisory Board (FAB) detailing four areas they want reassurances around – including that the group have the funds to provide “financial security to ensure the club runs sustainably”.

Other areas include how they will fund the new stadium project at Bramley-Moore Dock, questions around their multi-club model and the make up of any new board appointed to run the club. Sources close to the group say a date to talk directly with the FAB is being finalised but early October is now looking likely.

It is part of a wider plan to get a “feel” for Everton ahead of the club changing hands. The chief operating officer of 777’s football department Don Dransfield met first-team manager Sean Dyche and director of football Kevin Thelwell at the club’s Finch Farm training base last week – although the Toffees boss insisted the talks were informal and it was stressed there was still much work to do before the takeover was completed.

As part of that they have opened up lines of communication with several prominent Everton supporters and some fan media. 777 co-founder and managing director Josh Wander himself has spoken to Everton blogger “The Esk” with a follow-up call planned for the end of the week.
The blogger told i he had written to Wander in a private capacity and continues to retain reservations about the group’s funding plans.

Sources close to the group told i the plan was part of a wider desire to be “transparent and communicate” and that they intended to be regular visitors to Goodison Park once the owners and directors’ test was complete.
An expert told i that the bulk of the ‘s enquiries in relation to 777 Partners was likely to focus on future funding.

Stephen Taylor Heath of JMW Solicitors, who has in-depth experience of the test, told i: “If the people involved in the business have successfully acquired football clubs before then you would think that they are likely to be regarded as fit and proper people in terms of passing the test.
“The one thing the Premier League look at is what is the ultimate source of the funding. They don’t take at face value who is put forward as the people who are funding the deal.
“They want to see where the money is coming from to protect against obvious money laundering issues but also in case people putting up the money have interests in competing clubs.”
He said the Premier League’s team of investigators would most likely concentrate on future financial funding of the club.
“If there are issues in terms of the funding of other clubs [in the group] then again they might not take the projections provided at face value and will be asking questions on top of that,” he said.

title: Dylan Hartley: Eddie Jones over the hill? I disagree
lead: Don’t get me wrong, we can be critical of his mistakes at this World Cup – but keep it professional
author: Dylan Hartley

body.text: I have a great respect for “the man in the arena”, as the description goes in the famous passage from American president Theodore Roosevelt.

The individuals who go out on to the turf to compete, physically and emotionally draining themselves, pouring years, months, weeks of preparation into 80 mins. They’re there to fight and win, but at times they will inevitably lose and get it wrong on the big stage (many a time for me!).

They then have to pick up the crap that’s thrown at them from disappointed fans and media while patching themselves up to go again. Another week of prep, more emotional and physical expenditure to fight another day. A little reminder that these players and coaches are human (yes  is human) and we’d do well to remember that.

Don’t get me wrong, we can be critical but keep it professional. Let’s talk Australia’s timing of Eddie’s appointment and Dave Rennie’s exit, as well as his selection and philosophy but that needs to be separated from personal/character assassination of which I’m seeing a lot, none of which is from people who have worked with Eddie and know the coach well enough to give a fair, factual analysis. A lot of opinion-spitters are blurring the lines of fact and fiction.

So let’s examine this issue of the timing of his appointment.  (RA) need to take responsibility for this. The low-impact option would have been for RA to let Rennie play out to the , purely for continuity and a steady ship, which is all important going to a big tournament – but the danger in doing so would be if Australia progressed and put on a good show it would complicate his exit.
Did they romanticise Eddie’s grand return? It also shows the excitement around someone like Eddie Jones on the open market. He is a quality coach, with impressive stats and speaks fluent Australian.

From Eddie’s point of view, imagine being released from your role, you’re unemployed and on the hunt for a new challenge (he’s human, remember) when the opportunity to coach his native Aussies emerges after travelling the world in numerous roles.
It must have been a dream job, of course he’d jump at it, it seemed like.

This whole situation was put into play when  Eddie’s contract which threw  into the role nine months before a World Cup instead of letting Eddie see out his England tenure – and people wondered why England were not scoring 10 tries a game and winning everything immediately.

My point is you’re creating multiple stories, stresses and dynamics. Termination of a head coach (never a nice story), uncertainty with players and staff on their futures and now a young coach under the pump with fans wanting performances and results –  the safe play is to let the contract play out and minimise the headlines and noise.
The time for change is post-World Cup, when you’ve got objective data and results, clear heads and a clear direction for the next four years. Good things take time.

In 2019, South Africa culled their coach and inserted Rassie Erasmus at short notice which resulted in them becoming world champions – many factors contributed to this (notably an established world-class playing group). It does prove this can work, but it takes bold leadership to make these culls and calls and ultimately you live and die by them – this time it hasn’t worked for Rugby Australia and we are yet to see how England progress.

The knee-jerk thing for Australia to do now would be to terminate Eddie, but what’s the point in all this pain if you’re going to start again? New coach, new staff, new/old players, more uncertainty. It’s quite clear EJ put his focus on developing the next wave of Australian talent and overtly talked about long-term planning to “make Australia great again”. All of the current crop will be better for this current experience, so long as they stick together.

I would however question why we didn’t see two old war horses in Michael Hooper and Quade Cooper – both high-performing, world-class athletes, talented rugby players with bags of experience. Australia needed them to guide this young crop.

Eddie hasn’t explained those non-selections – and that is very typical of him which leaves unanswered questions, which drives curiosity, frustration and conspiracy. Ultimately he’s in the big seat of leadership where he makes those calls, where you live and die by your selections, and Eddie has died on this one. That said, Carter Gordon, Australia’s young fly-half, will be better for this experience.

Another way to look at it is what’s happened with Wales. They have unearthed a new captain and world-class bolter in Jac Morgan. Just imagine that Warren Gatland had left Justin Tipuric at home and selected Morgan over him – it would have initially created pandemonium in leaving out a stalwart of Tipuric’s quality but the current performances and justified fanfare around Morgan would dissipate those initial grumbles.

A selection masterclass by Gatland and a reminder that in sport we have short memories – so long as we win at the weekend, “everything is awesome” but also a reminder when our team lose it’s not to panic – a case in point is England’s World Cup prep compared to where they sit now.
Behind the scenes, 99 per cent of players who work with Eddie are very complimentary.

They talk about his philosophy on the game, his unwavering dedication to the role and the way he interacts with players as humans away from the paddock… and that’s not forgetting the unrelenting, intense conversations where he holds you accountable to your every word and forensically analyses your physical performances. He keeps you very honest and is 110 per cent dedicated to his role.

It’s commonly suggested I have a blind loyalty to him just because he made me his captain, which is ridiculous. I am loyal with my personal views based on my experience with the man. I have bags of respect for him for reasons outlined above but I’m not blind, there’s nothing to be gained from lying… my time under him was not pleasant but damn it was rewarding. You don’t have to love his media persona but if you can separate that from the rugby, you’ve got to respect what he’s achieved in the game.

The Australian newspaper breaking the story of his discussions over the Japan job on the eve of their game was filthy. Why would you want to sabotage your own team’s prep? Why couldn’t they wait? If they were true-blue Australians, they’d have let the team play Wales, then run with it at a later date.

It seems personal. With an already turbulent campaign, Australia’s young group of players didn’t need extra fuel on the media fire –  I have no doubt it was disruptive to their preparations and performance. Any player who says it’s not a distraction, don’t believe them. It is.

Again, in sport we live in the here and now and have a short memory. England got knocked out at the pool stage in the 2015 World Cup, and they sacked Stuart Lancaster, Andy Farrell, Mike Catt and Graham Rowntree. Lanny and Faz are now being rated among the best coaches in the world while Catty and Wig are doing great in their respective roles.

I believe they had to go through that to become the men and the coaches they are today. We all need to go through that to learn. That sense of failure, hardship, loss, disappointment, to come out the other side stronger, more experienced, uglier and more resilient for it – it’s the same for players and coaches.

Timing is everything. Post-World Cup, in 2016, it was the right time. England had been knocked out of a home World Cup, we were rock bottom and couldn’t go any further which paved the way for opportunity. Whoever is coaching Australia after this World Cup will have a group with only one way to go and that’s up, I believe in time they will come back to be a very powerful rugby team.
Mentioning Andy Farrell, his team were strong contenders along with France, New Zealand and South Africa at the start of this World Cup – now I make them bang-on favourites.

They remind me of England in 2002 and 2003 – slaying whoever steps up, winning everything, doing everything that’s asked of them and fully justifying their world No 1 ranking. Put simply, they are on it and their belief will only be building with every performance like the one last weekend.

I’m of course supporting the darkest of horses England, you know that, but that game I saw between Ireland and South Africa was played like a final. The intensity was something else. South Africa are now a wounded beast and their race is far from run.
I enjoyed their post-match comments saying the loss is good for them as they now understand where they need to go to work – spoken like champions.

I copped some stick for saying had been lucky against Fiji – I stand by it and will repeat it (I wish the Welsh press actually printed the context to what I say not just a headline!)  – they were lucky.

Semi Radradra, one of the best players in the world, dropping the ball with an open try line in the last play of the game is unbelievably lucky, in my eyes – and that’s not taking anything away from the fantastic defensive effort and intensity that Wales hustled with.

As a player, you’re always chasing the perfect game and  was pretty damn good. It was full of some huge individual efforts which contributed to a team performance that has now raised some eyebrows around the tournament.

Warren Gatland has made reference to an episode he and I shared when I was playing for England against his Wales team in 2011. He publicly questioned my temperament and rugby capability… which I thank him for. It gave me the fuel and awareness to prepare for a game like I had never done so before and I subsequently performed well that weekend with England picking up the all-important win in Cardiff.
You could say it’s a great example of the Eddie Jones syndrome – you live by the sword, you die by the sword.

What people don’t see is when Warren had to regulate, with great sportsmanship, and approach me post-match to shake my hand and congratulate me on the performance. That’s the human stuff we don’t always see.

title: Ryder Cup 2023: How Phil Mickelson ‘took a bullet’ in bid to break USA team’s 30-year curse in Europe
lead: If the US do conquer Rome then Mickelson will deserve some credit for his astonishing and transformational attack on the team hierarchy
author: Kevin Garside

body.text: Mark Cannizzaro’s first  assignment for the New York Post came 30 years ago at The Belfry, where the Americans retained the trophy with a 15-13 victory.

It was the last American win on which he reported on European soil, a trend that reached its nadir nine years ago when  launched an astonishing attack on captain Tom Watson following another crushing loss at Gleneagles.

A week later Cannizzaro was covering the NFL in San Diego when he received a text from Mickelson, a resident of the southern California town, inviting him for a round of golf. It proved a revealing 18 holes in which Mickelson justified his nuclear assault on one of America’s most sacred figures.
It was, Cannizzaro explained, the first move in a strategy aimed at wresting power away from the Ryder Cup executives at the PGA of America and handing greater control to the players.

Mickelson wanted the players front of centre of the Ryder Cup project, to have a connected captain with recent playing experience and a greater influence in the selection process. The Gleneagles meltdown led to the formation of a “task force” which was essentially a tight group of significant players who would drill into the secrets of European success in order to replicate it.

It was an impulse that mirrored the radical changes initiated 40 years ago under the captaincy of Tony Jacklin, who reconstructed the European team around the needs of the players not administrators on a junket.
“Mickelson brought up this task force thing. He was kind of mapping out the whole reason for it,” Cannizzaro tells i.

“The American understanding was that Europe was much more united, and part of that was the succession plan where they would bring up the ladder guys as vice-captains and those guys would end up as captains.

“That’s where we get into the Watson thing. Watson was so far removed from the current players at Gleneagles. The generation gap is a big deal in sport these days. Watson was more of an old school manager who rules with an iron first.

“My way is the only way. He was not listening to the people around him. Watson was not around the PGA Tour. I’m not sure if he was even playing the Champions Tour. So that week at Gleneagles was a clash of a number of forces.

“The US realising that Europe has the secret sauce. Why was that? Because of a succession plan and the way they worked that. And also that Ted Bishop, who was the president of the PGA of America at the time, was best pals with Watson. It was an old boys’ network, and that infuriated the players, but no-one had the cache or the balls to speak out.

“So when Mickelson came out on that Sunday night and said what he did, it was shocking because no-one in our culture takes out their coach and manager publicly. That stuff is all whispered. I asked Mickelson why he did that, because he was getting skewered for doing that to a legend.
“He said, ‘I totally understand. I know the timing was awkward but if I expressed those sentiments six months later nobody cares, it would have zero impact.’

“Really, he was speaking to what everybody else was thinking. And as is usual with Phil, he ended up taking bullets for them. If you want to call that noble or stupid or silly, at the end of the day that was the catalyst for change. The players themselves came up with the task force idea, and the core of the task force was Mickelson, Tiger Woods, Davis Love III, Rickie Fowler and Jim Furyk.”

Though the United States lost in Paris on their subsequent visit here, they inflicted massive wounds at Hazeltine in 2016 and Whistling Straits two years ago. Present captain Zach Johnson was part of the Gleneagles debacle and believes the changes since, rooted in a player-centric model, has resulted in a team capable of breaking the 30-year hoodoo.

Johnson was criticised for the , the likes of Dustin Johnson, Bryson DeChambeau and Patrick Reed – perhaps a hint that egos were also unwelcome – but countered that the picks he made were chosen as much by the six who qualified automatically as him, which is a manifestation of the player power and connectivity Mickelson was seeking.

“There’s a lot of elements involved when it comes to all of our guys and the picks in particular,” Johnson said. “I can say this in full confidence with our six guys that made this team: Those guys were adamant they wanted those six other guys to help complete their team.”
Johnson has selected players bonded around established friendships, college bros who will fight for one another and the overall cause.

The majority live in the same Florida enclave. The practice groups on Tuesday betrayed this team chemistry; Jordan Spieth played with Justin Thomas, Patrick Cantlay with Xander Schauffele and Scottie Scheffler with his chum Sam Burns. Johnson sees himself as little more than an enabler creating the conditions in which his players can thrive.

“These guys want to change things up and play and roll. They just want to be around each other on and off the golf course. We are letting these guys be comfortable, given the fact that it’s a pretty uncomfortable situation. There’s more fluidity and versatility in our system now.”

This, argues Cannizzaro, is the litmus test of the Mickelson revolution. Old Lefty remains as controversial and divisive as ever, yet if the United States do conquer Rome, at least some of the credit accrues to him.

title: Man Utd return ‘a distant dream’ for Jadon Sancho, insiders say
lead: There remains the feeling that the relationship between Sancho and Ten Hag cannot be repaired with neither prepared to accept the blame
author: Pete Hall

body.text: believes he is within his rights to voice his disapproval at ’s questioning of his commitment in training, sources close to the player have told i, with the  international feeling like he was singled-out .
The  winger believes that if he were simply to apologise now and admit the manager was right, it would undermine going public with his views and invite similar treatment in the future, insiders said.
However,  and , some in the forward’s entourage have concerns. Especially after Ten Hag doubled down on his belief that the ball is in Sancho’s court after United’s 3-0 win over  on Tuesday.
“He is a great player, that doesn’t go away, so he will have offers in January if we are where we are now – with first-team football at United a distant dream,” an insider said.
“But clubs need to see something that would encourage them to bring him to their club. Talent alone won’t get him a move to another top team.
“We are aware of how this all looks for him, and the longer United leave him in the cold, the lower his appeal drops.”

Concerns over Sancho’s timekeeping and overall attitude are nothing new. Sancho himself admitted he had trouble with timekeeping when turning up late for  training in 2019 and was fined by the club a year later for returning from England duty late.
Reports also claim timekeeping has been a problem for Sancho when on England duty. He has not been called up by  for any squad since 2021.
i understands one particular problem with Sancho is around sleep, or lack thereof, caused partly by playing computer games at night – something several of his clubs have noticed.

United have stood by Ten Hag over his forthright stance on the player’s attitude, with club sources insisting the Dutchman has the backing of director of football John Murtough and CEO Richard Arnold.

Despite Brazilian forward Antony remaining unavailable even though he is back in the UK to answer allegations of assault, other options have presented themselves to Ten Hag, with young Uruguayan Facundo Pellistri finally given his first-team chance and Alejandro Garnacho’s stock growing by the week.
Alternatives give Ten Hag further cause to stick to his guns on Sancho. Ill-discipline at United has been endemic in the post  era, with the club impressed how the Dutchman dealt with ’s exit.

Senior players in the squad have done all they can to persuade Sancho to knock on his manager’s door. The feeling among team-mates is one of “bewilderment”, given how reconcilable they feel this whole thing is.

The Professional Footballers’ Association (PFA) has also offered to mediate any dialogue between parties, i understands. They do not want a player who spent a period away from the club last season for “physical and mental health” reasons to be left to fight any battle alone.

There remains the underlying feeling, though, that the relationship between Sancho and Ten Hag cannot be repaired. Last season, , which the player remains grateful for, the 23-year-old could not command a regular first-team spot or even work out what his best position was.
The breakthrough came in pre-season when Sancho excelled in a No 10 role, one Ten Hag has openly suggested plays to Sancho’s strengths.
Ahead of the trip to Arsenal earlier this month, Sancho had not started a single game, . The social media fallout since leaves us at the current impasse.
And the longer it goes on, the more everyone loses out.
