title: VAR’s absence is an insult to women’s football and has thrown Nations League into chaos
lead: Both England matches this international break have featured major errors, with no VAR to correct them
author: Katherine Lucas

body.text: UTRECHT — “It was so obvious it was offside.”
was as bewildered as the rest of Stadion Galgenwaard at Danielle van de Donk’s role in Lieke Martens’ opener as the  in the Nations League.
VAR, or in this case, its use in some games and glaring absence in others, is a discrepancy fewer and fewer people can understand.

Dutch boss Andries Jonker insisted he would prefer VAR was not funded at all – he suggested the money might be better invested in youth football – but added: “If there is a VAR, I don’t understand why there is not always a VAR… if you’re convinced you should do it, do it every tournament.”

The fact may yet be relegated from the mini-league and sit third behind Belgium and  cannot be blamed on technology alone – indeed it has both benefited the Lionesses and cost them. In the  over Scotland, Millie Bright was fortunate not to give away a penalty for a foul on Martha Thomas. There was no VAR at the Stadium of Light, which is not required to install the equipment because Sunderland are not in the Premier League, nor in Utrecht on Tuesday night.

According to Uefa’s own regulations, VAR is not a necessity in the Nations League’s group stages; it will only come into play in the semi-finals and beyond. Countries like England, who could use the VAR technology at Wembley if desired, may not even be in the competition by then – if that happens, they will also miss out on the Paris Olympics in their iteration as Team GB.
The decision is up to national associations, many of whom do not have the funding to run the system effectively, or indeed at all.

The discrepancy is damning, though, for the women’s game as a whole. Bright said afterwards: “We push the level of the game to be so high and professional, yet sometimes have VAR, sometimes don’t, sometimes have goal-line technology. There is no consistency.”

While insisting that it was not an excuse for England’s performance, the skipper hit out at the “mind-blowing” state of international women’s football in which tournaments are so heavily influenced by the lack of VAR.
“She [Van de Donk] was basically stood next to Mary [Earps]!” Georgia Stanway added.

“That’s football, but also we are at a level now where we do need VAR at every game and we do need officials to be able to step up in those moments, because those are the moments whether you make qualification or don’t. We are competing to go to an Olympics here, yet things like that are the difference.
“There is not much you can say apart from there is still work to be done in the women’s game and for VAR to be at every single game.”
Chelsea recently became the first  club to trial VAR in their pre-season friendly against Roma at Kingsmeadow.
However, there is no sign of the technology becoming implemented across the league. That is largely due to funding and due to the difficulties of hosting video assistants at smaller grounds.

It is understood there is a fear that the WSL’s leading clubs, who play more regularly at their side’s main stadia – such as Arsenal at the Emirates and Chelsea at Stamford Bridge – could benefit disproportionately from the possibilities of using VAR in those grounds.

Until that is addressed – and at the very least at international level – there are few bodies who can claim to be serious about growing the women’s game. But as Wiegman put it: “The sport’s never fair”.

title: Who will win the Ryder Cup 2023? Our predictions for winning team and top points-scorer in Europe vs USA
lead: Europe are the narrow favourites with the bookies to regain the trophy but the USA are sending arguably their best ever team in a bid to end a 30-year streak without an away win
author: James Gray

body.text: Golfers have never made so much money, and yet  24 of them will give everything they have and more to win a tournament where there is not a penny on the line.
Yes, in the there is no prize money, no Green Jacket and no individual trophy. You can shoot 59 and no one will really remember unless you win.
The only thing really on the line is two years of bragging rights and the chance to make a bit of history.
So too i‘s own predictions, where pride and honour are at stake.
Chief sports correspondent in Rome
Winner and margin

Europe by three points. The bookies have swung (marginally) behind the home side. The form of big three – Rory McIlroy, Jon Rahm and Viktor Hovland plus wunderkind  – has given Europe a sense that momentum is theirs.
Top Europe points scorer
Viktor Hovland arrives as the FedEx Cup champion playing the golf of his young life. He made his debut in  but is a far more mature player here. A big personality, he loves the fight.
Top USA points scorer
Few rise to a competitive occasion like Brooks Koepka. He sealed his fifth major at the PGA Championship in May following  and if the US have an eight-footer to win the cup, he’s the man to make it.
Dark horse

Ludvig Aberg is less dark a horse than he was following his first victory as a pro to seal his captain’s pick in Switzerland. He hits it a mile and gun-barrel straight but showed he is human by blowing a last-day lead at Wentworth two weeks ago. He will be even harder to beat for that experience.
Best pairing

Hovland and Aberg would be a fantastic gamble. Bonded by a shared Scandinavian culture, they are both huge hitters with unflappable temperaments. If Aberg feeds off Hovland’s irrepressible drive, they could prove a devastating combination.
Sports news correspondent
Winner and margin
by two points.
Top Europe points scorer

The obvious choice is Rory McIlroy given he could easily play five matches, but Tyrrell Hatton’s game could suit Marco Simone very well. Bay Hill, home to the Arnold Palmer Invitational, is the course most likened to this one in terms of strengths and weaknesses: Hatton won there in 2020 and was tied for second in 2022.
Top USA points scorer

Scottie Scheffler is top of most statistics on this US team but most notably on Strokes Gained: Driving, a statistic that looks likely to be the most important of the week. Scheffler went unbeaten two years ago, including hammering then-reigning US Open champion Jon Rahm in the singles.
Dark horse

The lowest ranked and youngest player in the whole competition, the analytics pick might well be Nicolai Hojgaard. He is second on the DP World Tour off the tee (only Adrian Meronk, a past winner in Rome and unlucky not to be picked, betters him).
Best pairing
Rahm and Hatton would surely be the sweariest two-ball for a fiery Friday afternoon. Stick them in against Justin Thomas and Patrick Cantlay, and watch the sparks fly.
Deputy sports editor
Winner and margin
USA by 1. Shorn of , this young squad has fewer battle scars than previous incarnations and a better team ethos – a combination that could give the Americans the extra 1 per cent they need.
Top Europe points scorer

Jon Rahm. Europe’s best performer in the demolition at Whistling Straits has grown immeasurably in stature since his 1-2-0 return on debut in 2018. With two major victories under his belt, including a four-shot victory at this year’s Masters, Rahmbo is the man for a big occasion.
Top USA points scorer

Collin Morikawa. No stranger to winning in Europe with victory at the Open in 2021. Undefeated on debut two years ago, the most accurate driver on the visiting team should be able navigate Marco Simone’s narrow fairways like the best Europeans.
Dark horse

Brian Harman. Dimunitive lefty barely missed a putt at the Open and could prove deadly if he translates that form into matchplay. Less brash than some of his teammates, the big game hunter is unlikely to rile up the home fans and that should also play in his favour.
Best pairing

I’m most intrigued by who Europe pick to pair Rory McIlroy. The best player in the world on his day but one who hasn’t always performed at his best in Ryder Cups, McIlroy looks in need of a fellow stalwart to help him be himself rather than a young rookie. With no Francesco Molinari this year to reprise “Moliwood”, could McIlroy be paired with Tommy Fleetwood and create “Fleetwood Mac”?

title: UK house prices: Properties selling for £12,000 below asking price as market weakens
lead: The highest discounts are found in London and the South East, where the average discount to the asking price is now 4.8 per cent
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Properties are  for £12,000 below their original asking price as buyers continue to benefit from a slump to  as the market weakens.
The average discount to the asking price is now 4.2 per cent, according to data published by the property website Zoopla. This rises to 4.8 per cent in London and the South East.

As a result of  and starting to fall, enquiries for people to view properties rose by 12 per cent in September compared with the previous month. This led to discounts reaching their highest level since March 2019.

While an increase after August, a time when many are on their summer holidays, is to be expected, agents  report that it remains a buyers’ market and home sellers have finally accepted the need to drop their prices. This has meant more buyers are happy to proceed. There are now 80 per cent more homes  for sale than in September 2021.

However, mortgage rates still remain high compared to two years ago when people could get rates for as low as 1 per cent. The average two-year fix is 6.53 per cent while the rate for a five-year one is 6.03 per cent, according to the analytics firm Moneyfacts.
Some experts believe that average rates will fall below 5 per cent within six to nine months, although some providers including Nationwide, HSBC and Santander,  all have rates below this already.
Zoopla added it expects the number of buyers to increase once mortgage rates get below 4.5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told i: “This is still a buyers’ market for the moment. It is no longer an environment where sellers can set a price knowing that  it will likely to be met.”
“The continues to adjust to a higher mortgage rate environment,” added Richard Donnell, executive director at Zoopla.
“Better news on and the end of increases has provided scope for lenders to start reducing mortgage rates which has supported a modest uptick in demand for homes this September.”

Home hunters also remain unwilling to make compromises on the size of home they are looking for, meaning they are waiting for either a fall in house prices or mortgage rates, even if this is not guaranteed to happen quickly.
Overall, the number of homes sold this year is set to be 20 per cent lower than in 2022, with 28 per cent fewer buyers around for those relying on a mortgage, Zoopla said.

Matt Thompson, head of sales at Chestertons, said: “Since the Bank of England’s announcement of interest rates remaining at 5.25 per cent for the time being, we have seen a positive response from buyers in September who felt more secure to make financial decisions and resume their property search.

“Understandably, buyers who are now entering the market are particularly careful about their budget and factor in any future rate hikes as well as the cost of living. As demand for properties in the capital continues to outstrip supply, the market remains competitive.”

title: How to buy a house for the best price: your guide to bagging a bargain in a buyers’ market
lead: There are several ways to get a discount on your property in the current market
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Home hunters will be closely observing at the moment, as  for an average of £12,000 under asking price, amid a weakening .
The average discount to asking prices is 4.2 per cent, with to be up to 3 per cent lower over 2023, according to Zoopla.
Prices have already fallen by 5.9 per cent compared to the same time last year, according to Nationwide, the sharpest fall since 2009.

This has created a buyers’ market, providing more options to negotiate with sellers and get a hefty discount on the asking price. If you’re thinkingin the near future, read below to see how you can get a good deal.
Experts says that now is a good time to put a “cheeky offer” on a home you want to buy, to see if it is accepted.
“It has swapped to a buyers’ market at the moment,” said Aaron Strutt of Trinity Financial, adding that  are trying to “stimulate the market” by offering cheaper rates to first time buyers.
“Mortgage rates are  with more lenders offering below 5 per cent fixed rates, provided you have a larger deposit.”
Nationwide, HSBC and Santander are all lenders offering deals below 5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told  that buyers shouldn’t wait too long if they have found a suitable property.

“My advice to any first time buyer or prospective home owner is, if you see a property that meets your desires and is affordable, don’t try to second guess when the market is going to bottom out or when rates are going to hit rock bottom,” he said.
However, Mr Strutt said many first time buyers are still putting off getting onto the property ladder.

“Many suspect mortgages will be more affordable by then, and property prices may well be more stable. But property is supposed to be a long term investment, and as we have seen, prices will go up and down.”
No seller puts their property on the market expecting to get the asking price at the moment, experts say.
“It’s a way of testing the market, see how many viewings the property gets and test any opening bids,” Mr Mendes said.
The longer the property stays on the market, the higher the chance of negotiating for a price you’re more comfortable with.
If you notice that your dream property is listed with two estate agents, Mr Mendes says to speak to both of them to “gain as much information as possible”.
“This could provide you with the golden nugget to seal the deal.”
Furthermore, showing sellers you really want their property can also win them over, even if you ask for less than the asking price.

“Sellers want to ensure you are committed to the purchase, so being personable and selling an idea of why you will be perfect will go a long way. They could choose your offer over another prospective offer at a higher amount.”
It’s important to remember to see what needs to be done to the property, something not every homeowner does. This doesn’t come cheap so negotiating the price is highly recommended.

Mr Mendes added: “Take stock of all the work that needs to be done and potential costs and use it as part of the negotiation. What’s the worst that can happen? The seller says no to your price, but at least you have something to work from.”
House hunters are encouraged to take things into their own hands and being slightly different, as it may come with rewards.
For example, if there is a property on the street up for sale, don’t be afraid to write a leaflet with why you want to live on that street and post to neighbouring properties.
Mr Mendes said: “Estate agents do it with ‘we need more properties like yours for a prospective buyer’ leaflets.”
“This way, you get in there first and potentially get a better deal buying privately without the competition.”
That being said, while buyers will have room to negotiate in the current market, it’s still important to remember that not all properties will be up for debate.

For instance, it may be easier to bring down the price of a larger home compared to a one bedroom flat. Post pandemic, the “race for space” is on the decline, with estate agents seeing a decline in house hunters looking for larger properties with spacious gardens.
In prime locations, sellers may try to hold out for the best offers they can get, so haggling for lower prices might not work.
It’s important to think about what a property may be worth and if the price you have in mind is realistic.

title: Should I fix my energy? How Ofgem’s new price cap change will affect bills as fixed deals return to the market
lead: As the price cap is due to change this week, some will be considering whether to fix their energy deal
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: The new comes into effect this week, dropping to
Millions will be affected by the change on October 1, with the cap falling by £151 from the current level of £2,074.
Under the cap, which limits the unit cost of  for those on variable tariffs, the unit costs will fall to 27p for electricity and 7p for gas.
As more providers start to introduce , many will be wondering if now is the best time to fix their energy bill?
i spoke to experts to find out.
The energy price cap is set by , the body that regulates energy suppliers in Great Britain. It limits the maximum amount energy suppliers can charge you for each unit of energy you use.
It was introduced in 2019 because there was a concern that people were paying too much for their energy. The price cap is currently reviewed every three months.

It was overridden by the Government’s energy price guarantee between 1 October last year until 30 June, 2023. This provided a support rate discount to all households with gas or electricity, bringing it down to around £2,500 per year.
However, since July the price cap is now the scheme limiting bills. It only applies to variable tariffs and not fixed ones.
Fixed deals, where you are tied in to a contract with your provider, used to be the cheapest way to pay for your energy.

Despite the reduction to the price cap being a positive move, are still much higher than they were just a couple of years ago when people could get a fixed deal for an average of £800 a year, if not less.
They are now returning to the market as prices begin to decrease, with some now available below the price cap. Most are fixed for a year or more.
Whether you should fix your energy deal will depend on what sort of deal you can get and whether you are willing to risk energy prices going up or down again.
If you are looking for certainty, a fixed deal could work for you. However, it will probably only make sense if you are guaranteed to pay less than your supplier’s default tariff.
Currently, there are 10 providers offering fixed deals, however, many come with caveats.
For example, several are for existing customers only, such as Octopus Energy’s Loyal Octopus fixed deal.

Others like Utility Warehouse’s Fixed Saver 6 deal requires customers to sign up to two other products with the firm, like broadband. This is also the only one below the new price cap at £1,873 on average.
However, it is probable that more deals will become available after the new cap comes into effect.

Natalie Mathie, energy expert at Uswitch.com, said: “Only those on fixed tariffs have the certainty of knowing what they will pay for the full term of their deal, which is usually a year. During that time, customers on variable tariffs will see their bills change four times.

“A reasonably priced fixed deal could be a good option for households who want certainty over what they will pay. However, as the energy market remains volatile, it can be difficult to predict whether opting for a fixed deal or sticking with a variable will save you money in the long run.”
For those thinking of switching to a fixed deal, experts are warning people to pay attention to any exit fees, which could cost up to £200 per fuel.

Ms Mathie added: “The price you are quoted to pay through direct debit each month is an estimate based on your predicted usage and may not end up being the actual cost over the whole year. Remember, if you use more energy, you’ll pay more.
“Make sure you look at the unit price and standing charge so you can understand how much you will pay for your energy usage and how it differs from what you are currently charged.”

title: How much the children of the UK’s super rich inherit – and how little they pay in inheritance tax
lead: Analysis by the IFS shows that the wealthiest 1 per cent of the population would see almost half of the financial benefit if Inheritance Tax (IHT) was abolished.
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Children of the wealthiest fifth will receive £380,000 next year in inheritance next year – with just 10 per cent of this paid in, according to figures from a leading think-tank.
Figures from the Institute for Fiscal Studies illustrate the differences in the amounts of money passed down through generations, with the least wealthy fifth of  leaving less than £2,000 per child.
Analysis by the IFS shows that the  of the population would see almost half of the financial benefit if Inheritance Tax (IHT) was abolished.

The think-tank said the cost of abolishing the  would be around £7 billion, and 47 per cent of the savings would go to those with £2.1 million or more in assets – representing the top 1 per cent of estates.
The calculations show that the vast  – around 90 per cent – would see no benefit if the tax were to go.
According to reports last weekend,  are currently drawing up plans to cut, and potentially even scrap, Inheritance Tax.
And the IFS’s report, Reforming, says that scrapping the policy would come with cost that “grows over time.”
In a decade’s time, it says getting rid of the tax would cost the Treasury around £15 billion.

The most recent HMRC statistics show less than 4 per cent of estates paid inheritance tax in 2020–21, but the rapid  among older individuals means this number is set to rise to over 7 per cent by 2032–33, according to the IFS.
And the number of people affected by the tax will be still larger, with one in eight people (12 per cent) will have inheritance tax due either on their death or their partner’s death by 2032–33.
The report has argued that if it retained, IHT should be reformed.
It has said reforms that remove poorly justified reliefs could raise up to £4.5 billion.

David Sturrock, a senior research economist at IFS, said: “There are reasonable arguments for and against an inheritance tax. But as inheritances grow in size, it’s increasingly important that we address problems in the current system.

“The government should abolish the special treatment given to business assets, certain types of shares, agricultural assets, pensions and homes passed to direct descendants. These exemptions and reliefs open up channels to avoid inheritance tax,” he added.
“This is costly, unfair and distorts economic decisions. Reforming them could raise as much as £4.5 billion in additional revenue,” he said.
There is a large regional variation in the number of people that pay the tax.
In London, around 23 per cent of people (or their surviving spouse or civil partner) will pay inheritance tax, almost twice the national average and five times higher than in the North East.

title: Number of first-time buyers falls by a fifth as UK mortgage rates remain high
lead: Challenges in the housing market have presented obstacles for many first time buyers in recent months
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: The number of  fell by more than a fifth this year, as the rise in mortgage rates has made getting on the property ladder less affordable.

Although first-time buyers still accounted for more than half of all home loans, this was down by 22 per cent between January and August this year when compared to the same period in 2022, according to Halifax.
Challenges in the , from increases in mortgage rates to periods of lower availability of mortgage deals, have presented obstacles for many first time buyers in recent months.

Nick Mendes of brokers, John Charcol, said: “First time buyers have been affected by affordability constraints. Lenders have had to take into account higher rates and an increase in household expenditure.”

Despite house prices falling in recent times with some experts still predicting drops of as much as 15 per cent from their peak, the average price of the first home is now £288,030, down by just 2 per cent in the past year.
Experts say there hasn’t been a drop in first time buyer activity like this since early 2020, after the pandemic hit.
Mendes said: “The last time we saw first time buyers transactions fall would be around the  period.
“We saw many first time buyers, those early in their careers or those who have recently started a new job, worried about their job security and as a result put on hold plans to take on a mortgage.”
Many are in the same boat now, due to the ongoing cost of living crisis, with inflation a barrier when it comes to  – an already difficult challenge of house ownership. The needed is now £54,116.

“The average age of those buying their first property is now 32, rising by two years over the past decade, most likely reflecting that increasing costs are making the road to home ownership longer,” said Kim Kinnaird, Director at Halifax Mortgages.
“When people are ready to , most are doing so in joint names which helps both in terms of costs and affordability.”
According to Kinnaird, “expected” falls in house prices and “stronger income growth” may offset in the future.
Currently, the house price to income ratio for first time buyers has fallen from 5.8 in June last year, to 5.1 currently.
According to Mendes, the figures reflect the  for the past 12 months, which included “fluctuations in rates and short periods when markets have settled.”
“Property prices have gradually decreased but are still significantly higher from where they were 24 months ago,” he told i.

Regionally, the South East – which has the second most expensive average property prices in the UK – had the biggest decline in the number of people buying a first home between January and August this year, at 25 per cent.
London and East Anglia had the second biggest decline in first-time buyers entering the property market so far this year, down 24 per cent.

title: How I Manage My Money: Fire saver, 25, who is saving £1.7k of his £2.6k monthly income
lead: Bonde lives a frugal lifestyle and puts a large slice of his income into a stocks and shares Isa each month
author: Jane Denton

body.text: In our  we aim to find out how people in the UK are spending, saving and investing money to meet their costs and achieve their goals. This week we speak to Bonde Ruzyotora, who is 25 and lives in a house in multiple occupation (HMO) in north London. Bonde works as a consultant at a large technology firm, aims to follow the Financial Independence, Retire Early (Fire) movement and is a fan of Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger.
Bonde lives a frugal lifestyle and puts a large slice of his income into a stocks and shares Isa each month.
My monthly income: The take-home pay from my job at a technology firm is about £2,600 per month.

My monthly outgoings: Rent, £400, though this may soon rise to £600, groceries, public transport and newspaper subscriptions, £300 to £350 per month. I put £1,700 per month into my stocks and shares Isa. I put 5 per cent of my salary into a workplace pension. I never eat out, don’t have a gym subscription or anything like Netflix or Spotify.

I was born in  but left for Uganda when I was three. I spent years growing up in Uganda and our life there was much better than life in the UK would have been given our income. We’d have been on a low income in the UK but lived comfortably in Uganda.

We had a happier upbringing than my cousins who grew up in Broadwater Farm, Tottenham. That’s where I’d have probably grown up had my parents not decided to move. My father tried his hand at a few different  and my mother did the same, while bringing up six children. I started hustling and earning money from a young age in Uganda.

I came back to London on my own in 2019 with the sole intention of trying McDonald’s for the first time. I also studied accounting and finance at university in London. By this point I had become a devout disciple of the church of Warren Buffet and Charlie Munger. There were only 14 shares listed on the Ugandan stock exchange at the time, so if I wanted to make a go of, I knew I had to be elsewhere.

Through my job, I now take home a salary of around £2,600 a month. I live in a HMO and my rent is £400 per month, though this is likely to be rising to £600 per month soon. I have a very minimalist  and don’t eat out, travel or have any subscriptions. I don’t even have any fashion sense anymore and just buy whatever is in my size.

I think the man who said that happiness comes from within was probably on to something. I don’t get a massive kick from spending money. If I have a good anime series to watch or am reading a good book, I’m happy.

I put £1,700 per month into a, with investments in the Berkshire Hathaway fund and Micron Technology.  I currently add 5 per cent of my salary to my work pension each month, with my employer matching the contribution.
I do not have cash savings and prefer to put all my money in one place. I don’t see the point of having multiple accounts open for slightly different reasons.

In the UK, for instance, I do not see why an emergency cash fund would be necessary when almost every possible disaster that could crop up would be resolved or covered either by the  or the local council. I do not see why you would put, for instance, a £4,000 “emergency fund” into a cash account rather than a stocks and shares Isa.

My main financial goal is to retire as early as possible and I would, of course, like to be a millionaire one day. I am very interested in the  and would like to spend my retirement watching anime, reading books, fulfilling my dream of attending a Berkshire Hathaway annual general meeting and supporting communities back home in Uganda. While I would say I am a proud member of the Fire movement, I am mindful that past results are not indicative of the future.

My liquid financial capital currently totals £85,000. However, I have never really been interested in buying a house, mainly because I like being single and don’t plan to settle down or get married for at least the next 10 to 15 years.

I do, however, find the idea of shared ownership interesting, but appreciate it is not risk-free. As far as I know, rent is calculated on the portion of the property you don’t own and, for a new-build, this is capped at 3 per cent of the share still owned by the housing association or landlord.

While some elements of shared ownership are appealing, I’d worry about the resale value of a shared ownership property being limited to non-existent. The additional service charges often applied, and sometimes increased every year, also make it difficult to gauge what the monthly costs would be. This is a housing scheme that could have been better thought out and I will be sticking to renting for the time being.

I have few monthly outgoings and am disciplined when it comes to my finances. I am keen on the idea of delayed gratification. You can either have a work-life balance for the majority of your career or do the heavy lifting in the beginning and relax in later life.
I prefer to adopt the latter approach. My goal is financial freedom and the ability to focus on my passions like reading and watching anime.

title: Interest rates to stay high, but predictably so: welcome to the new normal for our finances
lead: Andrew Bailey votes to pause on rate rises, but leaves wiggle room to increase in the future
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: On Thursday we saw something happen last seen in November 2021: the Bank of England opted not to increase the base rate.

The effect in the press room at the Bank of England, where journalists got early sight of the decision, was immediate. There was a ripple of excitement and intakes of breath. Nothing was happening, but this was the best and most exciting nothing we’ve seen for close to two years.

and his colleagues at the Bank left lots of wiggle room to increase rates in the future if necessary – the Governor of the Bank of England repeatedly stated he was not being “complacent” to reassure the markets.
But he will be aware the message he’s sending: that the fastest period of increases to interest rates in modern times is likely to be coming to an end.
This is good news. It means we are moving from a period of uncertainty and financial shocks to a future where rates are likely to be more stable.
But let’s not get out the bunting just yet: mortgage rates won’t go down dramatically, they will just remain predictably high.

The markets are now predicting the base rate to average just above 5 per cent for the next three years, and the GDP data for the second and third quarter of this years show us uncomfortably close to a technical recession, another reason the Bank may not want to have pushed things too far on Thursday.

It will be some time before we get to the next stage of recovery, when the . Inflation is not expected to return to 2 per cent next year, and rates aren’t likely going to go down significantly before the middle of 2024.

So what are the key messages from today? That people with variable mortgages can breathe a small sight of relief that their repayments won’t go up too much higher in the near future and those on fixed rates can assume a rate of 5 per cent (ish) for the next three years or so.

Savers should fix a good rate now ad feel able to tie up their money for several years, if they haven’t already, knowing that rates won’t get much better. Anyone holding off getting a pension annuity can now commit for the same reasons.

Ultimately, while Thursday’s news isn’t a celebration, many people can take a small degree of comfort from knowing that it’s going to be easier to plan our finances. We’re not living with shifting financial sands any longer.

title: ‘Triple lock’ is as much as a bind for the Tories as it is for Labour
lead: It is getting increasingly difficult to fund this protection now that it is growing more than anything else
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: One former Cabinet-level minister told me off the record that both Labour and Conservative would dearly love to ditch the “” – the commitment to raise the state pension each April in line with higher prices or wages, with a fall back of 2.5 per cent if neither rises by that much – “but neither wants to be the first one to do it”.

It had been assumed that the Tories would never consider substantially changing it, for to do so would be the equivalent of releasing a heat-seeking missile to blow up what remains of their voter base, but the lack of enthusiasm for committing to it is noticeable.

The triple lock debate is a messy argument because there are very good reasons to keep it – and equally good ones to scrap it. Its costs are mainly paid for by pre-retirement workers, who may already be having to pay off university loans, fund the impact of climate change and pay for the growing bill of social care.
It is getting increasingly difficult to fund this protection now that it is growing more than anything else (wages, the size of the economy or how much is raised via taxation included).

But it’s also true that the lock has kept plenty of older people –  – out of poverty. This is because historically the state pension has been woefully low, so recent increases, though very big, could also be seen as righting a wrong.

Expect to see future fudges as politicians seek to be seen to do something about it while mindful that the majority of people who vote want to keep it. And all in the hope that they will not be in power at the time when someone has to properly address it.

title: Stamp duty should be scrapped and ‘gums up’ housing market, says senior economics expert at IFS
lead: Economics expert Helen Miller says the tax on house purchases means ‘young families struggle to trade up, and older people hold onto bigger properties than they need’
author: Jessie Hewitson

body.text: The deputy director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies has called for  to be axed.
, Helen Miller said it “imposes a heavier tax charge on properties that change hands more often” and “there is no good reason to do this”.

Ms Miller, head of tax for the independent and respected economics think tank, added: “It gums up the housing market, meaning people find it harder to move to where the jobs are, young families struggle to trade up, and older people hold onto bigger properties than they need, because it costs so much to move… stamp duty should simply be scrapped.”

Buyers paid £15.4bn in stamp duty over the tax year 2022-2023. Currently, it is paid on increasing portions of the property price when you buy a residential property. In England, the tax only applies to homes over £250,000, above which the buyer pays up to 12 per cent.

In Scotland, there is no Land and Buildings Transaction Tax – the equivalent of stamp duty – on the first £145,000 above which buyers are taxed up to 12 per cent, and in Wales, the Land Transaction Tax is triggered at £225,000 and also goes up to 12 per cent.
Earlier in the summer, another think tank, the Resolution Foundation, called on the Government to reduce stamp duty by 50 per cent to boost the country’s productivity.

The foundation proposed cancelling the 2025 rise in stamp duty, and halving rates for main homes and non-residential properties, at a total cost of £5bn. It said this would make it cheaper for people to move jobs and homes while helping firms grow and move premises.

Ms Miller’s comments came as the IFS called for the tax system to be reformed more broadly. A report by the institute found that tax revenue is now 37 per cent of national income –– and rising, and that taxes will have to go higher in the coming decades to fund health and social care costs for an ageing population, as well as costs associated with climate change.

The report also looked into how the tax system encouraged people into , and how wealth “tends to be undertaxed relative to labour income… and in some cases – including the gains made on main homes – completely untaxed.”
This combined, with high marginal tax rates caused by “humps” in income, reduce the incentive to work, or change how people work, which creates “an unnecessary drag on productivity”.
Ms Miller also wrote that inheritance tax is currently “easily avoided by the healthy, wealthy and well advised”.

title: ‘At 62, I’ve fallen in love with my job again after going part-time, now I’ll work into my 80s’
lead: New figures reveal record numbers of people in their fifties and older are now in part-time work
author: Aasma Day

body.text: A tutor who cut her hours to work part-time says the move has rekindled her passion for work so much she never wants to , as figures reveal record numbers of people aged 50 and older are working part-time in the UK.

New data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) shows that 3.6 million  are working part-time in the UK. This is a record high and a 12 per cent increase since 2021. It also represents a 26 per cent increase in the past decade and a 56 per cent increase in the past two decades.

Sue Dinnage, 62, who lives in Gorseinon, Wales told i that changing to working part-time from full-time has completely changed her outlook on work and it is now such a pleasure rather than a necessity, she “never wants to .”
Ms Dinnage, who is married to Keith and has a son and a step-son, spent 15 years working in the education sector in different roles, most recently as a higher level teaching assistant.
A few years ago, the family relocated back to Wales from South East England with no jobs and Ms Dinnage planned to set up a private online tutoring business.

She says she has now built up a busy practice tutoring English and maths with 20 students and a waiting list and reveals she now earns more money working part-time as a tutor than she ever did in her full-time role in schools.
Ms Dinnage, whose husband is also working part-time in retail, tells i becoming a part-time tutor has totally transformed her perspective on work and .
“I love working in education, but working in a school brings with it all sorts of stresses which are not there when you’re tutoring on a one-to-one basis.

“When me and my husband were both working full-time, we felt we were working flat-out and our weekends were devoted to jobs and all the boring and necessary things and lo and behold, it would be Sunday evening and Monday morning again.
“But now I enjoy my work so much and moving to part-time work has given me so much more time for other things, that I never want to retire and want tutoring to be a part of my life forever.
“Many people can’t wait to retire because they don’t particularly enjoy what they are doing and it is a drudge.
“However, I love what I do so much that I don’t ever want to retire. If the children would be happy to have an 85-year-old tutor teaching them, I would willingly do it until that age and beyond.”
She added: “The word ‘retire’ is like a dirty word in our house as my husband also loves working part-time and the flexible nature of it.”

Ms Dinnage explained that moving to part-time working has allowed her to look after her elderly parents, including visiting her mother who is in a care home. It has also given her more opportunities to socialise with friends and pursue interests such as joining a book club.

She and her husband also have a dog now – something she says they could never have done while they were both working full-time. As well as having time for dog walks, as she and her husband both work part-time hours, they even have time to enjoy the occasional lunch together.

“Life has never been better and I can’t even bring myself to call what I do a job, because it has become such a part of me,” she said. “I never have the Sunday night blues and work feels so much more rewarding and I’m not bogged down with all the form filling and data collection that runs alongside with working in a huge secondary school.
“A job used to be more of a necessity than a pleasure, but now that has completely changed. Working is still a necessity in terms of that we do have to earn that income.
“But if you’re earning it and enjoying it at the same time, then it is the best of all worlds.”
The new data from the ONS about the record number of older people in their fifties and older are in part-time work was analysed by Rest Less, a digital community and advocate for those aged over 50.

It found that 42 per cent of the UK’s part-time workers are aged over 50 and that at least 40 per cent of workers aged 60 to 64 are part-time and 66 per cent of workers aged over 65 are working part-time. The is 66.
Stuart Lewis, chief executive of , told i there are positive and negative reasons behind the shift in work and retirement among the over-50s.
“On the one hand, it is a positive thing as more and more people are reframing their relationship with retirement,” he said.
“There is a growing body of evidence to show that working for four or five decades before suddenly retiring cold turkey is actually bad for people’s health and wellbeing.

“So it is a positive that more people are choosing to glide into retirement with this transition period of working part-time where they might be looking for a bit more flexibility for life around work, rather than ‘nothingness’.
“However, on the more negative side behind this, there are concerns some people may be working part-time when they are older, .”

Mr Lewis explained that the reasons behind this include that many people in their fifties and sixties are the “”, where they have responsibilities caring for their elderly parents in their eighties and nineties, while maybe also having dependents at home with their own children and grandchildren.

He says other reasons include more people working part-time for health reasons and fitting around medical appointments and treatment and people needing to work part-time due to and struggling to rely on the .
“There are also people who cannot find permanent or meaningful work due to age discrimination, which is still very widespread,” he added.
“There is great inequality when it comes to in this country.”

title: ‘I’ve opted out of saving into my pension – even though I will end up regretting it when I hit 60’
lead: Cutting back on your pension contributions can leave you with less money in retirement – though many opt-out to have extra cash up front
author: Callum Mason

body.text: Inflation may be going down – and interest rates paused – but this doesn’t mean people’s financial worries are over.
Among the more dramatic solutions to make ends meet is to pause or stop pension contributions altogether, something on the increase.

Some 51 per cent of employers said employees have requested to cut pension contributions, and 47 per cent have seen them ask to halt contributions altogether, according to LCP’s 2023 Financial Wellbeing study.
Jennifer Page is one such person who has currently opted out of the  that her employer, a teaching supply agency, opts staff into, but knows she will likely end up regretting this in the future.
The 40-year-old primary school teacher, who lives in Birmingham, has  twice in the past three years and says she did so “for purely financial reasons” both times.
In 2020, she retrained to work in schools after a career in sales, but by doing so, her salary halved.
“I pretty much budgeted to the narrowest of narrow margins.  – it was only a small amount but I just couldn’t stretch that far,” she says.
She  of her scheme in the second year after her career switch.

“My salary went up a bit and I could have just about afforded it, but my had been so depleted and I needed money for things like Christmas and buying birthday presents. I needed a year to get that breathing space,” she explains.

She then chose to opt in again but has since pulled out once more after leaving her full-time teaching post – where she was eligible for the generous Teachers Pension Scheme – and becoming a supply worker for an agency.
“I know I may need it and I know when I get into my sixties you’ll possibly regret it, but it’s an awful dilemma to have,” she says.
“I know it’s for and that’s the whole point, but it’s difficult to tie up money knowing you can’t get it for 20 years or so.”
Under UK law, if you’re employed, your employer must automatically enrol you into a pension scheme and make contributions to it if you are over 22 and earn £10,000 or more per year.
They must contribute at least 3 per cent, with the total minimum contribution being 8 per cent – and people who pay income tax also get tax relief on the money.
The tax relief and the money from your employer are clearly a boon – especially as research suggests you need a £23,300 per year income to live a “moderate” lifestyle in retirement.
But in the current financial climate, Jen is not alone.
According to recent research from Hargreaves Lansdown, more than one in five people have stopped or cut back pension contributions as a result of the .
Men were also more likely to have made changes, with 25 per cent reducing or halting contributions, compared to 18 per cent of women.
Chris Brooker, 47, from Bristol is another who is opting to forgo his pension.

The dad-of-three became  in 2016, running a smart technology business as a sole trade. Self-employed people get the same tax advantages that an employed person would, including 20 per cent relief added to the pension pot, and the ability to claim extra tax relief as a higher-rate taxpayer.
But Chris has chosen not to take advantage of this.
“I paid into a pension straight way from the age of 21, as my first job was as a computer programmer for a pensions software company, and paid into various pots after this,” he says.

“I know that currently with the money I have, I actually don’t have quite enough to live off, but with what I do have, hopefully having the mortgage paid off and more, I’d have options. And my money is actually outperforming my wife’s, even though she’s been paying in to a pot for years,” he adds.
Chris says at the moment, he would not pay into a pension until he was making enough to be a high-rate tax payer, and got extra relief on contributions.

“If I had spare money, and the choice was to put it into a pension, spend it, or put it into another form of like , I would say putting it into a pension would probably be last on my list. If I invest it in an Isa, then if I suddenly need it – if I have a couple of hard years, if the car blows up – I’ve got that money, whereas a pension is very inflexible.
“Especially without having the extra tax relief, I’d rather keep some of the money or invest it in my business or use it for my family,” he says.

In the past two years, a third of all workers have looked into reducing or stopping their pension contributions according to research from Royal London – and this rises to 49 per cent of workers aged 18-34.
But although stopping paying into a pension can bump up your annual salary, it can also cost you significantly in the long-term.

A worker on £35,000 paying 5 per cent of their wage into a pension would boost their take-home pay by £1,404 per year, but would lose out on £4,092 per year in pension savings, as a result of losing money from their employer – if they matched their contributions – and tax relief, according to Royal London.
Becky O’Connor, director of public affairs at PensionBee, said that while cutting pension contributions was “understandable” for many, the consequences should be weighed up.

“Life moves quickly, and before you know it, you might’ve kicked the can too far down the road and end up needing to give up work without having enough to fall back on to even cover basic living costs,” she said.

“If you are also likely to have housing costs when you hit retirement age, you’ll need even more in your pension pot to cover them – something for people who expect to be paying rent or a mortgage into their sixties to consider.

“Before giving up pension contributions, make sure you’ve cut out any excess spending. If you have no choice and just need to do it, keep things under review and reintroduce pension saving when you can. Your future self will thank you for it.”

Most people pay their pensions into a ‘defined contribution’ scheme, whereby their money goes into a savings pot, and grows over time as it is invested. Therefore, the more you save earlier, the more your pot could grow.

In 20 years’ time the £4,092 a year someone would lose through opting out of their workplace pension could have boosted the pension pot by £10,575 through investment growth had the contributions not been paused.

title: Government threatened with legal action after North Sea oil field go-ahead sparks green fury
lead: Greenpeace said approval of the Rosebank North Sea oil and gas field will give ‘carte blanche to fossil fuel companies to ruin the climate’
author: David Connett

body.text: The Government has been threatened with the prospect of a legal challenge over the decision to approve development of the Rosebank North Sea oil and gas field.
The said Rosebank, one of the largest untapped fields in the North Sea, could be developed. It is expected to produce 500 million barrels of oil in its lifetime.

But the move has been attacked by environmental groups, reigniting the debate around Britain’s climate change strategy after Rishi Sunak last week watered down the country’s interim plans to hit the 2050 net-zero target.

Tessa Khan of , called it a “rip-off”, adding: “It’s another case of the Government allowing foreign companies to profit, while the costs are put on British people who worry about the world we are handing on to our children.

“Rosebank will do nothing to lower fuel bills or boost UK energy security. Most of this oil will be shipped abroad and then sold back to use at whatever price makes the oil and gas industry the most profit.
“There are strong grounds to believe that the way this Government has come to this decision is unlawful and we will see them in court if so.”
Green MP  called it “the greatest act of environmental vandalism in my lifetime.”

She tweeted: “Rosebank oilfield just given go-ahead – the greatest act of environmental vandalism in my lifetime, causing emissions equal to 28 lowest income countries, busting climate targets & doing nothing for energy security since vast majority is for export. #climatecriminals.”
Phil Richards of Greenpeace UK said the decision amounted to “carte blanche to fossil fuel companies to ruin the climate”.

Last month 50 cross-party MPs and members of the House of Lords urged ministers to block Rosebank, warning that it could produce 200m tonnes of carbon dioxide. They claimed that most of the cost would fall on UK taxpayers.
The decision allows Norwegian oil and gas firm Equinor and its UK partner Ithaca Energy to begin drilling at the field, which lies north-west of Shetland. It  from environmental groups.

Energy Security Secretary Claire Coutinho welcomed the decision, saying that the regulator, the North Sea Transition Authority (NSTA), had given approval after “extensive scrutiny, including undergoing a detailed environmental impact assessment process and a period of public consultation.

“We are investing on our world-leading renewable energy but, as the independent Climate Change Committee recognises, we will need oil and gas as part of that mix on the path to net zero and so it makes sense to use our own supplies from North Sea fields such as Rosebank.
“The jobs and billions of pounds this is worth to our economy will enable us to have greater energy independence, making us more secure against tyrants like [Vladimir] Putin.
“We will continue to back the UK’s oil and gas industry to underpin our energy security, grow our economy and help us deliver the transition to cheaper, cleaner energy.”
The  in Britain, supporting up to 1,600 jobs during construction. First production is expected in 2026-27.

It said new projects like Rosebank are expected to be significantly less emissions intensive than previous developments, as they are more efficient and are developed with measures to mitigate emissions.

It added: “Even when we’ve reached net zero in 2050, the Climate Change Committee says that a quarter of our energy needs will come from oil and gas, but the choice is between it coming from hostile states rather than from the supplies we have here at home.”

title: Government-owned British Business Bank records £147m loss
lead: The bank has said UK taxpayers will feel the long-term benefits of it investing billions of pounds into small firms
author: Anna Wise

body.text: The Government-owned British Business Bank has said UK taxpayers will feel the long-term benefits of it billions of pounds into small firms after revealing that it swung to a loss of more than £147m last year.
The UK’s economic development bank said it was affected by wider economic difficulties which led to a drop in the valuation of firms it invests in.
It reported a pre-tax loss for the year to the end of March of £147.3m, compared to a profit of £604.8m the previous year.
The bank, which lends money to and buys stakes in  to help them start and grow, made £1.6bn worth of funding agreements during the latest year.
UK taxpayers, who back the bank, have “not lost any money”, chief executive Louis Taylor made clear.
Mr Taylor said: “I think we generate a good return for the taxpayer.
“These are long-term and we are confident that over time, when we actually realise these investments, they will yield profitable growth for us but also real social benefit for the economy.”
The bank said it had been affected by falls in the market valuations of companies, especially in the technology sector which saw valuations cut after the pandemic.
But it said the drop in valuations and a consequent loss was expected after investing more in recent years.
The bank’s Start Up Loans programme recently reached a milestone of £1bn in lending, with more than half the funding going to small businesses run by women and people from ethnic minorities.
The scheme targets underrepresented groups who are excluded from mainstream finance to help them start a business, and regions beyond London and the South East.
Nearly all of its funding is given by providers outside of the “big five” British .

“The bank is more than self-sufficient in terms of operating itself from the income it generates from the portfolio,” Mr Taylor said. “If you add in the social value of what we do, [the return] is very high indeed.”
The bank boss said UK’s smaller businesses are feeling more cautious now than in recent months amid higher and uncertainty over the future of the economy.
He added: “There are a lot of companies we see that have investment plans, but are waiting for the right time where they feel more confident to launch them.”

title: Interest rate held at 5.25% by Bank of England: Here’s what it means for your mortgage and savings
lead: The Bank has paused upping rates after increasing it 14 times in a row
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: The Bank of England has held the base rate at 5.25 per cent this lunchtime, for the first time since December 2021.
It had been increased 14 times in a row, but the Bank has decided to pause these hikes following the surprise news that inflation had fallen slightly to 6.7 per cent yesterday.
While good news, the Bank is still struggling to bring it down to its two per cent target. It has now said it expected it would reach this target by the second quarter of 2025.
A rise was expected although there are hopes from economists that the rate rises may now have reached their peak.

The Bank’s Monetary Policy Committee (MPC), which sets rates, voted 5 – 4 to hold. Four members preferred to increase Bank Rate by 0.25 percentage points, to 5.5 per cent. Governor Andrew Bailey, who had the casting vote, chose to hold.

Bailey said today: “Inflation has fallen a lot in recent months, and we think it will continue to do so. But there is no room for complacency. We need to be sure inflation returns to normal and we continue to take the decisions necessary to do just that.”

The Chancellor, Jeremy Hunt, added: “We are starting to see the tide turn against high inflation, but we will continue to do what we can to help households struggling with mortgage payments. Now is the time to see the job through. We are on track to halve inflation this year and sticking to our plan is the only way to bring interest and mortgage rates down.”
Here, i examines what this rise means for your money.

Millions of homeowners have had their  However, rates have been decreasing in the past couple of weeks as swap rates have stabilised. It is hoped they could fall further as the base rate hikes have been paused.

Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, said: “There has been a steady decline in swap rates in recent days, which has resulted in many lenders reducing rates on both residential and buy-to-let products, which is welcome news for mortgage holders. Whether today’s hold is a sign of future long-term direction remain to be seen.”
Exactly how you will be affected by today’s decision
Tracker mortgages
About 8 per cent of customers are on these – a type of loan that literally tracks the Bank’s base rate, with added interest on top. If you’re on one, your payments will stay the same.
Standard variable rate (SVR) mortgages
Around 9 per cent of customers are on these – they do not have to follow the Bank of England’s interest rate, though they generally do. A pause means they will hopefully not see an increase.
Fixed mortgages

Some 81 per cent of customers are on these and they have locked in an interest rate for a set period of time – usually two or five years – so their payments will not change based on today’s interest rate announcement.
The average two-year fixed rate is now 6.66 per cent, although mortgage lenders are now decreasing rates and so it is hoped this will fall.

If you are coming off a fixed-rate deal on to a new deal, you are likely to pay a far higher interest rate – though this is not directly affected by the Bank rate changing today and is instead the accumulative impact of rate rises.
What should you do if you cannot already afford higher payments?

If you are on a tracker, talk to your lender, who are obligated to take your concerns seriously. They may be able to offer you to extend the term of your mortgage or allow you go on an interest-only loan for a period of time. This will lower monthly payments in the short-term but, ultimately, you will pay more in interest. They may also be able to organise a “payment holiday”, which means a short break from paying your mortgage.

If you are remortgaging from a cheap fixed-rate mortgage, the best plan is to speak to a broker, who can see what the cheapest deal is, factoring in fees. You may wish to extend the term of your mortgage but, as discussed above, it will cost you more in the long-term.

If you have a spare room, you could also consider taking in a lodger to help you with your mortgage payments. You can earn £7,500 tax-free when you rent out a furnished room in your home under the Rent a Room Scheme.
What does this mean for renters?

Renting costs are not directly affected by the Bank of England base rate rise but mortgages have been getting more expensive for buy-to-let landlords who borrowed money to purchase their property, some are passing on the costs to their tenants.

If you are a renter, make sure you know your rights around when a landlord can increase your rent and by how much. If you feel the rent increases are unjustified, you can go to a rental tribunal, where a judge will decide what is fair.

One of the best outcomes from rising  As it has paused, it is possible some lenders may increase rates although many won’t increase them at all, especially as they have been increasing in recent times.

Savers might be surprised by how quickly banks are passing on the rate increase this time, thanks to the Financial Conduct Authority’s 14-point action plan, which effectively shames banks into passing on the rate rises to savers.
Experts are now saying it is a good time to review the returns you are getting, as rates are likely to be either reaching their peak or have peaked.

Anna Bowes, founder of the Savings Champion website, said: “The good news is that savings rates have once again become far more tethered to what happens to the Bank of England base rate. If you haven’t reviewed your savings accounts recently, now is a good time to do so as you could well increase the interest you are earning.”

Pensioners are one group who have been benefitting from interest rates. That said, any income they take from their pension may not be stretching as far as before due to the cost of living crisis and inflation, and they don’t have the same ability to earn more money (triple lock-excepted).
Thein line with inflation and is expected to rise by 8.5 per cent next April, increasing by earnings growth.
Had there been an increase, those with annuities would also likely have benefitted. An annuity provides you with a regular guaranteed income in retirement. You can buy an annuity

It is difficult to say exactly how much rates would go up by, given an increase, as annuities are largely priced on the direction of gilt yields and not the base rate per se (gilt is government debt).

Helen Morrissey, head of retirement analysis at Hargreaves Lansdown, said: “Annuities have proved to be a rare point of positivity in the current economic gloom as rates surged off the back of interest rate hikes. This time two years ago, a 65-year-old with a £100,000 pension could get an income of up to £4,941 per year from an annuity whereas today they could get £7,317.”

However, she added that after an initial period of rapid increase that peaked in the aftermath of the mini-Budget they have since settled down around their current level and though we may see a further small increase in incomes over the coming weeks it is unlikely to be huge.

A higher base rate is bad news for borrowers as more of their money is taken up by interest payments on loans, mortgages, credit cards and overdrafts. This means keeping it at a standstill may not be beneficial but at least it means there is less likelihood of higher interest payments.
If there is an increase, the interest rate on your credit card or overdraft could go up. However, your credit card provider must give you notice before this happens.

If you borrowed £1,000 on overdraft for a whole month at 39.9 per cent it would cost you £33.25, but on a credit card charging 21.9 per cent, it would cost £18.25. If you paid off your card statement balance in full, you’d pay no interest at all.
Therefore, those with large debts could explore signing up for a zero per cent balance transfer credit card that clears the debt with no interest applied for a set period.

title: Government’s first Investment Zone in Sheffield will create thousands of jobs, experts say
lead: South Yorkshire will be the first area to benefit from a scaled-back version of the Liz Truss policy
author: Steve Robson

body.text: The Government’s first Investment Zone will support a new research facility in Sheffield that is hoped will reduce the aviation industry’s carbon footprint and generate a £2bn industry.
Investment Zones were first announced by Liz Truss’ short-lived Government as a way of boosting economic growth in deprived areas and 38 local authorities were invited to bid for funding.
Earlier this year, Chancellor Jeremy Hunt , primarily around elite universities, which will benefit from £80m in funding and tax incentives to become research and development hubs.
Today the University of Sheffield confirmed it will be the first area in the country to receive support to further develop ground-breaking aerospace technology.
The aviation industry is estimated to need 40,000 new passenger jets over the next 20 years but is only on track to deliver around 12,000.
Engineers at the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC) have made a technological breakthrough which can reduce the manufacturing time of major components by up to 90 per cent.
It also means the components – such as parts of the wing and fuselage – are lighter and more aerodynamic making planes more fuel efficient.
The process has been achieved thanks to state-of-the-art robot automation which is now able to build to an accuracy of 0.1 milimetres.
The technology is already being used by elite car manufacturer McLaren on its chassis but could prove crucial for the future of the aviation industry as it transitions to greener fuels.
US giant Boeing will be the first partner for the research programme amid hopes it will help meet global demand.
Steve Foxley, chief executive of AMRC, told i: “Because we’ve got robotic experience elsewhere in the sector, we’ve been able to push robots beyond the boundaries of their current performance.
“It’s a game-changing improvement.”
The new project Composites at Speed and Scale (Compass) will be built as an extension one of AMRC’s Factory 2050 and one of the North of England’s largest ever research and innovation projects.
It will initially create around 50 jobs in South Yorkshire, but university bosses and the government believe it has the potential to create 3,000 jobs by the mid 2030s.
Mr Foxley hailed the support for the new facility as “fantastic” for Sheffield’s manufacturing sector.
“Manufacturing has been decimated in the past 30 or 40 years but we saw in Covid how critical it still is in the UK,” he added.
“There’s been a big push for reshoring and green shoring, this is really important for Sheffield.”
Boeing opened its first manufacturing plant in Europe in Sheffield in 2018 and the US company says the new facility will boost the potential for further growth.
Maria Laine, President of Boeing UK, Ireland and Nordic region, said: “This project is a testament to Boeing’s commitment to drive innovation and growth within the UK aerospace sector.
“Together with our world-leading industry partners, this investment is poised to revolutionise aerospace manufacturing to meet global demand, while supporting vital jobs and growth in the UK.”
Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt: “Our first Investment Zone is a shining example of how we will drive growth across the country.
“It’s already secured more than £80m of private investment, including backing from Boeing, and will help support more than 8,000 jobs by 2030.”

Secretary of State for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities Michael Gove said: “Today’s announcement is a significant moment for South Yorkshire as it becomes the home of England’s first advanced manufacturing Investment Zone. This will help level up the region, creating jobs and boosting economic growth.

“We want to build on South Yorkshire’s proud heritage so that it can make an even greater contribution to the UK economy. This is what levelling up is all about, promoting growth and providing opportunities so people can thrive in the communities they are from.”

title: ‘I’m putting the brakes on’: How rising interest rates have hammered small businesses
lead: Rates going up has ‘massively slowed down growth’, a business owner told i
author: Callum Mason

body.text: “I’ve had to be more cautious. If we weren’t in this situation, I’d have more confidence on bringing in an extra person but at the moment I’m putting the brakes on that.”

These are the thoughts of Hannah Viney, the founder of Sycamore Communications, who has said she has had to be more measured with her company’s growth in recent times following successive interest rate increases.

Ms Viney, who founded her firm five years ago just before the Covid pandemic, said there is “much less risking taking” now than there would have been in previous years. “I wouldn’t take out a loan to take a punt on investment now because it’d be so expensive,” she added.
She is just one of  grappling with the .

The interest rate determines the amount that banks are charged for borrowing from the Bank of England, and although most consumers see the effects of this in the form of higher mortgage costs, loans – including those offered to businesses and households – there is another knock-on effect.

“Small business confidence stalled significantly between the first and second quarters of the year, and interest rate rises are undoubtedly an important factor behind the fall,” explained Martin McTague, National Chair of the Federation of Small Businesses (FSB).
Viney’s business is now a six-figure company and has around 20 clients but admits she doesn’t want to make risky moves.

“The mortgage has gone up, so instead of pushing on, I’ve had to be more cautious. Cashflow is a concern because other clients are struggling financially, so there’s definitely a shift in mindset,” she added.
“I’m tentative in pushing on in terms of extra investment – that means putting off extra training for example as well.”

Interest rates are upped to bring down inflation, which  – far above the target rate of 2 per cent. The logic being that by increasing the cost of borrowing, spending is generally decreased, and thus price rises slow down as demand for goods fall.

But the downside of that, as well as decreasing people’s ability to buy, businesses themselves find it more expensive to get finance, meaning they often have to curtail creating new jobs, or new ventures.

“Low-cost finance for small firms has almost entirely disappeared,” explained Mr McTague. “It’s therefore sadly not surprising that some small firms have had to scale down or even shelved growth plans.”
Kamran Saleem, who runs a motoring business in the West Midlands, is having to change his plans.
The 41-year-old employs more than 30 staff at Motorserv-uk, a car service centre that also deals in used vehicles.
“We’re thinking about U-turning on the sales part of our business. It’s just not feasible anymore,” he said.

“Around 80 per cent of our cars are sold on finance, but headline rates [on finance loans] have gone up by 4 percentage points in the last year or so, so we’ve had an absolutely massive drop-off in purchases. It’s massively slowing down growth”, he told i.
Nick Staab, an entrepreneur and founder of the Elite Sales Academy, which works with businesses’ staff to improve their sales, has said the rising rates will have a big impact on new ventures.
“A lot of people are waiting for rates to come down and things to improve, meaning they have great ideas that they can’t get out there because they can’t get the finance,” he explained.
This cautiousness among firms is likely to curtail economic growth.

Stats released on Friday morning shows that the economy grew by just 0.2 per cent in the second quarter of the year, and although experts have said a recession – two quarters of successive negative growth – are likely to be avoided, a leading think-tank has highlighted that this means the period has been the .
Periods of low growth typically mean  and possibly lower wages as less jobs are created and retained.
So what should happen to rates? Mr Staab has said he recognises that inflation needs to come down, as this a “challenge,” to businesses too in terms of the increased costs it poses.
Mr Saleem has said that he now thinks interest rates need to come down though.
“I’d really want to see lower interest rates – inflation is coming down already and a lot of people are at breaking point in terms of mortgages,” he explained.

He has said he wants to see tax breaks for small businesses as well. The FSB has specific demands: increasing the VAT threshold to £100,000, tackling late payment to get cash moving through supply chains, and taking more small firms out of paying business rates would “all provide immediate relief to hard-pressed small businesses who feel hemmed in on all sides by costs,” it has said.

A spokesperson for HM Treasury said: “We’re committed to boosting the growth of small businesses, which is why we have supported them throughout the pandemic and Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, which since last year includes a £13.6billion business rates package slashing bills, a £27billion effective cut to corporation tax through full expensing, energy bills protection, £10billion in fuel duty cuts and simplifications to the tax system to save firms time and money.
“The UK has a higher VAT registration threshold than any EU member state and the second highest in the OECD, which keeps most businesses out of VAT altogether.”

title: How I Make My Money: Graphic designer on £2.5k per month with a £1.5k vegan shampoo side hustle
lead: Nicola Wordsworth would love to go full-time with her side-hustle of making vegan shampoo for dogs – and dreams of investment from Dragon’s Den star Deborah Meaden
author: Jane Denton

body.text: In our  we aim to find out how people in the UK are earning their cash and making a living.

This week we speak to Nicola Wordsworth, 56, who lives in Minnis Bay, Kent, with her two dogs, Bertie and Mabel. Nicola has one daughter, Emily, 29. By day, Nicola is a graphic designer, but she’s also running a blossoming side-hustle shampoo bar business for dogs, Pup Suds. She used to make 100 shampoo bars a night in a tiny household kitchen and has ambitions to get on Dragon’s Den and secure an investment from multi-millionaire businesswoman Deborah Meaden.
Income: I make £2,500 a month from my job as a senior graphic designer and studio manager at Whybrow Studio. I make about £1,500 a month from my side-hustle business, Pup Suds.
My main monthly outgoings: Mortgage, £550; groceries, £300; utility bills, £300; council tax, £145; car fuel, £100; car lease, £150.

By day I work as a senior graphic designer and studio manager at Whybrow Studio in Margate. I work four days a week, earning £2,500 a month. I work on large-scale jobs, often pulling together tenders for projects worth more than £400,000, and work with clients like the British Library and Castle Howard.

I’m also a massive dog lover. My eldest dog, a Tibetan Terrier, Bertie, is divine. He’s totally zen and makes me late for everything as people are always stopping to tell me how gorgeous he is; and, boy, does he know it! Recently, I’ve got Bertie’s niece, Mabel, who is eight weeks old. She is causing me many sleepless nights as she settles in.

Up to three days a week, including weekends, and three evenings a week, I work, along with my daughter, on my burgeoning , . I set it up during lockdown as most of my work dried up and I wanted to keep busy. I make solid vegan shampoo bars for dogs. Naturally, Bertie was my inspiration for the business, as he is always up to his belly in seaweed, sand and water and sometimes rolls around in stinky stuff. Most of the products I tried on him weren’t very good or eco-friendly. He’s become the poster boy for Pup Suds.
I managed to save myself about £20,000 in set-up costs as I was able to do things like get a website going and sort out the branding for the business myself.

At the moment I make about £1,500 a month from my side-hustle and can sell anything from 10 solid shampoo bars a week to more than 200 a week. The best seller by far is the “Massaging Anti-Stink Anti-Fox Poo’ bar, which is £10. My costs have been rising so I might have to increase my prices, but I don’t want to. I like the fact I don’t have to deal with pitches or proposals all the time. People either buy the products or they don’t. I get a real buzz getting up in the morning and finding orders in the online basket. We also go to fairs and dog shows.

Wholesalers have become involved, and we sell products in some overseas locations too now. We have even secured a potential listing with a UK-based retailer in Dubai to sell our products in fifteen stores out there. However, this deal is, for one reason or another, in limbo.

When I first started my side-hustle, my family and friends were a little sceptical and thought it was just a little hobby. But since making lots of sales and even winning awards, they are now fully behind it and proud of my achievements.

Getting the production line in order at the beginning was a challenge. I used to make 100 shampoo bars a night in a small standard kitchen in my former house. I had the best smelling house for miles, but it was tough juggling a production line and cramming worktops, a desk and dining table with the moulds needed.

Bringing in extra income from Pup Suds has been really helpful. I moved house, to what I call my “Old Lady Bungalow”, in December last year. With additional income coming in I was able to sort out a garage conversion for my new home, at a cost of £15,000. I’ve created a bespoke production line and manufacturing space in the garage. I’ve gone for the industrial look and have a commercial microwave and mixer, which I use for some of the products. I can now grow the business, before eventually taking the plunge and renting a unit somewhere.

I’m so tempted to get on the BBC television show Dragon’s Den and try to secure an investment for Pup Suds. I think my products are right up their street, particularly for Deborah Meaden. The prospect of investment is somewhat daunting as it’s not something I have experience of, but it’s an exciting proposition.

It would be great to be able to make about £100,000 a year from my business. I don’t necessarily want the stress that goes with having a multi-million pound business, as I have run a large business before, and it is very stressful and can stop being fun. But I still want to make Pup Suds into a decent business and even better than it is now.

I would love to be able to give up my day job as a graphic designer and focus on my side-hustle business full-time. I’d be able to work with dogs every day, and having the opportunity to run a family business with my daughter full-time would be a dream. If we secure more retailers this could happen sooner rather than later!
