title: ‘The cost of insuring our two Teslas has gone up to £5.6k a year’: Why electric car insurance is so expensive
lead: Electric vehicles are often more costly to insure although insurance costs are going up for all vehicles
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Alex Gosney and his wife, Rachel, expected an increase when they asked for a car insurance renewal quote for their two Teslas, as Alex had received three points for speeding.
But even so the quote they received shocked them: their bill . Put another way, the bill just for their car insurance alone is now £450 a month.
“This is an increase of £3,800 – an amount we just did not expect,” said Alex, 34, who owns one Tesla outright and with his wife pays off the other one each
“If one of the cars wasn’t leased, we would have given it up, but we do have two young children we need to take to school and we both work full time, so having two cars is convenient,” he added.
The Gosneys say that they will consider other makes of car in future

The initial quote came from their existing insurer, Admiral. They turned to comparison sites to see if there were any better offers, and then a broker – but all to no avail. And so they stuck with the first offer.

“In fact, Admiral seemed to have the best deal. One of the quotes that came back was for £8,000,” Alex said. “We are fortunate that we have two incomes and so can just about afford it but other families will not be so lucky.

“For our next car, we will have to do more research to see which vehicles are cheaper to insure. If a hybrid is cheaper we will opt for that but for sustainability purposes, we’re going backwards to go forwards.”
Why have insurance costs for electric vehicles gone up so much?
One of the main reasons why policies can be so extortionate is because Teslas are electric vehicles, which are more expensive to insure because their repair costs are higher.

Figures from the price comparison site Compare the Market show that the cost of car insurance is rising faster for electric vehicles than petrol-fuelled cars. The typical EV premium has risen by £274 year-on-year, while insurance for a petrol-fuelled car has increased by £250.

Julie Daniels, a motor insurance expert at Compare the Market, said: “This increase may in part be due to insurers facing higher repair costs. The rapid rise in inflation will have probably affected many areas of the motor repair industry including the cost of spare parts, energy and hiring specialist mechanics.

“Insurance for EVs usually costs more as these cars are typically more expensive to purchase than petrol-fuelled equivalents. This means these vehicles are often also more costly to repair or replace. Replacing some parts of electric vehicles such as new batteries can be particularly costly.”
Batteries drive up the cost of electric car insurance so much as all use lithium ion batteries which are complex and expensive to repair or replace.
Data from the insurer Axa also recently revealed that when electric cars crash, they are more expensive to fix and can do more damage than other vehicles.

Louise Thomas, a motoring expert at , said: “EVs typically use smarter technology or have more expensive parts than others so if an EV driver ever needed to make a claim, this would more likely cost their insurer a lot more to repair or replace compared to other vehicles. This includes smaller claims, too.”
While shopping around for a quote can help to curb some of the costs, car insurance prices are going up across the board.
The average bill is now £511, and the industry blames and increased repair costs for the steep increases, which are expected to continue.

title: I had to sell my car because my insurance went up by nearly 50%
lead: The cost of owning a car has soared for many drivers, leaving them with a difficult decision as to whether they can afford it anymore
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Amy Downes had been driving a car for 17 years but said the increasing costs of tax, petrol and
“I feel like I’ve lost my independence, but the costs were too high,” says Amy, a 39-year-old freelance writer who lives in Leeds with her husband and two children.
“I’ve been driving for nearly 20 years and live far from my family so it made seeing them easier and it was good to be able to take my children everywhere.”
What made the decision was the , which went up £121 this year – a rise of 48 per.  Then there was the bigger tax bill, which has risen from £165 to £216 since 2016.
“My husband and I were shocked when we received the insurance bill. This alongside paying £60 for fuel each month.”

On average, car insurance has soared , according to the Office for National Statistics. The average bill is now £511, and the industry blames and increased repair costs for the steep increases, which are expected to continue. August also fuel price rises, the RAC said, as the price of petrol rose by 6.68p a litre while diesel shot up by 8p.
This has left some with difficult choices about whether owning a car is now financially feasible.

Amy said it started to become much easier to spend £5 for her and her sons, ages seven and four, to get return bus tickets when heading out for the day as opposed to spending larger sums on filling up her car with petrol. Her husband has still kept his car, which he uses to commute to work.

“My eldest has now started school which is in walking distance. As I am self employed, there are also times I am struggling for income which means unexpected costs, like repairs, can be difficult to manage.”
However, she admits it was a difficult decision to make.

“It was a massive decision but it was just not viable anymore. We were told replacing our tyres in the MOT would cost £300 while to repair the clutch it would cost £325. It felt like it was only going to get worse financially.”

Other costs that factored into the decision to sell included the fact it was a struggle to clean the vehicle as they have no access to a hose at home and the expense of parking. The environmental impact of owning a petrol car also swayed her decision.
Unfortunately, when the couple did sell the car, they got far less than expected. They had bought the Peugeot 206 in 2015, second hand, for £4,000.
However, they only got £260 for it on WeBuyAnyCar.com last month.
“This was very disappointing as we were hoping to use the money from the sale to go towards our other .”
Even though she hopes that by selling her car, she will now be more comfortable financially, Amy said it has left her with much less freedom.

“The fact I can’t just pack up and go is difficult. I am missing out on networking opportunities as I can’t easily get there. There has been a fair bit of sacrifice. But the car felt like a luxury at a time I’m not convinced we should have so many.”

title: I lost £2,000 on a cancelled wedding after discovering my fiancé cheated on me
lead: The breakdown of my relationship led to a financial nightmare – ensure you and our ex both share the burden
author: Nicholas Fearn

body.text: In January, my life took a sudden turn when  during a New Year’s Eve party. His cheating broke not only my heart but also my bank account, as we broke up and I had to cancel our wedding due to happen this year.  I had spent , and once I returned home to Wales without him, I faced the reality of rebuilding my life as a single man and climbing out of a financial hole.

While I wasn’t in a fit state to cancel our wedding, it was a necessary first step in sorting my financial affairs following the messy break-up., I struggle to speak to people on the phone. Luckily, my mum was on hand to make all the important calls. The wedding venue was the first place to ring, and this was an awkward prospect as my fiancé worked there.

After explaining my situation and signing a cancellation form, we were told the venue couldn’t return the £500 deposit as it was non-refundable. This was just the tip of the iceberg when it came to the cash I would lose from the wedding.

I also paid £100 for make-up, £350 for a car, £350 for a cake, £300 for a videographer, £100 for a photographer, £200 for flowers, and around £50 for decorations purchased via Facebook marketplaces. That nearly adds up to £2,000.

The only silver lining was that the cake maker agreed to provide me and my family with cakes up to the value of £350. This will be very useful for future birthday cakes, although I’d still prefer to have an extra £350 in my back pocket to spend on.

Within a few days, my parents had made all the necessary phone calls, and my wedding was officially cancelled. Although this felt like a weight off my shoulders, losing such a large amount of money during  was a difficult pill to swallow. And because I decided to keep the flat to myself, this money would have helped me pay rent and other bills as I no longer had my partner to cover half of the costs.

Either way, I didn’t want to move back home: it would have felt like going backwards. Unfortunately, taking over the tenancy and bills wasn’t an easy process. Many bills, including council tax and the electric and gas top-app app were in my ex’s name.

My parents ran the electric and gas companies and the local council to put the accounts in my name. For nearly a week, I could not top up my electricity and gas, so I faced the  prospect of having no heating and electricity during the cold winter months.

The Sky TV and broadband were also in my ex’s name, and  it was eventually easier to move contract with  BT, although the Wi-Fi wouldn’t be up and running for several weeks. This made life incredibly difficult for me as a freelancer – I rely on a solid internet connection to work. A new TV cost me nearly £500, too.

We also had three and two . Due to my disabilities, I was not in a position to care for all these animals. Nor could I afford to pay for all their food and vet fees. I ended up rehoming one of the rabbits and the two guinea pigs and keeping two of the rabbits. But it’s actually my brother who cleans them, as I have severe OCD.

Months later, I’m in a much better position. I live alone, but this wouldn’t be possible without the help of my. My brother cleans the flat once a week, while my parents manage all of my bills. They even  for me and regularly check in to ensure I stick to it.
My intention isn’t to sound bitter but I think it’s vital that people remember that relationships don’t always last forever and that.

title: Money Clinic: ‘My partner and I have separated but he won’t continue paying our mortgage. What can I do?’
lead: Nicholas Mendes helps a reader who has been caught out by their partner refusing to continue paying their mortgage
author: Nicholas Mendes

body.text: Is the mortgage market turbulence getting you down? Have you got a mortgage-related question you need answering? Email in and we’ll get one of our experts to reply. Nick Mendes, mortgage technical manager at John Charcol, has given his advice to a reader below. If you have a question for our experts, email us at

Question: My ex-partner and I have recently separated after eight years together. We lived together in a home we jointly bought, and we had a joint mortgage. He’s now moved out, and is renting, as it wasn’t feasible for us to continue to live together after the split. The only problem is he has now said he won’t continue. Is there anything I can do in this situation? What are my rights?

Answer: Going through divorce or separation is . That said, it’s actually not uncommon for one partner to move out and refuse to maintain the mortgage payments or uphold their end of an agreement when it comes to financial outgoing.
Be reassured that . There will be some extremely severe consequences if they try to.

The first thing I would recommend you do in this situation is to inform your lender. You should then consider seeking legal advice. Lenders will show leniency when mortgages are kept up to date, which means they could look to reduce your monthly payments by converting to interest only or extending the term.
Lenders could also look to change the mortgage from a joint to a sole depending on affordability.

With a joint mortgage you and your ex-partner are both equally liable for the mortgage and moving out of the property doesn’t relinquish your agreement with the lender. A lender can choose to chase either party jointly or individually for payment including any costs, legals fees or loss made upon any possible repossession.

If one party chooses to not pay it is important that the other party doesn’t follow the same course, as refusing to pay the mortgage can impact your credit file meaning it will be harder to secure a mortgage or credit in the future.
In the event your existing lender doesn’t deem it would be affordable to transfer the mortgage into your sole name you could consider any of the following –
I would recommend you speak with your lender to understand your options, it would also be advisable to speak with a solicitor to understand other options.
Lastly, speak with a broker. If you existing lender doesn’t feel that the mortgage is affordable one lender view doesn’t reflect the market.
A mortgage broker will be able to review your circumstances and potentially find another lender that can raise the funds you need to clear the mortgage and refinance into your sole name.

title: How being LGBTQ+  can affect your money, from higher property costs to lower salaries and smaller pensions
lead: Having a gender identity outside of the “norm” means you are likely to encounter several inequalities
author: Annabelle Williams

body.text: and shining a light on areas that are often overlooked – such as how sexual orientation or gender identity interacts with a person’s ability to thrive financially.
While everyone grapples with money and no one finds it easy to increase their pay, build a decent retirement fund or reach their financial goals, LGBTQ+ people can face additional barriers.

That is not to say that all LGBTQ+ people are worse off or face the same issues.  It does mean it is important to recognise that, despite all the progress that’s been made for LGBTQ+ equity and inclusion, even today life paths that differ from “the norm” and the impact of discrimination in the past or present all come with a cost.
In other ways, being LGBTQ+ just means having additional things to consider when it comes to financial planning.
Here are some of the factors that may affect an LGBTQ+ person’s finances.

It is difficult to build a full picture of how being LGBTQ+ affects a person financially because population data has typically been gathered using traditional definitions of “male”, “female”, “husband” and “wife”. What we know about people’s earnings, tax, pensions, credit scores, mortgages – virtually every aspect of money – is based on this assumption of a gender binary.

There is increasing recognition these data models don’t tell the full story and things are changing – for example, the Census asked about gender identity and sexual orientation for the first time in 2021 – but it will take time before the data gap is bridged.
Academic studies from around the world are filling part of the data gap. Some findings include:

Living in a neighbourhood where they’ll feel safe and supported by others like them . But renting or buying a home in one of the big LGBTQ+ communities in Manchester, Brighton or London can cost significantly more than elsewhere. Even within those cities, a person who identifies as LGBTQ+ will still probably have to spend more to be able to buy or rent in an area that feels progressive and accepting.

It takes a national average of 5.7 years for a first-time buyer to save a deposit with the help of the Lifetime ISA,. But for a first home in Brighton it would take 8.8 years and in London it would be 10.8 years.

Higher property prices in these areas can be a factor when it comes to retirement planning, as homeowners often downsize to a smaller property in a cheaper area when they are older, to release equity from their home which they live off in retirement. Someone who is LGBTQ+ may be less willing to move away from the community or feel they have fewer choices about where to live. This underscores why it is so important to have pension savings, rather than relying on property wealth for retirement.
Despite all the progress made for LGBTQ+ equality, discrimination persists. Studies have found gay men and lesbian women are less likely to be invited for a job interview,  and .

It’s still not easy to be “out” in the workplace. Sometimes people “go back in the closet” when they change job, if they sense the environment is not safe. Stress from the ongoing effort of modifying behaviour to fit in at work, changing a partner’s pronouns or dodging the topic during office chats about family or holiday plans can take its toll and people in this situation are less likely to stay in their job.
The flipside is that many employers value the benefits of a diverse workforce. LGBTQ+ people’s careers can thrive even more when they find an inclusive organisation with the right cultural fit.

Campaigners have successfully challenged historical discriminatory policies in all areas of life, including financial services. For example, until rules were changed in 1994, insurers would ask customers if they had ever taken a HIV test in the assumption that testing was an indicator of someone having a “riskier” lifestyle.

In the past, pension providers did not recognise same-sex partners when it came to “survivor benefits’” This meant that when a straight person died their remaining pension went to their opposite-sex partner, but when someone in a same-sex relationship died their pension went with them. Since 2017 same-sex couples have had the same rights – not very long ago.
While laws and social norms have changed, it is understandable that some LGBTQ+ individuals might have bitter memories or continue to feel alienated by industries that did not support them.
There is still work that needs to be done and things are far from perfect, but banks, investment managers, financial advisers and pension providers are trying harder to ‘speak’ to LGBTQ+ customers.

Tweaks to policies such as using customers’ preferred pronouns or offering gender-neutral titles may be small ways of showing respect towards different identities, but over time their impact could be much bigger.

By knowing who their customers really are, companies can help with financial inclusion, close the data gap and create services tailored to the individual, regardless of someone’s sexual orientation or gender identity.
Annabelle Williams is a personal finance specialist at Nutmeg

title: Hidden mortgage fees mean homeowners could be paying more than ever despite rates falling
lead: Some homeowners could find they are paying more on their mortgage now than when rates were at their peak
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Mortgage holders could find themselves paying more now than whenhave been found to be upping their fees by as much as 60 per cent.
Some leading two-year fixed deals in July, proved to be cheaper than those currently on the market despite rates coming down, research by Which?, exclusive to i, reveals.
This is because providers are increasing their arrangement fee – also know as product fee – which most come with. They usually cost between £999 and £1,999 and are charged by lenders.
Now many providers are increasing these fees, offsetting mortgage rates coming down, with some charging nearly £3,000 – money which could
Skipton Building Society is the worst offender, charging £2,995 on its five-year deals for those with 10 per cent, 15 per cent and 25 per cent deposits.

Ele Clark, senior money editor at Which?, said: “While several lenders are reducing products’ headline rates, some have also hiked their arrangement fees, meaning that a number of borrowers could actually have secured a cheaper deal back in July, when mortgage rates were higher.
“The market is complicated for borrowers and choosing a new deal is not as straightforward as picking the cheapest rate – it’s vital to look at the overall cost.”

Which? compared the top 10 leading products available on 25 September with the top 10 deals available two months ago on 24 July across four different deposit brackets including 40, 25, 10 and 5 per cent deposits using Moneyfacts data.
Of the 40 leading products, 15 were fee-free in July. In contrast, on 25 September there were no fee-free products in the top 40.
The average fee for a product with a 40 per cent deposit was £718 in July, now this has risen to £1,157 – an increase of 61 per cent.
In July you wouldn’t have to scroll for long to get to the first fee-free deal, coming up first or second as the best rates but now fee-free deals are rare on market-leading rates.
On a 40 per cent deposit the 46th best rate was the first fee-free deal found.

Separate data from Moneyfacts found the average mortgage fee, including fee-free products, has risen for two consecutive months, increasing to £662 in September. This is the highest on its records since April 2021 (£663).

At the same time, average fixed rates dropped in September following sharp rises in the months prior. August 2023’s average two-year fixed rate at 6.85 per cent was the highest since August 2008 when it reached 6.94 per cent.
August’s average five-year fixed rate of 6.37 per cent was the highest since November 2008 when it rose to 6.41 per cent.
Now the average five-year deal is under 6 per cent and the average two-year deal is 6.5 per cent.

Rachel Springall, finance expert at Moneyfacts, said: “Due to the changes in the mortgage landscape, borrowers may find themselves better off by looking beyond headline-grabbing fixed initial rates, and instead look at the overall true cost package.
“Low-rate fixed mortgages can carry some of the highest fees, so they may not be the best choice for every borrower. Seeking independent advice to assess the overall deal is wise.”
So what does this mean for the cost of a mortgage? Which? compared the market-leading deal in September with the best fee-free deal from July, to find out the overall cost.
It crunched the numbers based on how much a homeowner would pay over a two-year fix on a £200,000 mortgage taken out over a 25-year term.

The analysis suggests lenders have made more significant price cuts to mortgages traditionally taken out by home movers and , those with a 25 per cent deposit or higher, compared with those traditionally for first-time buyers who have 5 or 10 per cent deposits.
Ultimately, borrowers who took out the best fee-free deal at a 40 or 25 per cent deposit in July would have been better off with September’s market-leading rates that are lower but come with a fee.
But the reverse is true for those with smaller deposits, as borrowers at 5 or 10 per cent deposit would have paid less in July, even though were higher.
So while interest rates on mortgage deals may have dropped, you need to check how the fee impacts what you pay back.
When searching for a mortgage deal, always look at the extra costs involved, these come under different guises, such as a product, arrangement or completion fee.

Banks commonly set fees between £999 and £1,999, but some use percentages instead – for example 0.5 per cent of the overall loan amount. If you’re borrowing a larger sum, this kind of fee can be significantly more expensive.
If you’re unsure about which type of deal to go for, a mortgage broker will be able to research deals based on their true cost, taking into account rates, fees and incentives such as cashback.

title: How I Manage My Money: World’s Strongest Man Eddie Hall, spent £400 a week  eating 12,000 calories a day
lead: “If you’re Sly or Arnie, you can earn millions, but if you’re not and you demand any more than five grand you’re laughed at.”
author: Nick McGrath

body.text: Expelled from school for fighting at 15 and earning £50,000 a year as a mechanic and bouncer aged 19 to hundreds of thousands as the World’s Strongest Man before he turned thirty, Eddie, ‘The Beast,’ Hall has always
Now, sharing  with Sylvester Stallone and Jason Statham in this month’s action-adventure movie Expend4bles, the  and are as solid as his biceps.
I don’t have a wallet. I just have a little pocket on the back of the phone, that I keep my credit cards in and perhaps keep a ten-pound note and a twenty-pound note. No coins.
I prefer contactless to cash anyway as there’s less germs and you know what’s going in and what’s going out.

In between maybe. I’m not really a show-off guy although it is hard to say that when I’ve got an army tank sat on my drive. It’s a boy’s toy. I’ve spent my whole life really wanting these things and not being able to afford them and then when you get to a place where you can afford them it’s like, ‘right,’ why not,’ I bought mine for quite a low price – still well over six figures – just before the  started, but prices have gone through the roof now.

Most people would buy a sports car or a motorbike, but I fancied a road-legal tank and that’s what I’ve got. I collect my son up from school in it and pick up a pint of milk from the local shop in it to a pint, which does leave quite a few people’s jaws on the floor. I regularly see old women just standing there going, ‘What the f**k is that?’

Growing up was tough. Dad was a health and safety officer, and Mum was a swimming teacher, and then aged 53 she became a firewoman. They had a decent income but lived in a house that probably stretched beyond their means, so food and entertainment were scarce. I remember seeing my mom cry at petrol stations because we didn’t have enough money to fill the Mini up.
I guess growing up in that environment, you just want to steer clear of it as best as you can because you know how miserable it can be, not just for the parents but also for the kids.
Aged 16, I did an apprenticeship as a mechanic then when I got my qualifications aged 18, I was initially paid about £18,000 a year then twelve months later I moved elsewhere to earn about £30,000.

I supplement that by moonlighting as security in nightclubs and pubs so from the age of 19 I’ve been used to earning fifty grand a year. I only quit my job in 2014 to become a full-time athlete and then I lived off sponsors, endorsements, appearance money, and prize money and set up my full-time business, Eddie The Beast Hall, to manage all my finances in a more tax-efficient way.
When I won the World’s Strongest Man in 2017 was amassing hundreds of thousands very quickly.

No, I very much doubt it. I was only in a small scene, and I was on set for ten days and probably earned about £300-£500 a day. People think it’s a dream world when you hit Hollywood, it really isn’t. If you’re Sly or Arnie, you can earn millions, but if you’re not and you demand any more than five grand you’re laughed at.
I did get to left up Jason Statham with one and nearly hit him but then I was shot and then I got to charge Sylvester Stallone and hit him, and he then threw me over a rock.

I was expelled from school aged 14 or 15 for fighting and started going to the gym, and some wise older body builders and strongmen in their 30s, 40s and 50s in the gave me some great advice: ‘Don’t pay into a pension, buy a house.’ It was a lightbulb moment and I thought, ‘Why would you give your money as somebody else to look after, and then they hold it to ransom until you’re nearly dead, and then they give you back?’
So, the day I turned 18 I bought a three-bedroom semi-detached house in my local area and then immediately rented it out to get on the property ladder.

I bought my second house a year later and so on and so on and gradually build up quite a decent property portfolio. Today I live in the property I’m in today and my business own quite a few properties.
No, I’m at the point in my career where I’m just building up capital, ready to invest into bigger businesses. I’ve also just invested into a protein business, Pharm, which launches this month.
I’m also planning to open a major 60,000 square feet gym somewhere. I’ve also got investments in the Middle East in gold mining companies.
When I quit my job in 2014 to commit myself to win the World’s Strongest Man, I went from working 80 hours a week earning fifty grand a year to just dropping everything and lived off savings.
I had no real back-up and I had mortgages to pay and kids to feed but in the end it came good.

Now not so much now but at my biggest at 32 stones I was spending consuming 12,000 calories a day, so I was spending £400 a week on food. Just for me. Not the wife and kids. Plus £250 a week on physios, gym memberships, supplements.
Probably £900 a week every week just on getting my body into shape.
The most moment for the least effort is probably companies paying me £5,000 just to share a story on Instagram. A couple of those a month, and you’ve paid the bills.

Investing in myself. When I quit my job, I had to have hyperbaric chambers. I had to have a hydro pool. I had to have saunas. Ice baths. That level of investment was insane, but it was necessary to win the World’s Strongest Man, which in the end has paid off massively.
Whatever I was charging prior to winning went up by about five times after I won. No one gives a shit about the runner up.
Cigars. And not cheap ones. I generally spend a grand for a box of 25.
My gaming set-up is insane. I’ve got the world’s most powerful gaming PC with a massage chair, and three screens that wrap around your head. It’s ultra-high end.
Definitely not pensions. Pensions aren’t worth a pot to piss in these days.
Most likely property. I’ll just keep investing in property. You just can’t go wrong. Property is the safest place to invest your money.
Eddie Hall  – and his fleet of Beast vehicles work  – is an ambassador for In

title: UK house prices: Properties selling for £12,000 below asking price as market weakens
lead: The highest discounts are found in London and the South East, where the average discount to the asking price is now 4.8 per cent
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Properties are  for £12,000 below their original asking price as buyers continue to benefit from a slump to  as the market weakens.
The average discount to the asking price is now 4.2 per cent, according to data published by the property website Zoopla. This rises to 4.8 per cent in London and the South East.

As a result of  and starting to fall, enquiries for people to view properties rose by 12 per cent in September compared with the previous month. This led to discounts reaching their highest level since March 2019.

While an increase after August, a time when many are on their summer holidays, is to be expected, agents  report that it remains a buyers’ market and home sellers have finally accepted the need to drop their prices. This has meant more buyers are happy to proceed. There are now 80 per cent more homes  for sale than in September 2021.

However, mortgage rates still remain high compared to two years ago when people could get rates for as low as 1 per cent. The average two-year fix is 6.53 per cent while the rate for a five-year one is 6.03 per cent, according to the analytics firm Moneyfacts.
Some experts believe that average rates will fall below 5 per cent within six to nine months, although some providers including Nationwide, HSBC and Santander,  all have rates below this already.
Zoopla added it expects the number of buyers to increase once mortgage rates get below 4.5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told i: “This is still a buyers’ market for the moment. It is no longer an environment where sellers can set a price knowing that  it will likely to be met.”
“The continues to adjust to a higher mortgage rate environment,” added Richard Donnell, executive director at Zoopla.
“Better news on and the end of increases has provided scope for lenders to start reducing mortgage rates which has supported a modest uptick in demand for homes this September.”

Home hunters also remain unwilling to make compromises on the size of home they are looking for, meaning they are waiting for either a fall in house prices or mortgage rates, even if this is not guaranteed to happen quickly.
Overall, the number of homes sold this year is set to be 20 per cent lower than in 2022, with 28 per cent fewer buyers around for those relying on a mortgage, Zoopla said.

Matt Thompson, head of sales at Chestertons, said: “Since the Bank of England’s announcement of interest rates remaining at 5.25 per cent for the time being, we have seen a positive response from buyers in September who felt more secure to make financial decisions and resume their property search.

“Understandably, buyers who are now entering the market are particularly careful about their budget and factor in any future rate hikes as well as the cost of living. As demand for properties in the capital continues to outstrip supply, the market remains competitive.”

title: How to buy a house for the best price: your guide to bagging a bargain in a buyers’ market
lead: There are several ways to get a discount on your property in the current market
author: Zesha Saleem

body.text: Home hunters will be closely observing at the moment, as  for an average of £12,000 under asking price, amid a weakening .
The average discount to asking prices is 4.2 per cent, with to be up to 3 per cent lower over 2023, according to Zoopla.
Prices have already fallen by 5.9 per cent compared to the same time last year, according to Nationwide, the sharpest fall since 2009.

This has created a buyers’ market, providing more options to negotiate with sellers and get a hefty discount on the asking price. If you’re thinkingin the near future, read below to see how you can get a good deal.
Experts says that now is a good time to put a “cheeky offer” on a home you want to buy, to see if it is accepted.
“It has swapped to a buyers’ market at the moment,” said Aaron Strutt of Trinity Financial, adding that  are trying to “stimulate the market” by offering cheaper rates to first time buyers.
“Mortgage rates are  with more lenders offering below 5 per cent fixed rates, provided you have a larger deposit.”
Nationwide, HSBC and Santander are all lenders offering deals below 5 per cent.
Nick Mendes, of brokers John Charcol, told  that buyers shouldn’t wait too long if they have found a suitable property.

“My advice to any first time buyer or prospective home owner is, if you see a property that meets your desires and is affordable, don’t try to second guess when the market is going to bottom out or when rates are going to hit rock bottom,” he said.
However, Mr Strutt said many first time buyers are still putting off getting onto the property ladder.

“Many suspect mortgages will be more affordable by then, and property prices may well be more stable. But property is supposed to be a long term investment, and as we have seen, prices will go up and down.”
No seller puts their property on the market expecting to get the asking price at the moment, experts say.
“It’s a way of testing the market, see how many viewings the property gets and test any opening bids,” Mr Mendes said.
The longer the property stays on the market, the higher the chance of negotiating for a price you’re more comfortable with.
If you notice that your dream property is listed with two estate agents, Mr Mendes says to speak to both of them to “gain as much information as possible”.
“This could provide you with the golden nugget to seal the deal.”
Furthermore, showing sellers you really want their property can also win them over, even if you ask for less than the asking price.

“Sellers want to ensure you are committed to the purchase, so being personable and selling an idea of why you will be perfect will go a long way. They could choose your offer over another prospective offer at a higher amount.”
It’s important to remember to see what needs to be done to the property, something not every homeowner does. This doesn’t come cheap so negotiating the price is highly recommended.

Mr Mendes added: “Take stock of all the work that needs to be done and potential costs and use it as part of the negotiation. What’s the worst that can happen? The seller says no to your price, but at least you have something to work from.”
House hunters are encouraged to take things into their own hands and being slightly different, as it may come with rewards.
For example, if there is a property on the street up for sale, don’t be afraid to write a leaflet with why you want to live on that street and post to neighbouring properties.
Mr Mendes said: “Estate agents do it with ‘we need more properties like yours for a prospective buyer’ leaflets.”
“This way, you get in there first and potentially get a better deal buying privately without the competition.”
That being said, while buyers will have room to negotiate in the current market, it’s still important to remember that not all properties will be up for debate.

For instance, it may be easier to bring down the price of a larger home compared to a one bedroom flat. Post pandemic, the “race for space” is on the decline, with estate agents seeing a decline in house hunters looking for larger properties with spacious gardens.
In prime locations, sellers may try to hold out for the best offers they can get, so haggling for lower prices might not work.
It’s important to think about what a property may be worth and if the price you have in mind is realistic.

title: ﻿Is attendance allowance taxed? How much the disability benefit is and who can claim it
lead: The good news is that attendance allowance is one of many state benefits that are not subject to income tax
author: Alys Key

body.text: Attendance allowance is a Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) benefit which provides financial support for those over the who require assistance or supervision due to asevere disability or long-term illness.

The, which ranges from £68.10 to £101.75 per week, can be a welcome relief, giving you some confidence that you’ll be able to handle the additional costs associated with a disability. Butseeing that extra money coming into your account might raise some concerns about where it leaves you.
The good news is that attendance allowance is one of many that are not subject to income tax. Some benefits are indeed taxable, so it’s always worth being aware of the issue.
Taxable benefits include carer’s allowance, bereavement allowance, and some legacy benefits like contribution-based employment and support allowance (ESA) and jobseeker’s allowance (JSA).
The state pension can also be subject to income tax.

But many other payments are tax-free, and these include many disability-related benefits such as disability living allowance (DLA), personal independence payment (PIP) and of course attendanceallowance.
You must have reached the state pension age to make an attendance allowance claim. As of today,this is currently 66 for both men and women, but it is due to rise in the coming years.
should have a physical or mental disability that means they need help throughout the dayor during the night. That might include someone to help you bathe, dress, eat, or managemedication.

While beneficiaries need to experience a severe condition, there is no official restriction on what kind of illness this can be. Instead, an assessment will look at the effect of the condition on an individual’s daily life and the level of support required.

The allowance is not means-tested, which means your income and any  are not taken into account. You can also spend the money on whatever would be most useful to you. Some people might pay a carer, while others choose to invest in equipment that makes life easier.

If you qualify for attendance allowance, you might also be able to get extra help with your living costs. In fact, having the benefit creates what the DWP refers to as a “passport” to additional amounts onmeans-tested benefits such as pension credit. So you could get a boost to your pension credit once you have been approved for attendance allowance.
You do not need to claim this bonus separately, and as long as the DWP has all the information, it should happen automatically.
It can also mean you are entitled to a council tax reduction, depending on your situation and who else lives with you. Contact your local council to find out if you could be eligible for a discount.

title: When are tax credits ending? How benefits claimants will be moving to universal credit and what you need to do
lead: Claimants will need to act and follow instructions from the migration notices to continue receiving their benefits
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: are being phased out and in their place most people will need to apply for universal credit.
The  will finish at the end of 2024.
The  (DWP) has already started sending out letters, called universal credit migration notices, to households affected by the change with details of what to do move over to universal credit.
We take a look at what’s happening and what you need to do.
The two forms of tax credits, working tax credit and child tax credit, will no longer exist by the end of next year replaced instead by universal credit.
The process of replacement will not happen automatically so claimants will need to act and follow instructions from the migration notices to continue receiving their benefits.
Universal credit is a benefit system for people in work, looking for work or unable to work.

It brings together six previous benefit systems: childtax credit, working tax credit, housingbenefit, income support, income-based jobseeker’s allowance (JSA) and income-related employment and support allowance (ESA).
It will be paid monthly or twice-monthly for some people in Scotland.
Most tax credits claimants are eligible for universal credit and may also be eligible for more financial support to cover other costs such as housing, and childcare costs.

If you have already received a migration notice, the DWP has said it is important people make a claim for universalcredit by the deadline in the letter to continue receiving financial support as their tax credits will end regardless.
The claim for universa credit has to be made by the deadline stated in your Migration Notice letter, even if the claimant has just renewed a tax credits claim.
If you are claiming tax credits and are aged 65 or over, the DWP will write to you to ask you to apply for universal credit or pension credit, depending on your circumstances.
The DWP has issued advice for the switch-over:

1) use an  to estimate how much you could get on universal credit. These are free to use and anonymous. If the amount you are entitled to on your existing benefits is more than you will get on universal Credit, where eligible, you can receive a top up amount called Transitional Protection.
2) find out what  and move to universal credit.

3)  check your savings. If you are currently claiming Tax Credits and have over £16,000 in money, savings, or investments you can still be eligible for universal credit for one year after you move across, but it’s important to wait for your Migration Notice letter before you switchover and follow the instructions in the letter closely.

title: Should I fix my energy? How Ofgem’s new price cap change will affect bills as fixed deals return to the market
lead: As the price cap is due to change this week, some will be considering whether to fix their energy deal
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: The new comes into effect this week, dropping to
Millions will be affected by the change on October 1, with the cap falling by £151 from the current level of £2,074.
Under the cap, which limits the unit cost of  for those on variable tariffs, the unit costs will fall to 27p for electricity and 7p for gas.
As more providers start to introduce , many will be wondering if now is the best time to fix their energy bill?
i spoke to experts to find out.
The energy price cap is set by , the body that regulates energy suppliers in Great Britain. It limits the maximum amount energy suppliers can charge you for each unit of energy you use.
It was introduced in 2019 because there was a concern that people were paying too much for their energy. The price cap is currently reviewed every three months.

It was overridden by the Government’s energy price guarantee between 1 October last year until 30 June, 2023. This provided a support rate discount to all households with gas or electricity, bringing it down to around £2,500 per year.
However, since July the price cap is now the scheme limiting bills. It only applies to variable tariffs and not fixed ones.
Fixed deals, where you are tied in to a contract with your provider, used to be the cheapest way to pay for your energy.

Despite the reduction to the price cap being a positive move, are still much higher than they were just a couple of years ago when people could get a fixed deal for an average of £800 a year, if not less.
They are now returning to the market as prices begin to decrease, with some now available below the price cap. Most are fixed for a year or more.
Whether you should fix your energy deal will depend on what sort of deal you can get and whether you are willing to risk energy prices going up or down again.
If you are looking for certainty, a fixed deal could work for you. However, it will probably only make sense if you are guaranteed to pay less than your supplier’s default tariff.
Currently, there are 10 providers offering fixed deals, however, many come with caveats.
For example, several are for existing customers only, such as Octopus Energy’s Loyal Octopus fixed deal.

Others like Utility Warehouse’s Fixed Saver 6 deal requires customers to sign up to two other products with the firm, like broadband. This is also the only one below the new price cap at £1,873 on average.
However, it is probable that more deals will become available after the new cap comes into effect.

Natalie Mathie, energy expert at Uswitch.com, said: “Only those on fixed tariffs have the certainty of knowing what they will pay for the full term of their deal, which is usually a year. During that time, customers on variable tariffs will see their bills change four times.

“A reasonably priced fixed deal could be a good option for households who want certainty over what they will pay. However, as the energy market remains volatile, it can be difficult to predict whether opting for a fixed deal or sticking with a variable will save you money in the long run.”
For those thinking of switching to a fixed deal, experts are warning people to pay attention to any exit fees, which could cost up to £200 per fuel.

Ms Mathie added: “The price you are quoted to pay through direct debit each month is an estimate based on your predicted usage and may not end up being the actual cost over the whole year. Remember, if you use more energy, you’ll pay more.
“Make sure you look at the unit price and standing charge so you can understand how much you will pay for your energy usage and how it differs from what you are currently charged.”

title: How Bake Off turned ‘baking’ into an identity
lead: Baking used to be a Saturday afternoon activity with the sole aim of producing a cake. Thirteen years of Instagram aesthetics and Bake Off have turned it into a personality type
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: The kettle’s on, there’s a chill in the air. Plastic products line the aisles of Big Sainsbury’s. You have been told by your Instagram feed that you are now permitted to make soup. And , that cosiest, most autumnal of shows that is now airing for the 13th year running, and has somehow become a national cultural touchstone.

Thanks to social media, autumn is no longer just a season but a lifestyle and state of mind. In the same vein, Bake Off has long been more than just a TV show. Since its inception in 2010 it has become synonymous with wholesomeness, puns, low stakes and high emotions.

Whichever Bake Off camp you consider yourself part of – nice cup of tea and an episode; hungover sobbing session and five episodes; prefer to read Karl Marx on a hard chair and never heard of it – Bake Off is an identity marker, a vibe, an essence.

And although the actual is somewhat incidental to all the show’s aesthetic garb (bunting, tea towels, comedy duos), a similar fate has befallen its central activity. Over the past 13 years we have watched baking transition from verb to sometime-Saturday afternoon activity to obsessive hobby to complete personality type.

Don’t pretend you don’t know what I’m talking about. Silicone cupcake moulds? Flowers made of sugar? Marbled icing? Your star sign is Baking. And before I get strung up in the town square for yucking your yum, or whatever quaint phrase most saccharinely summarises unnecessary criticisms of other people’s enthusiasms, let me explain. This has no bearing on skillset or enjoyment. It doesn’t matter if you’re amateur or professional, ironic or earnest. It’s a feeling. There is small-b baking and capital-B baking; one bakes or one Bakes. And Baking, as opposed to baking, encourages a particular kind of identity performance that takes the joy out of the thing you’re telling everyone gives you joy.

Does a woman in her late sixties making a carrot cake before her children come home for the May Day Bank Holiday constitute Baking? Of course not. It’s their favourite; she has made it every year since they were small. This is simply baking.

By contrast, a woman whose age I will not disclose lest I am accused of discrimination, who makes ombre cupcakes for dessert at a brunch, which are posted on Instagram by all attendees, does not bake. She Bakes. And unlike the first woman, who uses tins she has had since 1982, the second has a kitchen full of sparkly new kit that has been advertised to her online and which serves additional decorative purpose in the presentation of her creations.

It goes without saying that this tiresome new identity, and commodification of a literally ancient activity, is not Bake Off’s sole responsibility. The show began as an emulation of the type of cake competitions common at village fetes, and was popular precisely because it seemed natural, genuine and a bit slapdash.

For the first six years,  were at the helm on the BBC – bringing with them thinly-veiled innuendos and enjoyably feminine novelty; the show was – and still is – filmed in a marquee strung with bunting, in a way that Americans definitely wouldn’t understand. After a decade of garish, stressful TV like Big Brother, The X Factor and How Clean Is Your House?, Bake Off was a soothing antidote with ASMR-style close-ups of batter being mixed, novelty “Technical” challenges and a refreshingly diverse cast.

A year after Bake Off first aired, though, came the dawn of Instagram. Everything became about aesthetics. Hobbyist bakers turned to the internet to share their creations, where a super-clean, colour-saturated look was becoming popular. Bake Off was a hit, but it was at risk of becoming samey – so producers turned to increasingly complicated, spurious challenges to keep it interesting. (Fans riled in 2013 at “Pancake Week”; pancakes are famously cooked in pans, not baked in ovens.)

And just as started as an earnest, novel way to share life updates and amateur photography projects and morphed into an anxiety-inducing, inescapable machine for self-realisation, so Bake Off went from a refreshingly low-stakes show to a self-referential behemoth with its own language (“soggy bottoms”), customs (the nausea-inducing “Hollywood handshake”) and culture (occasional bouts of non-competitiveness when contestants help each other).

As Christmas stockings continued to be filled with high-end piping bags and various shades of silicone, and Bake Off continued to provide a sanctuary with an almost manically wholesome energy, a vicious circle was created. Bake Off spawned Baking, but Baking also ruined Bake Off.

We all remember the episode from 2020 in which contestants had to make busts of their favourite celebrities out of cake. Producing a delectable Victoria sponge is no longer sufficient: they must construct shortbread palaces; build mille-feuille villages; imbue focaccia with exotic flavour combinations that get Paul Hollywood licking his greasy little fingers.

Now, in series 14, producers appear to have become aware of this. With presenter Matt Lucas replaced by , there is a touch of fresh energy – and teasers promise that it will go back to basics in content. Yet Big Baking still looms large on the horizon. If this season inspires you to get out the wooden spoon, you must choose your fate: will you Bake? Or will you simply, blissfully, bake?

title: Who Killed Jill Dando?, Netflix, review: Not just another cheap true crime doc – this is serious journalism
lead: After three episodes we still don’t know who shot Jill Dando in 1999, but that doesn’t mean this docuseries is a waste of time
author: Gerard Gilbert

body.text: “The golden girl of British television murdered on her doorstep in broad daylight… that just does not happen,” says former Sun journalist Jane Moore at the start of the thorough three-part Netflix  documentary
Except of course it did happen to the much-loved BBC presenter on the morning of 26 April 1999. The 37-year-old Dando was killed with a single gunshot to the head on the steps of her home in Fulham.

Twenty-four years later, the case remains unsolved and while Who Killed Jill Dando? doesn’t answer its own question (if the murderer had been identified it would have been all over the news), it does provide an impressive roster of contributors.
These include the senior investigating police officer, Hamish Campbell, and the man whom Campbell saw imprisoned (unsafely, it eventually transpired) for eight years for Dando’s murder, .

A local fantasist with learning difficulties, an interest in guns and a criminal record for attempted rape, George is interviewed in Ireland, where he now lives. In a somewhat unsettling sequence, he even demonstrates on his female interviewer how hard it would have been for him to grab Dando without being splattered in her blood.

The three episodes follow the various lines of inquiry (or wrong turns, critics of the police might say), from the possibility of a Serbian hitman retaliating for the deadly Nato bombing of a Belgrade TV station during the Balkans War to a revenge attack by one of the criminals exposed by Dando while presenting Crimewatch.
There was a hunt for a mysterious blue Range Rover seen speeding away from the murder scene, and the release of an E-Fit of a possible suspect that led to an eccentric undertaker in Shepherd’s Bush.

Meanwhile, Dando’s former friend and BBC colleague recalls having to read the breaking news bulletin about the murder, while Dando’s hairdresser, Martyn Maxey, explains how he gave her trademark cropped style – before, he confides, he gave the same cut to .

This isn’t as irrelevant as it might sound, because Dando was perhaps only second to Diana as the nation’s sweetheart in the 90s. The scenes at her funeral in Weston-Super-Mare, with the thousands lining the streets throwing flowers at her passing hearse, were reminiscent of Diana’s funeral procession two years earlier.

We also hear from George’s defence barrister, the legendary human-rights lawyer Michael Mansfield, George’s sister, Michelle Diskin Bates, who campaigned tirelessly for his release, along with Dando’s brother, Nigel, her former boyfriend, ex-BBC executive Bob Wheaton, and her erstwhile agent Jon Roseman.

The latter two were questioned by police as potential suspects. Wheaton had received a £35,000 loan from Dando, while Roseman had been writing a novel in which a celebrity agent’s clients start being murdered. Talk about clutching at straws.

Executive producer Emma Cooper (The Mystery of Marilyn Monroe: The Unheard Tapes) has done an impressive job in securing contributors. Nigel Dando stated in a recent interview that he agreed to take part in the hope that the documentary might open fresh avenues in an investigation that has been effectively stalled since George’s release from prison in 2008.

Campbell is still adamant that George did it, Mansfield reckons that the forensic evidence points to Serbia, while a career criminal-turned-writer called Noel “Razor” Smith claims to have heard rumours that it was a crime-gang hit job. He can’t say who, he says darkly, for his own safety.

Needless to say, social media has filled the vacuum with a variety of colourful theories, including the idea that Dando was murdered by a VIP paedophile ring. Who Killed Jill Dando?, however, is a proper piece of journalism that sheds light on the case, even if it can provide no definitive answer.
