title: Who was Todd Matshikiza? Why a Google Doodle is celebrating the South African jazz musician and journalist
lead: On this day in 1956 Matshikiza’s cantata, Uxolo, was played by the orchestra at the 70th Johannesburg Festival
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: Today’s  celebrates  jazz pianist, composer, and journalist Todd Matshikiza.
On this day in 1956 his cantata, Uxolo (Peace), was played by the orchestra at the 70th Johannesburg Festival.

The Doodle was illustrated by South Africa-based pop artist Keith Vlahakis, who said he was heavily influenced by the album cover design for the South African musical King Kong, the music for which Matshikiza composed.

Matshikiza was born in Queenstown, South Africa, on 7 March 1921, and was the youngest of seven children. His mother was a singer and his father was an organist, and they taught him and his siblings how to play piano when they were young.

He went on to obtain a diploma in music at Adams College in Natal, and a teacher’s diploma at Lovedale Institute in Alice. He stayed at Lovedale to teach, before moving back to Johannesburg where he founded his own music school, the Todd Matshikiza School of Music.

As a composer, he is most famous for his work on the song “Quickly in Love”, which appears in the 2013 film : Long Walk to Freedom, and the score for two theatrical productions, King Kong (1958) and Mkhumbane (1960).

King Kong, which had an all-black cast, told the real-life story of heavyweight boxer Ezekiel Dlamini, whose nickname was King Kong. The production was very successful with both black and white audiences, being staged in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Port Elizabeth in South Africa as well as at the Prince’s Theatre in London’s West End in 1961.
It was this show, as well as a growing frustration with South African apartheid, that brought Matshikiza to London. He moved over with his wife, Esme Sheila Mpama, and their two children.
Matshikiza was one of the first writers at Drum magazine, where he wrote a column about the artistry and evolution of , and another on township life called “With the Lid Off”.
His journalistic endeavours allowed him to work for the BBC as presenter and researcher while in London, before moving to Zambia, where he worked as a broadcaster and a music archivist.
Matshikiza was frustrated at being prevented from returning to South Africa, where his writing had been banned by the South African government. He died in Lusaka in 1968.
His story is told in his autobiography, Chocolates for My Wife (1961), which describes apartheid in South Africa and his move to London.

title: Land of Milk and Honey, by C Pam Zhang, review: The perfect book for millennial foodies
lead: The Booker longlistee’s second novel unpicks the murky morals of the 0.1 per cent club – and is a tasty treat
author: Susie Mesure

body.text: Imagine a world with no , no strawberries, no almonds. A world where a chef has to strike pesto from the menu because there are no more nuts and seeds in the pantry, and no basil, not even the powdered kind.

Where “chef had lost its meaning, like lucky, like fresh, like soon”, the global population surviving only thanks to a gritty and distributed by governments and engineered from plants that can grow in the dark.

That is the world C Pam Zhang conjures in her second novel, Land of Milk and Honey, which is set in the near future, three years after agricultural smog from a cornfield in Iowa has blotted out the sun, triggering a global

It’s a clever premise with the potential to be the perfect book for our foodie-obsessed times: gastronomic cli-fi for a generation who’d rather splurge on something tasty and photographic from a fresh drop at their local artisanal bakery than save for a mortgage that may remain forever out of reach.

Zhang, who was long-listed for the Booker Prize with her 2020 debut, , about a Chinese American family swept up in the Gold Rush, spins her story from the vantage point of an old woman looking back on an extraordinary chapter of her life.

“I would have gone anywhere, done anything, for one last taste of green sharp enough to pierce the caul of my life. I was 29, a hungry ghost, adrift. I hadn’t seen California in 10 years, hadn’t tasted a strawberry or a leaf of lettuce in three,” Zhang writes.

The nameless narrator is an Asian American chef who found herself stranded in England after America’s borders closed. Sick of struggling to make anything edible from the dwindling supplies at the restaurant where she works in return for a refugee visa, she quits to take a cooking job at an “elite research community” at a secret location on the Italian-French alpine border.
The community was ostensibly founded as a food research centre to save the world from famine: occasional sunlight still blessed its mountain location, which meant fresh produce.

In reality, the chef’s new employer is the stinking rich kingpin in an enclave of 0.1 per centers – think and the like – who are all jockeying for his favour in the hope of buying themselves eternal salvation via an invitation to be part of his grand relocation project.
In turn, the kingpin needs their investments for a research programme run by his 20-year-old daughter breeding rare and extinct varieties of plants and animals.

Our protagonist’s task is to devise banquets for mutual wooing sessions with the ever more outlandish ingredients at her disposal. And I mean outlandish: Zhang’s imagination is as rich as the dishes her narrator prepares.

This is a zippy, fresh take on dystopian fiction that Zhang clearly had fun writing. That much is clear from the acknowledgements: a love letter to gastronomy, they alternate between dishes and books that influenced her writing, anything from Evelyn Waugh’s Brideshead Revisited and jian bing pancakes at a particular stall in Beijing, to The Lover by Marguerite Duras and Sainsbury’s red Leicester. The sentences sing as the tensions ratchet up to an inevitable righteous reckoning.

The world outside “La terra di latte e miele”, as the community is dubbed by its increasingly cynical Italian neighbours, barely gets a look in, but that doesn’t matter because Land of Milk and Honey is as much a parable as a novel about the murky morals of the 0.1 per cent club. Required reading for them and a tasty treat for everyone else.
, by C Pam Zhang, is published by Hutchinson Heinemann at £16.99

title: Edge of Here by Kelechi Okafor, review: An afrofuturist Black Mirror shot through with romance
lead: Okafor’s debut story collection uses sci-fi themes to consider what it means to be a Black woman in society
author: Kuba Shand-Baptiste

body.text: Dystopia is perhaps the last thing that comes to mind when we ruminate on the concept of love. But British Nigerian writer Kelechi Okafor’s debut short story collection juxtaposes the two – to great success.

An afrofuturist  of sorts, it merges aspects of ancient Igbo and Yoruba sprituality with a not-too-distant futuristic world in which pandemics have rendered us even more removed from physical touch and brought technology further into our lives. Against all odds, love in all its forms thrives anyway.

A  collection is a venture that some may not have expected from Okafor, but it suits her. An actor, and podcast host, she has turned her hand to everything from running her own pole and fitness studio, advocating from all walks of life, discussing issues about race and gender in the media, doing tarot readings and generally entertaining her fans with her quick wit and sharp tongue.

Her stories use sci-fi themes to consider what it means to be a black woman in society. Plotlines explore how it would feel to literally hold the world’s burdens in your own body, or to be addicted to experiencing an alternate version of your life through virtual reality, or to find yourself betrayed by a system you thought served to keep you safe.

But they are all also love stories at their heart. Along with emphasising reincarnation and the immortal soul – core tenets of traditional Yoruba and Igbo beliefs – the stories tell of technology that allows you to explore an alternate love life with a stranger, and a pair of lovers named Chinonso and Ndidi, who are drawn to each other across the ages and in multiple universes.

These hopeful stories, which portray “a world where black women love and are loved back” and “don’t have all the answers” are refreshing, as is the representation of aspects of West African spirituality in a part of the world that often rejects it.

Edge of Here may not be the first book to consider the far-reaching consequences of unbridled biotechnology, or how comfortably concepts like “race science” (the bogus idea that certain races are inherently more intelligent than others) fit into hellish, futuristic worlds, but that’s not the point. Like many books in the same genre, it portrays a future that interrogates what we’re dealing with now and asks us to pay attention.

The book is written honestly and plainly, and some of its themes and characters at times feel like a proxy for Okafor’s thoughts and feelings about the state of the world and what she’d like to change in it. That’s likely to be exactly the case, given her admission in the introduction that “these stories allow” her to share her “deepest hopes and dreams, represented through the protagonists”.

One story, for example, tells of the advent of an “ally chip”, which helps people with some degree of privilege to understand the everyday feelings of marginalised people (in this case, black people specifically). But they cast eerie parallels with today’s world in the tradition of other black sci-fi writers such as Octavia E Butler or Nnedi Okorafor.
Edge of Here is a collection that is bursting with fervour, vulnerability and romance. I’m excited to see where Kelechi Okafor, the author, goes next.
, is published by Trapeze at £16.99

title: Sarah Lucas: Happy Gas, Tate Britain, review: Toilets, dildos, fags and boobs – the YBA is still perverse
lead: The YBA’s territory has always been a blokey world of innuendos and off-colour jokes. But in this show, her subject is cruelty – and it’s not funny in the slightest
author: Hettie Judah

body.text: Toilets, dildos, wanking, fags, boobs, Page 3. When she got big alongside the “Young British Artists” in the 1990s, was a blokey world of innuendos and off-colour jokes. A very specific, very British sensibility, probing both gender and class.

Her sculptural vocabulary was local and inglorious: fruit, veg and tights from the corner store; chairs and tables from the junk shop; old mattresses pulled from the skip. Her best-known early works mined a sticky seam of vulgarity, exploring the body and its functions, abject assemblages of old furniture, cucumbers, kebabs, melons, buckets and fried eggs.

Lucas is now 60 and has not lost her relish for sexual innuendo – concrete sculptures of giant marrows on the lawn outside Tate Britain herald the artist’s show there. Rather than cramming her work so far into four galleries, she’s selected a typically perverse theme.

: Happy Gas focuses largely on work involving chairs, from burnt-out car seats to a suspended “egg” chair covered in little breasts to a cast of the dancer Michael Clark sitting on a toilet. Why chairs? The chair supports the body as a plinth supports a sculpture. Where there is a chair, there is an implied body. You get the idea.

Happy Gas opens with The Old Couple (1992) – two hardbacked kitchen chairs, one with a pair of false teeth in the seat, the other with a rearing white wax penis. At face value, it’s a visual joke about ageing and oral sex. It’s also a comment on reducing people to body parts and functions – both the dildo and the dentures are prosthetics, of a kind.

Hovering over it all is an atmosphere of implicit violence. The penis waiting to pierce you like a drawing pin on a teacher’s seat. The teeth a vagina dentata, ready to bite. It’s nasty, really, rather than funny.

There’s a wanking chair with a moving arm, and an early example of one of Lucas’s Bunny sculptures – loose female figures made of stuffed tights and stockings. This 1997 Bunny is sprawled and stretched over a pub chair. She looks like a passed-out drunk, incapable but apparently sexually available. Blown-up photos on the wall show Lucas touting a huge salmon standing outside a men’s toilet.

It was tricky, in the 90s and noughties, to know where to position Lucas in relation to the culture she drew on. Her ascendance coincided with the era of the lad and the accompanying pressure on women to be “ladettes” and find leering, lager and lechery all a big laugh.

But was Lucas laughing with or at the jokes? She seemed to play both sides. A lot of her work was intentionally crude and upfront. Who was she out to shock – the prudes? The patriarchy? The art world? Perhaps she wasn’t totally sure herself.

It was and remains easy to read Lucas wrong, to frame her as a bit of a joker. I went into the Tate show still carrying a hangover of this idea. It’s Sarah Lucas! This is going to be a laugh! And came out reminded of how brutal her work can be.

On the wall of the opening gallery, for instance, is a piece from the 90s: three spreads from The Sun newspaper photocopied up to the dimensions of a large painting. The picture stories in which women were paid to perform enjoyment and availability are no longer hidden in the privacy of a newspaper centrefold, or slyly shared with a friend, they’re suddenly big and public and fixed to the wall, as if daring us to feel uncomfortable.

Framed on the wall opposite are five neat lists compiled by Lucas in 1990 while on a residency in Rome. Each is a collection of slang terms – for masturbation, male sex organs, and toilet stuff, for women and gay men. The final two are lists of insults: a fairly stark illustration of which groups of people were usually on the receiving end, both of jokes and abuse. We might see the lists as a starting position for the work that followed.

I saw Lucas’s show less than a week after the Channel 4 Dispatches documentary laid bare allegations of sexual assault against Russell Brand (which he denies). The film’s running theme was that Brand’s predatory misogyny was couched in plain sight, framed as humour. What a potent moment to engage with Lucas’s work, with its jabbing suggestion that a joke can be freighted with so much more.

Lucas has layered up works from across her career. Photos of the artist performing to the camera – young, devouring a banana, cradling that dead salmon, older now, smoking in a red room in a stripy top – are blown up to become the show’s wallpaper.

In a back gallery running the full width of the show are dozens of recent Bunny sculptures, made with stuffed tights, women’s shoes and chairs. They are plumper and more colourful than their earlier sisters, more sculpturally deft and expressive. Some have been cast in bronze or concrete. They are anxious sex objects sprawling on their seats, some trying to impress us, others less sure. It’s like walking round a puppet brothel. Scrutinising them, it’s hard not to feel implicated.

There are “muses” from her installation for the British Pavilion at the 2015 Venice Biennale – casts taken of the bottom halves of her female friends, leaning or sprawled on pieces of furniture with cigarettes coming out of one orifice or another. It’s a punchy gesture of sorority – gritty, solid and base.

Lucas refuses to be a “lone genius” directing our attention to the figures behind the camera in her self-portraits, all boyfriends past and present (among them artists Angus Fairhurst and Gary Hume). Such gestures of alliance have lightened the mood in other recent Lucas outings. Last year she created an uproarious opening display of female artist friends brandishing broomsticks, and Bunny sculptures lolling on a sports car for Big Women,  she curated for Firstsite in Colchester.

For a recent mid-career retrospective at New York’s New Museum, she invited women to hurl 1,000 eggs at a gallery wall to create a hormonal drippy yolk painting. That show felt a lot more raucous, much bawdier than this. Lucas wasn’t just picking apart jokes, she was also having a laugh. Maybe that’s easier to do off home territory. Maybe things don’t feel that funny here at the moment.

With the exception of the Tits in Space wallpaper patterned with breasts sculpted in cigarettes that lines the exhibition entrance, joie de vivre is in short supply in Happy Gas. The centrepiece of the final gallery is a burnt-out car half covered in unsmoked cigarettes – This Jaguar’s Going to Heaven (2018). It’s part midlife crisis, part death of British industry, part cancerous spectre of mortality.

There’s a lot of concrete – used on the exhibition walls, its custom furniture and many of the sculptures. The alienating stuff of the loveless built environment. I felt its grey solidity weighing on my soul. Lucas may speak the visual language of humour but in Happy Gas, her subject is cruelty, both personal and structural.

title: The Running Grave by Robert Galbraith, review: JK Rowling’s latest is fat-shaming and sexist
lead: This wouldn’t pass the Bechdel Test – and proves everyone needs an editor
author: Moira Redmond

body.text: The Running Grave is the seventh  by Robert Galbraith (the pseudonym of ), which based on where it comes in the series makes it the equivalent of  and the Deathly Hallows.
But while that adventure ended the Potter saga, there is every indication that the Strike books will go on forever – even if this novel has as many shortcomings as qualities to recommend it.

Let’s start with the positives. The setup here is instantly compelling – detective partners Strike and Robin are hired by a family whose son has disappeared into a religious cult on a farm estate in Norfolk. The troubled young man, Will, has cut off all contact with his family and they are worried about him.

The decision is made that Robin will go undercover, posing as a new recruit at the farm, which makes for fascinating and very tense reading, though there is a weird similarity with Harry Potter, because the farm is like a distorted, evil version of Hogwarts.

The recruits are put into groups – I kept expecting the Sorting Hat to arrange it – and they have to learn a whole new vocabulary and way of living, but instead of potions and spells there are spirit wives, free love, and a resistance to notions of family.

The cult details are horrible – the new recruits and lower-level members are forced to do manual labour, are not fed properly, and are subject to cruel and degrading punishments. Rowling is very good on the effects on the rest of the family outside the cult when one member goes rogue – the difficulties for siblings and their variable attitudes to what is going on.

But it takes 200 pages just to get Robin into the cult HQ, and that points to a major issue: The Running Grave is a total doorstopper of more than 900 pages, and seems to be suffering from the same problem as afflicted its predecessors – no-one dares to tell Rowling that it would be a better book at half the length.
There are long scenes where people are questioned – their answers infuriatingly rendered in weird phonetic speech with every “like” and “you know” included.

And there is far too much detail about Strike and Robin’s detective agency – they have clients on the go other than Will’s family, who are endlessly described, which seems neither necessary nor a good idea. When Rowling starts telling us the shift patterns of the employees you think this really is getting out of hand.

What’s more, plenty of elements simply don’t ring true. Strike is rude and unpleasant, but magnetically attractive to women, and also tabloid-famous for being a private detective, not something we are familiar with in the real world.

Characters make mistakes because they haven’t charged their phones, or because they are upset. If you are going to write 900 pages I think you could spend some time thinking of better reasons to miss something vital.

Rowling’s last book, The Ink Black Heart, looked at the kind of online pile-on she was familiar with due to her views on trans rights. The real-world parallels are subtler here, but there are still hints of commentary about our increasingly black and white public debates as she examines the idea of people being brainwashed and unable to see past the lines they are being fed.
But despite Rowling’s engagement with current issues, in places the book’s treatment of women feels outdated; Rowling has, most unexpectedly, taken on the persona of a male thriller writer.

The books would fail a  – women characters do not have meaningful discussions that don’t involve men. Robin is an excellent, well-rounded character, but she is too much obsessed by and in awe of Strike and spends any time with friends hearing about, and worrying about, Strike.

And the unattractive women in the book are described as fat, chubby, porky, in a casual way. This made me realise that there has been a change for the better in most modern books, so Rowling comes over as judgmental: someone should suggest cutting the .

Somewhere, here, there is a good book, but it is hidden in a baggy and flawed outer shell. Rowling is one of our richest and most successful writers, but that doesn’t mean she doesn’t need advice – or an editor.

title: Grand Designs, Channel 4, review: No one loves a disaster more than Kevin McCloud
lead: A more cynical show would have zoomed in on the melodrama, but Grand Designs is a property series with heart and soul
author: Ed Power

body.text: Kevin McCloud was walking on air as he returned for the latest series of . The architectural guru fizzed with enthusiasm when he arrived in Herefordshire, where young couple Rosa and Craig were converting a dilapidated railway shed into a partly submerged house.

McCloud was thrilled to hear of their plans for a home that would exist among “the amazing natural beauty” of the Wye Valley. But cutting-edge architecture isn’t cheap – in fact, due to the ever-rising cost of living it’s never been more expensive. The tension in a surprisingly gripping episode came from the gulf between Rosa and Craig’s ambitions and their resources.

But that’s how it has always been on Grand Designs – a series that has remained remarkably consistent across the more than 200 episodes that have aired since 1999. It’s a monument to imaginative architecture – but even more so to pressing on with an ambitious project even when everything seems stacked against you.

It was an uphill struggle to build the subterranean home. They had budgeted a whopping £700,000 for their underground paradise – £500,000 of which was covered by a hefty mortgage. But it soon became apparent that they had underestimated the expenses involved – all of the builders’ quotes came in well above £1m. Even McCloud was momentarily downbeat. The sheer cost, he said, was a “hammer blow to their dreams”.

Beyond the architecture lay the compelling story of a couple pursuing an impossible dream handed down from a previous generation. The idea to redevelop the shed – a water reservoir from an obsolete steam railway line – had originated with Rosa’s grandfather Leo (technically, he was a family friend rather than a relative, but what does that matter?). He’d spent years trying to make the shed fit for human habitation, personally removing slurry from the structure using only a humble wheelbarrow.

Leo spoke passionately about wanting to see Rosa make the decaying structure her home. But he died during filming, and his granddaughter struggled to keep the tears at bay. “I see it as his legacy,” she said.

That legacy came at a price. The bills were soon stacking up and then Covid struck, forcing Craig to give up his day job as a skydiving instructor. The resourceful couple instead launched an online sweet business. Meanwhile, the builders pouring concrete and affixing a new roof had mixed views about their vision. One described the structure “as a Tellytubby house… a multi-story carpark at the end of the day”.

And still, the overheads spiralled. Craig rounded up some friends to lay the floor himself, saving £15,000 along the way. It helped – but not enough, as Rosa admitted. “If I’d known how much it cost I never would have done it,” she said as she cradled the couple’s newborn baby, named after Leo.

A more cynical show would have zoomed in on the melodrama as this family felt the strain, and made a song and dance about Rosa and Craig’s financial pressures. However, McCloud isn’t that sort of presenter, and the episode was the better for it. He was here for the architecture, and Grand Designs resisted the temptation to blow Rosa and Craig’s financial difficulties out of proportion.

Finally, after a three-year slog, several bank loans and one pandemic, the revamp was finished. The ever-buoyant McCloud was smitten by this house under the hill. He was even more impressed by Rosa and Craig’s resolve to push forward against daunting odds.

Their mortgage was huge and they had spent a “horrendous” amount finishing their new home. But they now lived in a stunning split-level structure that was a cross between a minimalist masterpiece and Bilbo Baggins’s wildest dreams. McCloud was delighted to have accompanied them on their journey.
His excitement was a reminder that, while Grand Designs is a love letter to fantastic architecture, it is also that rarest thing: property television with a heart and soul.

title: Why I won’t be watching Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour concert film in the cinema
lead: The announcement that the tour is coming to cinemas put me and my fellow cult members into a quandary
author: Rebecca Reid

body.text: Those of us who have been devoted Swifties since her early career will remember the fallow period. The long drought, where we went three arid, Taylorless years between the 1989 and Reputation albums where there wasn’t so much as a whiff of a vault track, a new song or a concert.

Happily, in a post Kimye world, Taylor keeps us all well fed and watered with a steady stream of content, dropping two albums in one year, pumping out the re-recordings and giving us the world’s highest-grossing concert tour. This week’s big exciting news is that the film is coming to cinemas in the UK on 13 October.

I don’t like to question our Glorious Leader, but the announcement that the tour is coming to cinemas put me and my fellow cult members into a bit of a quandary.  and a teeny little panic attack that was probably about something unrelated, we have ended up with next August.

I don’t know what my life will look like by then, but I do know that whatever happens I will be sobbing my way through the set list and exchanging friendship bracelets with people so young I could legally adopt them. But – as the question rippled through our WhatsApp groups – does that mean no cinema trip?

The decision to release the film globally before the tour has reached its dates outside of North America and Mexico has not been welcome news to everyone. There have been dissenting voices on the internet arguing that it’s not fair on people who haven’t had a chance to see it live yet, that for the other legs of the tour were wildly expensive and that putting the show in the cinema somehow makes those tickets less good value for money.

Listen, I get it. If you’ve spent most of your disposable income on something that other people can ostensibly go and see for about £15, that might feel frustrating. But honestly, it really doesn’t feel very in the spirit of being to object to more people getting to enjoy what is apparently the best tour of all time (absolutely no bias to that opinion at all).

Maybe if the concert were top secret it might make more sense to object to the film, but it’s been splattered all over the internet since the outset in March. Spotify has dozens of playlists of the set list and TikTok is full of clips. It’s been live-streamed by Swifties every night. I’ve tried to avoid spoilers because I want to see it for the first time in person, but even with my ironclad willpower, I’ve still seen a decent amount of the show online.

There are plenty of people who can’t afford to go to the show, who don’t have anyone to go with, who aren’t comfortable in large crowds or don’t live anywhere near a concert venue, all of whom want to be part of the Eras phenomenon, and this caters to them perfectly. Someone else getting to enjoy the concert film doesn’t detract from the live experience.

On a less earnest note, it’s easy to fall into the trap of viewing as our best friend, the go-to gal of heartbreak, the greatest songwriter of her generation, and forget that there is Taylor Swift the person, and Taylor Swift the brand. She’s a business, she makes money – a lot of money. There’s a reason that she’s one of the richest people on earth and it’s because she’s an extremely savvy businesswoman.

We need to accept that much as we love her, Taylor is here to make bank as well as hold our hands when our hearts hurt, and that while the Eras Tour is a reportedly a borderline spiritual experience, it’s also a big shiny capitalist money-making machine, and both of those things can be true at the same time.

title: Don’t Tell the Bride celebrated everything wrong with lad culture
lead: While grooms were portrayed as doltish but loveable rascals, brides who had their special day ruined were seen as boring and demanding
author: Emily Baker

body.text: There’s nowhere the strict gender roles we place on men and women are as clear cut as in a western, heterosexual .

The bride wears white to signify that she is “pure” and is given to her husband-to-be by her father, like a goat in Medieval times. The groom is given the privilege to “kiss the bride” and it’s traditionally his mates who get to stand up and celebrate (or, more likely, roast) the fact that he found a woman willing to put up with him enough to marry him.

All this was enshrined in reality TV series Don’t Tell the Bride, which challenged men to organise a wedding without any input from their bride and ran intermittently and on various channels from 2006. For the best part of a decade, it was one of the most entertaining series on TV, accurately and often painfully depicting the fraught chaos of a British wedding. But it is now horribly outdated, which is likely why Channel 4 bosses have revealed there are currently “no plans” to bring it back.

In Don’t Tell the Bride, the grooms and their accomplices were portrayed as dumb, uncaring lager louts who couldn’t care less about the bride or her wishes. And yet, they were not the villains. Instead, that label fell to the women, who were either  who would take any nonsense their fiancé throws at them or over-demanding, hysterical shrews who could never be satisfied.
It’s a maxim that props up all that is wrong with lad culture: boys just want to have fun; girls just want ruin it.

Every episode (of which there are more than 164 in 14 series) told the same story. A bloke packed his fiancé off to stay with her mum and the first bit of the £14,000 wedding budget was spaffed on getting the beers in while he and his mates started planning.

The first order of business was, invariably, the stag do. Ibiza or Amsterdam? The grooms always went abroad on a lad’s holiday while the women suffered through a sad night at the local Indian (where they inevitably had to drive themselves, after the groom forgot to book a taxi) with the £40 left over. Typical men; can’t live with the dolts, can’t live without ‘em.

Then there’s the wedding dress, which almost always left the bride in tears and her mother/sister/best friends lying through their teeth about how lovely she looked, even though it wasn’t “what she’d imagined”. Because it turns out, a lot of men have absolutely no idea of their partner’s body shape and size or even their fashion sense. Lace and diamanté and veil and a train and a tiara? Why not!

As the groom made his decisions, the poor sales assistant was roped into trying on dresses in place of the bride, while the wedding party pretended not to ogle her boobs. What else was the poor lad supposed to do? Listen to his missus? Not likely, the football was on that day.

But it’s the wedding day itself that always caused the most contention. The grooms – presumably having been encouraged by production – always gave in to their most absurd, childish, and distasteful instincts. Memorable (for all the wrong reasons) are ceremonies in a branch of Ikea, a pig farm, on a banana boat in the middle of the sea and a football pitch, during which the bride was made to wear football boots instead of the diamond-encrusted heels she’d always dreamed of.

The worst of all saw the groom, Simon, plan a ceremony in Las Vegas only to find out he had no budget left to fly his beloved Kayleigh’s family over for the occasion. Through tears, Kayleigh told him she was calling the wedding off, though they eventually did get married (only to split up nine months later).

I’m the first to admit that, in the late noughties, I found the series wildly entertaining. Having grown up on a media diet of, Heat magazine and , lad culture and its spidery influence was ingrained into my consciousness from a young age. Why couldn’t these women just go along with whatever their boyfriends wanted? What’s so important about a wedding, anyway?

Now I see just how twisted the concept of Don’t Tell the Bride is. The series preys on women’s desire (a pressure impressed upon them for centuries) to have their own wedding day the way they want it – just one special day – and then punishes them for it by ripping it all away and praising the men who don’t have the emotional intelligence to understand the gravity of their actions.
As is the case with any display of patriarchy, men and women both lose.

title: How Russell Brand defined TV’s grim decade of ‘irony banter’
lead: In the Noughties, anything went – you just had to understand that nobody meant anything they said. Tom Nicholson looks back at the aloofness, outrageousness, cruelty and misogyny that defined our entertainment, and led to modern Nice TV
author: Tom Nicholson

body.text: There has been a lot to be alarmed and disturbed by in Channel 4, The Times and The Sunday Times’ .

The snippets of the comedian’s stand-up and TV work woven through the Dispatches film In Plain Sight traced a connection between the heinous things Brand is alleged to have done in private, and the jokes he cracked on TV and in front of live audiences. One 2006 exchange with the model Caprice, shown in the documentary, leapt out: “Don’t be afraid of your own sexuality. Be afraid of mine though.”

Watching at home, we didn’t necessarily need that footage. We were all there, and we all remember it. Channel 4 chief exec Alex Mahon told a Royal Television Society conference last week that she was shocked by “”. It wasn’t, as is sometimes said of matters like these, “a different time”.

But the noughties did have a very different TV landscape. With new digital channels, streaming platforms and an increasingly anything-goes attitude to what exactly was acceptable or helpful to put on screen, it now seems like an irresponsibly carefree time. And it has a lot more to answer for than Gillian McKeith hectoring people about their poo.

Brand, who denies the allegations and who has said that all of his relationships were consensual, broke into TV through the mid- and late-noughties, an era when TV was breaking away – slightly – from the TFI Friday-Fantasy Football-Men Behaving Badly nexus of 90s laddism. That time was, as the editor’s letter in the first issue of Loaded put it, “dedicated to life, liberty and the pursuit of sex, drink, football and less serious matters”.

Instead, the TV of the noughties was defined by irony and a particularly grubby kind of post-millennium hedonism, plus the vague feeling that all the major battles had been won. Politics was fairly dull, the financial crash hadn’t happened yet, and the  boys’ casual homophobia and mockery of any culture outside a 20-mile radius from Jeremy Clarkson’s Oxfordshire home made them beloved iconoclasts.

It was TV’s Banter Era, and Clarkson, James May and Richard Hammond were at the helm, along with Tim Lovejoy from Soccer AM, Keith Lemon on Celebrity Juice and Frankie Boyle and the gang on Mock the Week.

They were all very different, but had in common that they would get away with riskier gags, thanks to a veneer of “satire” (and in Celebrity Juice’s case, being rubbish). The whooping and leering of Soccer AM‘s Soccerettes feature, where a young woman walked a catwalk after removing a team’s shirt – revealing another one underneath – was actually ironic, mate. Chill out.

Russell Brand, at first glance, might not seem like he’d have fit in.He might have banged on about being a West Ham fan, but his aesthetic sat closer to , that elegantly wasted noughties look which riffed on Pete Doherty’s shabby bohemian vibe: loads of beads and/or chains, skinny jeans, deliberately anachronistic headwear.

Brand dressed like a post-Captain Jack Sparrow dandy, and his bird’s nest hair was compared to Amy Winehouse’s beehive. He wasn’t Zoo or Nuts; he worked for the Guardian and guest-edited an issue of the New Statesman, appeared on Newsnight and Question Time, and made a documentary inspired by Jack Kerouac’s On the Road. He styled himself as an intellectual libertine who saw taboos and laughed at them, rather than a standard-issue lad who piled through them without noticing.

But Brand’s affected irony and glee at knowing he was being outrageous – that desperation to be a devil’s advocate – made him far more similar to Clarkson and co than he’d probably have liked to admit. His first big break was on MTV, presenting Dancefloor Chart and Select.

He was sacked after coming into work on 12 September 2001 dressed up as Osama bin Laden, and bringing his drug dealer along with him. Brand introduced his dealer to Kylie Minogue who happened to be around the studios that day. “I thought: ‘It don’t get any better than this,’” Brand recalled later. “And it didn’t, ‘cos they sacked me about two days later.” It was as if was trying to follow in the footsteps of controversy-baiting comedians like Sacha Baron Cohen, but had far less to say.

Brand was one of several comics breaking through by pushing at “taboos” at that time. Jimmy Carr and Frankie Boyle traded in dark material delivered in a deliberately distant, aloof way which invited you to wonder whether they actually meant it or not. Brand made himself so absurd a cock-er-ney caricature and went so far past the mark with interviewees, like when he told Caprice in that same interview to take her knickers off, and mimed masturbating over her, that the whole joke seemed to lie in knowing that he couldn’t possibly be serious.

Just as tastes were changing, digital TV started to splinter the schedules and opened up opportunities for those who wanted to take risks they’d likely have been talked down from on terrestrial channels.

BBC Three had launched in 2003 with a mission to push at the extremities of what the BBC did; to “mess things up a bit”, as Stuart Murphy, who was channel controller at its inception, told me recently. , he said – which debuted on the channel’s opening night – “was definitely that”.

Skins revelled in scuzzy, sexy, narcotic-fuelled drama on E4, and The Mighty Boosh became the weirdest mainstream breakthrough of the decade from BBC Three. The late night spaces of E4’s Big Brother’s Big Mouth and the vaguely current affairs-led forum show Russell Brand’s Got Issues and UK Play’s post-Louis Theroux gonzo doc RE:Brand wouldn’t have existed a decade before when anyone without Sky was stuck with four channels. They were chaotic, anti-mainstream. Brand was loved for it. The RE:Brand finale, titled “Wanky Wanky”, saw him masturbate a man in a pub toilet.

Brand was ubiquitous. He turned up at the Olympics Closing Ceremony in 2012 singing “I am the Walrus”. He defined an era of ironic misogyny. And then TV turned against it – and against him – and even he started to move away from it.

His latter-day persona as a thought leader to his “awakening wonders” on social media is much more in tune with the way that TV talks to us now: sincere, and outwardly inclusive. No longer is it “cool” to be aloof and uncaring and out to shock.

Instead we have kind comedy like Ghosts, we have harmless, silly panel shows like Taskmaster, we have heartwarming tearjerkers like The Repair Shop. Viewers crave the gentle, like Gogglebox, Sewing Bee and .

Watching In Plain Sight, it’s tempting to feel some relief at how far TV has come since. But the echoes are still there. Our Nice TV era is a reaction to everything we indulged, to what we found funny, to the people we made stars.
Somewhere under all the Pottery Throwdowns, there’s the lingering knowledge that we helped make a more cruel and strange TV era happen.
